Texto: The New York Stock Exchange is buying Radiate, a company which creates short videos of career advice from business leaders, to boost its services in the arms race for corporate listings in the world’s biggest equity market.Betty Liu, who founded Radiate and worked as a business journalist for outlets including Bloomberg Television and the Financial Times, will join NYSE as executive vice-chairman as of July 9 and have a seat on the NYSE Group board. “We have 2,400 listed companies on the exchange and we want to create a bigger community for them,” Ms Liu told the FT, saying Radiate’s short videos on leadership and live events would help make a NYSE listing “more than just a trading relationship” for existing members and prospective initial public offering candidates.Her appointment comes just weeks after Intercontinental Exchange, NYSE’s parent, named Stacey Cunningham as the first female leader in the New York exchange’s 226-year history. NYSE and Nasdaq are locked in a battle for corporate listings that involves not just intense blitzes for IPOs, but efforts to persuade companies to transfer from rival exchanges.[Ms Liu will] help us offer our customers even more opportunities to tap the NYSE network to connect and share ideasThe pattern over time has been that Nasdaq wins a greater number of deals, but the “Big Board” attracts listings of larger size. So far this year, 55 companies raising $12.3bn have listed on Nasdaq while 29 companies raising $15.7bn have opted for NYSE.Following the dotcom boom of the 1990s and early 2000s, NYSE changed its standards and has targeted more tech listings, winning high-profile deals in recent years like Snap, the owner of messaging app Snapchat, and music streaming service Spotify.NYSE did not disclose the financial terms of the deal, but said the transaction would not affect ICE’s 2018 results or capital return plans.Radiate, which has just three full-time staff and about 20 freelancers, has built a library of concise video lessons from chief executives about leadership and management challenges, from how to hire good people to how to fire underperformers. Lessons on time management and how chief executives handle emails were among its most popular videos, Ms Liu said.“We look forward to building on Radiate, the innovative business [Ms Liu] founded, as part of our efforts to enrich the NYSE network and experience for our listed issuers and the broader business community,” said Jeff Sprecher, ICE’s chairman and chief executive.Ms Cunningham said Ms Liu would “help us offer our customers even more opportunities to tap the NYSE network to connect and share ideas on our global stage”.

Titular: Intercontinental Exchange: right recipe
Subtitular: Data reigns supreme for the exchange group
Texto: Stacey Cunningham, chief operating officer of the New York Stock Exchange, once took a leave of absence to train in a demanding restaurant kitchen. She is no longer a sous chef. Her appointment on Tuesday makes Ms Cunningham the first female president of the Big Board in its more than 200-year history. Her predecessor, Tom Farley, is departing to set up a “blank-check” shell investment company with Dan Loeb.Ms Cunningham began as an intern on the floor of NYSE in the 1990s. Her career has coincided with the rise of electronification in securities trading that crimped profitability and resulted in a wave of global consolidation among exchanges. NYSE was acquired in 2012 by Intercontinental Exchange.In spite of the acquisition, ICE has opted to focus on data alongside trading. It now makes nearly half of its $6bn in annual revenue from sales of pricing and other financial data. The company believes these two units — data packages and securities exchanges — form a virtuous circle. Its 2015 acquisition of Interactive Data Corporation, a pricing service and data feed for hard-to-value securities, for $5bn, is part of the same strategy. Along with other niche data acquisitions such as S&P Securities Evaluations and Credit Market Analysis, and SuperDerivatives, ICE is creating bundles that buy- and sell-side analysis firms have become heavily dependent on.Data providers have found new favour because of their recurring revenue streams and stickiness among such customers. Meanwhile, NYSE has become a strong rival to Nasdaq for high-profile tech listings such as Snap and Spotify. It remains the leader for global IPOs (little actual trading goes on at the NYSE venue on Wall Street but firms still love to ring the bell). The exchange may be stuck in the middle of a tricky tech revamp but ICE has said that NYSE’s profit margin and cash flow has doubled since it was acquired. Ms Cunningham will be a big figure for NYSE even if her bosses at ICE regard trading as just one ingredient in the dish they are serving.Lex recommends the FT’s Due Diligence newsletter, a curated briefing on the world of mergers and acquisitions. Sign up at ft.com/newsletters.

Titular: NYSE appoints Cunningham first female leader
Subtitular: Tom Farley will leave role as exchange’s president at the end of this week
Texto: Stacey Cunningham will become the first female leader of the 226-year old New York Stock Exchange, taking on the top role of president after the departure of Tom Farley.Ms Cunningham was previously the group’s chief operating officer and will begin on Friday, when Mr Farley leaves. The appointment was confirmed by a spokesperson for Intercontinental Exchange, NYSE’s parent company.Her appointment comes eighteen months after Nasdaq, NYSE’s big rival, named Adena Friedman as its first female head.Ms Cunningham originally started out on the NYSE floor in the 1990s as a “specialist” for JJC, handling the shares of companies such as Hershey Foods and Ambac Financial. After she left the floor in the early 2000s, she took a nine-month programme at the Institute of Culinary Education in Manhattan, which required six weeks working in a restaurant, and rejoined NYSE in 2012 after a spell at Nasdaq.The news was first reported by the Wall Street Journal.Mr Farley will join Far Point, a special purpose acquisition vehicle backed by Daniel Loeb’s Third Point hedge fund, the newspaper said. Mr Farley had been president of NYSE since its purchase by ICE in late 2013.

Titular: ICE to begin futures trading in new alternative Libor rate
Texto: IntercontinentalExchange, which administers the Libor lending rate, is to begin trading futures on the alternative benchmark rate intended to supplant the scandal-hit Libor.The US exchange operator said on Wednesday it would launch 3-month futures contracts based on the Sterling Overnight Index Average, or Sonia, a measure of the short-term price at which banks and building societies lend to each other.The reformed Sonia benchmark part of a broader global push this year by banks and regulators to wean the market off the tarnished Libor rates, whose role has come under fierce scrutiny after banks and brokers were found trying to manipulate them. From next week the Bank of England will begin publishing the new Sonia rates.Libor has been built up over 30 years into a lynchpin of the financial system. Oliver Wyman, the consultancy, estimates total notional exposure to Libor is around $240tn, in the form of mortgages, consumer loans, credit card rates, derivatives and bonds. Companies, banks and consumers use the benchmarks to underpin their payment schedules.IBA, a unit of ICE, took over administration of Libor from the British Bankers Association in 2013, is also working on a reformed version of the benchmark. It argues that many market participants do not want to see Libor phased out.Dozens of companies and financial institutions are wary of moving away from Libor because it could dramatically change their payments exposures. Sonia is an overnight rate that can fluctuate while Libor rates are held steady for a term.The new 3 month Sonia futures contracts will be cash-settled and will debut on June 1, subject to regulatory approval, ICE said. It becomes the second venue to try to capture the potential new business, after CurveGlobal, which is owned by the London Stock Exchange Group and several investment banks.The three month contract is the main reference benchmark for swaps and futures deals. Traders in derivatives markets watch the overnight benchmark rates closely because the returns tend to closely mirror those earned on margin posted on derivatives. The trader can benefit when the spread between Libor and overnight rates widens.ICE’s European exchange is also the main venue for trading and clearing most other sterling-related futures, including gilts and the main interest rate benchmark, called short sterling.

Titular: Chicago Stock Exchange agrees sale to ICE
Subtitular: Move follows collapse of deal with consortium including Chinese investors
Texto: The Chicago Stock Exchange has agreed a sale to Intercontinental Exchange, after the collapse of a deal to sell to a consortium that included Chinese investors.It comes a month after the Chicago exchange abandoned a plan for a controversial acquisition by a bidding group called North America Casin Holdings, which was based on the idea of making Chicago a destination for Chinese listings.The purchase adds to the growing footprint of ICE, which owns the New York Stock Exchange, the Chicago bourse’s larger rival. The exchanges announced the deal on Thursday but did not disclose terms.According to people with knowledge of the deal, that sale price was about $70m compared with the $20m to $30m the Casin group was poised to pay.Atlanta-based ICE has clinched a number of fixed-income acquisitions over the past few years, including that of BondPoint, a bond trading platform, and Interactive Data. The Chicago deal will bolster its equity franchise.John Kerin, chief executive and president of the Chicago exchange, said: “ICE is a proven innovator, and we are looking forward to joining its family of exchanges.”Shares of ICE, which has a market capitalisation of more than $42bn, were up 0.2 per cent in New York.The sale will give NYSE another exchange licence to potentially experiment with, analysts said. In 2016, NYSE bought the National Stock Exchange and plans to launch this year with a taker-maker model — the flipside of the traditional maker taker model for US equity trading whereby exchanges offer rebates to brokers that post orders and charge for those that access existing ones.ICE is a proven innovator, and we are looking forward to joining its family of exchangesThe Chicago exchange, founded in the late 1800s and now accounting for about 1 per cent of daily US equities, will continue to operate as a registered national securities exchange based in Chicago. It represents the last of the traditional regional equity bourses in the US, a group that once included dozens of exchange across the country. They became more difficult and expensive to operate with the rise of modern, largely electronic trading.The sale to ICE is expected to close by the year’s end pending regulatory approval.The Chicago exchange gave up on the Casin deal after regulators rejected it. Regulators also thwarted a plan by the Chicago bourse to offer a delay on some orders.“On the Chicago side, they lost their Chinese-backed bid for regulatory reasons and they also were denied by the SEC recently on their speed bump,” said Doug Clark, head of Americas market structure at ITG, the agency broker. “That cramped their ability to do things that were differentiating and the financing they thought was coming disappeared.”The Securities and Exchange Commission last month voted against the Casin transaction. It had been left in limbo last summer when the commission delayed an earlier approval pending further review.The SEC cited concerns that it conflicted with rules governing exchanges, but the plan had been met with opposition over the presence of Chinese investors in the bidding consortium.

Titular: ICE agrees deal for Chicago Stock Exchange
Subtitular: Atlanta-based group expands footprint in a series of deals
Texto: Fresh from its break-up with a consortium of buyers including Chinese investors, the Chicago Stock Exchange has agreed to wed Intercontinental Exchange, owner of the Chicago exchange’s much larger rival the New York Stock Exchange.Terms were not disclosed. The deal is expected to close by year end pending regulatory approvals. The Securities and Exchange Commission had put the kibosh on the earlier Chicago deal after a saga that included SEC staff approving it, but then regulators imposing a stay on the approval only to ultimately reject it.The purchase of the Chicago Stock Exchange, which handles roughly 1 per cent of US stock trading a day, adds to ICE’s growing exchange footprint.The Atlanta-based group has clinched a number of fixed income acquisitions over the past few years, including its purchase of BondPoint, a bond trading platform, and Interactive Data. Its deal for the Chicago Stock Exchange will in turn bolster its equity franchise.“After an in-depth review of strategic alternatives for CHX, we believe this transaction is clearly in the best interests of CHX stockholders and positions the organisation well going forward,” said Matthew Frymier, chairman of the Chicago Stock Exchange.

Titular: ICE communications head Kelly Loeffler to step down at year’s end
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange has announced the pending resignation of Kelly Loeffler, a senior executive who helped win over Wall Street as the company emerged from roots as an energy trading platform into a pillar of finance. Ms Loeffler, ICE’s head of communications, marketing and investor relations, will depart at the end of the year, the company said. After joining ICE in 2002, Ms Loeffler fielded queries from investors and journalists as the company acquired a string of bourses including the New York Board of Trade and the New York Stock Exchange. She helped prepare ICE for its initial public offering in 2005. In 2004 she married Jeff Sprecher, ICE chief executive, forming a high-profile couple in the exchange industry. ICE did not provide a reason for her departure. Ms Loeffler is co-owner of the Atlanta Dream, a women’s professional basketball team. She had previously been reported to be considering a run for elected office. Scott Hill, chief financial officer, said: “Kelly has been an integral member of our management team and served as a key link to our investors, while mentoring countless employees over the years. She has earned this opportunity to step back and pursue the interests that she put on hold to help build our company. She’s assembled a strong team that will continue to drive us forward.”In recent months ICE said it has added three executives to handle investor relations, communications and marketing functions. They are, respectively, Warren Gardiner, Josh King and Russ Rubino. This story has been corrected to remove a reference to the International Petroleum Exchange, which ICE acquired in 2001, before Ms Loeffler’s arrival.

Titular: Short sterling futures business at decade high on BoE expectations
Texto: Trading in short-term sterling futures at Intercontinental Exchange, the US exchanges operator, has hit its highest level in a decade as investors position themselves for a hawkish Bank of England to push for a rate rise in the next few months.Open interest in short sterling futures contracts, which hedge against potential interest moves over the next three months, hit a record 3.87m contracts last Friday. That broke the record of 3.8m contracts set in July 2007, ICE Futures Europe confirmed.Financial futures are used by investors to speculate and hedge against expected moves in borrowing costs. Sterling futures contracts at ICE are tied to rates set by the Bank of England.The Bank will meet to set rates this week and last month indicated rate rises were likely to come earlier and faster than previously expected. Investors are now pricing in a 70 per cent chance the BoE will raise rates in May, analysts said.The pound rose above $1.40 against the US dollar on Monday after UK and EU leaders struck a preliminary agreement for a 21-month Brexit transition.Rising growth in the eurozone is also fuelling expectations of a change in tone on monetary policy from the European Central Bank during the year. Average daily volume of Euribor futures, which are tied to rates set by the ECB, hit 1m contracts at ICE in February, up 37 per cent year-on-year.

Titular: Nex/Michael Spencer: charging rhinos
Subtitular: Price could be steep if pachyderms join the charge
Texto: An attacking rhino lacks discrimination and has trouble stopping. The same goes for heavyweight bidders for strategic assets. The prospect of Michael Spencer, a City entrepreneur and rhino conservationist, auctioningNex Group has therefore excited minority investors. The price could be steep if a herd of pachyderms joins the stampede.The shares nosed up 30 per cent to 870p on news that CME Group had made an approach for Nex, valuing it at £3.3bn. Bosses at the US exchanges group should warily remember Mr Spencer is as shrewd an observer of business cycles as he is of wildlife. He sold out of voice broking last year.This meant saying goodbye to ICAP, the business he built up through the nineties and noughties, for an estimated personal gain of over £200m. The thrill had gone. ICAP had paid a £55m rate-rigging penalty. The rise of automated trading had made voice brokers — shouty folk who trade weird investments by phone — as endangered as rhinos.This left Mr Spencer with a legacy business presciently stuffed with financial technology assets. CME will be greatly interested in an electronic trading platform for US Treasuries. This would sit sweetly alongside CME’s Treasury futures trading operation. A Nex unit that nets derivatives exposure to reduce the outlay of banks is an attractive asset to numerous buyers.Nex warned on profits recently. This means the midpoint of the acquisition price range estimated by Liberum — 885p per share — would be a steep 37 times current year earnings. This becomes a thriftier 26 times, in line with large quoted exchange groups, at next year’s forecast earnings.Besides, Nex has fintech glitz. It could sell for north of £10 per share if big beasts such as CME’s Terry Duffy and Jeff Sprecher of Intercontinental Exchange lock horns. Mr Spencer would make £650m at that price.Critics of the City say intermediation is useless. Not to Michael Spencer.The Lex team is interested in hearing more from readers. What’s your take on Michael Spencer’s career in the City? Please tell us what you think in the comments section below.

Titular: NYSE to pay $14m in penalties over market disruptions
Subtitular: Deal with US markets regulators includes outage in 2015 and ‘August 24’ trading day
Texto: The New York Stock Exchange has agreed to pay $14m in penalties to settle regulatory charges for multiple violations related to high-profile events in recent years that have disrupted trading in the world’s largest equity market.The exchange, part of Intercontinental Exchange, struck a deal with US markets regulators looking into an outage on the NYSE in 2015 and a chaotic trading day months later known in the industry as “August 24”.The move represents the first charged violation of rules around computerised trading in US equities markets, known as Regulation SCI, and indicates the Securities and Exchange Commission is taking a tougher stance on the interruptions and glitches that have come to characterise modern, highly automated markets.“Exchanges play an important role in protecting investors,” said Stephanie Avakian, co-director of the SEC’s division of enforcement. “For retail investors to have confidence in our markets, exchanges must provide accurate information and comply with legal requirements, including being equipped for unexpected market disruptions.”[The case] shows the SEC is starting to hold the exchanges accountable for major market disruptionsThe SEC order describes a series of problems at NYSE and its affiliates, including the failure to inform traders from 2008 to 2015 that certain types of orders potentially gave its floor brokers an advantage by allowing them to detect the presence but not the size of non-public orders at the exchange.In addition, the SEC said NYSE had inaccurately described share prices as “automated” in the lead-up to a trading shutdown in July 2015, had relied for a time on one of its exchanges’ back-up systems for two other platforms, and improperly issued a trading halt on its Arca exchange in March 2015.On August 24 2015, NYSE Arca improperly applied pricing collars, or limits, when trading resumed in securities that were halted for sharp movements, the SEC said. That added to the day’s tumult by causing delays and additional suspensions as shares were recovering. The session included 1,278 trading suspensions and, of the 999 pauses on Arca, 697 were repeated halts.A NYSE spokesperson said: “We believe this settlement is in the best interest of the NYSE exchanges. We take our regulatory obligations seriously and remain focused on building and maintaining industry leading technology and ensuring that our markets operate with the utmost integrity.”NYSE and its affiliates NYSE Arca and NYSE American neither admitted nor denied the findings in the SEC’s order. ICE had profits of $2.5bn for 2017.Tyler Gellasch, executive director of Healthy Markets Association, an investor-focused trade group, said the case “shows the SEC is starting to hold the exchanges accountable for major market disruptions, like August 24”.

Titular: ICE increases stake in Euroclear to 10%
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange has upped its stake in Euroclear, one of the world’s largest settlement houses, to around 10 per cent, according to two people familiar with its purchases.The US exchanges operator has bought shares from unidentified members of the consortium of banks that own the Belgian-based group. That further strengthens its holding of one of the Europe’s biggest independent market utilities.The group bought a 4.7 per cent stake in Euroclear from Royal Bank of Scotland for €275m in October, in a deal that valued the European group at more than €5bn. Both Euroclear and ICE declined to comment.Euroclear has more than €27.7tn assets under custody, and its main rival is Deutsche Börse’s Clearstream. Settlement houses hold assets, typically highly liquid assets like top-rated government bonds or cash, for investors to use for securities and derivatives trading.In an analysts’ call last November, Jeff Sprecher, chief executive, said the collateral management industry in Europe was changing in response to tougher bank capital requirements, and ICE had already begun conversations with Euroclear management on some initiatives.

Titular: Nasdaq seeks boost from bitcoin products
Subtitular: Chief executive Adena Friedman exploring cryptocurrency offering for retail investors
Texto: Nasdaq is actively exploring bitcoin-linked products and other digital currencies that would appeal to retail investors, Adena Friedman, the exchange’s chief executive has said. The initiative comes as the financial establishment is looking for ways to play a part in the rise of cryptocurrencies, which gathered pace with bitcoin’s sharp appreciation last year, where trading volatility stands in sharp contrast to the placid markets for traditional assets.Nasdaq rivals Cboe Global Markets and CME Group already have rolled out their own bitcoin futures contracts.“We are looking to create a product geared to investors, not traders, as an investible asset,” Ms Friedman told the Financial Times, adding that what she is calling a “digital gold” model might be the most effective precedent to use when structuring retail-friendly products.She described digital gold as a store of value that would exist alongside other “real” currencies, rather than a fully fledged currency in its own right. Nasdaq wants its product to be a vehicle for long-term investment rather than trading or arbitraging against moves in bitcoin.Nasdaq has previously expressed interest in bitcoin futures. While it did not offer specifics, a total return future is a type of derivative that mimics a privately-negotiated swap, but is traded on a regulated exchange.Nasdaq is also likely to create a bitcoin index, which might pave the way for exchange traded products, further broadening the retail appeal for digital currencies. CME has a bitcoin reference rate and Intercontinental Exchange recently unveiled plans to create a consolidated price data feed for cryptocurrencies.Nasdaq officials stress that they have not yet taken any formal decision about when they might unveil this move, not least because US regulators have been opposed to bitcoin-linked ETFs. However, the exchange group has already quietly worked with partners to launch exchange traded notes linked to bitcoin and Ethereum on its Scandinavian exchanges, where regulators have permitted these innovations.And the discussions inside Nasdaq about potential retail bitcoin products have accelerated after the CME and Cboe Global Markets each launched futures contracts linked to bitcoin last year.Retail investors can already trade existing bitcoin futures through retail brokerages such as TD Ameritrade and ETrade and the latest data from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the regulator, show interest from retail investors, even though Cboe’s future, for example, requires an outlay of more than $10,000 based on the current bitcoin price.Until recently, Nasdaq was wary of jumping into the sector since its senior officials feared that the structure of the unregulated digital currency market left retail investors at a deep disadvantage. One problem is that when an investor buys or sells bitcoin at present, brokers usually only offer “indicative” price, rather than stop limits, meaning that brokers cannot guarantee the price at execution. The market is also prone to technical glitches, particularly when volumes are high, and transparency is low. “There are a lot of opportunities to improve the market structure as it exists today,” Ms Friedman said. “Other instruments [in finance] have matured into a mode which is offered to retail investors. There is room for this to happen in cryptocurrency. We will only launch a product if we can make it much better.”

Titular: Cboe approval shakes up stock market’s closing auction
Subtitular: Rival hopes to lure lucrative end-of-day business away from NYSE and Nasdaq
Texto: Regulators have given Cboe Global Markets approval to create an alternative to closing auctions for the US stock market, in a victory for the exchange that could shake up one of the most important moments in the trading day.The decision by the Securities and Exchange Commission, late on Wednesday, is a blow to the New York Stock Exchange, a unit of Intercontinental Exchange and Nasdaq, where nearly all companies list their shares and for whom the closing auction has guaranteed a certain amount of trading volume.While US equities trade on about a dozen exchanges and through a myriad of dark pools during the trading session, the official closing price is set through the auction on a company’s home exchange.The new regulatory approval allows Cboe to launch what it calls the “Cboe Market Close”, which will match trades using the closing price set on the home exchanges, potentially luring volume away from its rivals.Cboe argued industry participants were frustrated with closing auction trading fees, which it said have increased between 16 per cent at NYSE and 60 per cent at Nasdaq over the past five years.“It is a big win and a significant change in market structure,” said Larry Tabb, founder of the Tabb Group, a capital markets consultancy.“To the extent that 8-10 per cent of volumes is at the close, that is 8-10 per cent [Cboe] does not get, but now has access to,” Mr Tabb said. “It could be an impactful aspect of their trading revenues.”Cboe equity exchanges are second to NYSE in terms of volumes traded, but can boast only one corporate listing: Cboe’s own shares.With the growth of index investing and exchange traded funds, the closing auction has become an even more critical part of the overall system, since ETFs need to create or redeem shares by the close of trading.Volume executed in the auctions rose more than 70 per cent between 2012 and 2016 — meaning a growing portion of trading is increasingly expensive.“Cboe Market Close was created in response to widespread industry frustration with existing closing auctions,” said Bryan Harkins, head of US equities and global FX at Cboe, in a statement.Given the increasing importance of the closing auction …and the apparent concerns that a competing facility could have unintended consequences, we respectfully advise great cautionThe SEC approved Cboe’s plan against opposition from NYSE and Nasdaq.A NYSE spokesperson declined to comment on whether the exchange would appeal the regulator’s decision. “The NYSE Closing Auction is consistently the largest daily liquidity event globally thanks to its unique mix of technology and human judgment that reliably delivers the best outcome for listed companies, investors and index providers,” they said.Nasdaq declined to comment.Large fund managers, such as T Rowe Price, and listed companies including FedEx also opposed the approval of Cboe Market Close. For their part, S&P Dow Jones Indices, the owner of the benchmark S&P 500 and other indices widely tracked by ETFs, urged caution.“In keeping with the overall ethos of passive investing, SPDJ applauds any measures that decrease costs, increase transparency and generally result in greater utility for investors,” said Alex Matturri, its chief executive, in a letter to the SEC.“However, given the increasing importance of the closing auction to those same investors, and the apparent concerns that a competing facility could have unintended consequences, we respectfully advise great caution in approaching any changes to this aspect of our market structure.”Supporters included Sifma, the US trade group for the securities industry, rival exchange IEX and market maker Virtu Financial..

Titular: Filings reveal DRW’s climb into top rank of trading firms
Subtitular: A subsidiary of Don Wilson’s firm pulled in nearly $1bn in revenue in two years
Texto: A unit of DRW pulled in almost $1bn in revenue in the space of two years, underlining the Chicago-based firm’s ascent to the upper rank of global proprietary trading companies.The firm, founded by Don Wilson, reported $454.8m in revenue at its DRW Investments LLC subsidiary in 2016, according to accounts made public this month by UK Companies House, a business registry.The figure came on top of $470.2m in 2015, and provides an indication of the size achieved by DRW at a time when trading firms are finding it hard to make money in financial markets experiencing historically low levels of volatility.Proprietary trading firms bet their own capital on the world’s exchanges, often using ultrafast computers to execute deals in fractions of a second. Like most firms, DRW is privately owned and does not announce financial results. Yet the company has discreetly filed years of accounts for DRW Investments at Companies House, going unnoticed by the industry.The accounts put the subsidiary in the same league as top traders whose finances are known. Virtu Financial, one of the few publicly listed proprietary trading firms, in 2016 had adjusted net trading income of $414.1m, a figure that subtracts brokerage commissions and exchange fees from revenue. DRW Investments’ trading expenses totalled $76m in 2016.John Lothian, a markets newsletter publisher, described Mr Wilson and his colleagues as “absolute leaders” in the trading community. “Don not only has tremendous personal influence within the community, but he also has tremendous business influence,” said Mr Lothian, a Chicago-based former futures trader and broker.DRW has become an important source of volume on the world’s largest futures exchanges, and Mr Wilson has pushed the traditionally low-profile industry to advocate for its interests.DRW Investments’ trading activity includes fixed-income derivatives and other futures, according to a company legal filing, and it runs three types of strategies — making markets as a liquidity provider, taking risks on the direction of prices, and high-frequency trading — people familiar with the company said.In 2008, DRW took over Lehman Brothers’ book of foreign exchange, interest rate and agriculture futures when the investment bank collapsed. It was the only non-bank to participate in the fire sale.The same year DRW Investments generated $656.5m in revenue, the most in at least the past decade, according to its accounts.The statements filed at Companies House offer an incomplete picture of the overall business of the DRW parent company, which includes several other subsidiaries. They do not reflect gains or losses at those businesses. A DRW spokeswoman declined to comment.As well as financial figures, the accounts also provide information on DRW Investments’ battle against allegations it manipulated interest-rate contracts. A civil case brought by the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission went to trial in 2016 but has not been adjudicated.The regulator is seeking steep penalties, including a possible trading ban, but DRW Investments’ accounts said management believed the case was without merit and “the ultimate resolution of the matter will not have a material impact on the ongoing operations of the company”.

Titular: London loses oil futures listings as Mifid II bites
Subtitular: ICE shifts 245 North American contracts to US in response to customer demand
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange plans to transfer trading in hundreds of energy futures contracts from London to the US, as customers seek to escape new Mifid II rules governing European financial markets.The company said that as of February 19, 245 futures and options contracts on North American oil and natural gas liquids will be removed from ICE Futures Europe, its London-based derivatives bourse, and instead traded on its ICE Futures US exchange.That would put trading under the oversight of the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission rather than European regulators.Europe’s far-reaching new Mifid II markets legislation sets stricter transparency standards on institutions trading on EU-based markets. It took effect on January 3.Traders also now face tighter position limits, designed to prevent any trader from having an outsized influence on the market, for a multitude of commodities contracts listed in Europe. The limits are set by national regulators and although the UK is leaving the EU, authorities have insisted on fully applying Mifid II.By contrast, position limits for US energy futures are governed by exchanges and are less restrictive. A proposed rule to allow the CFTC to directly set position limits remains unfinished and would have addressed only a handful of contracts in any event.When US lawmakers passed the Dodd-Frank financial reforms in 2010, the EU appeared to have less regulation, said Paul Architzel, a partner at WilmerHale, a law firm in the US. But with Mifid II now complete, “some people are finding that the US regulations are less onerous”, he said.Jeff Sprecher, chief executive of Atlanta-based ICE, has been an outspoken critic of Mifid II, once calling it “the worst piece of legislation I have seen in my career”.An ICE spokesman declined to comment.The ICE contracts shifting from London to the US do not include the biggest North American oil futures such as benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude, heating oil and gasoline futures, the company told customers in a notice on Wednesday. Brent, ICE’s flagship North Sea crude contract, will remain listed in London.However, they do feature contracts heavily traded by both commercial energy companies and hedge funds, such as one tracking the difference between WTI and Brent crude.The announcement could be a defensive move for ICE, whose chief competitor in energy futures is Chicago-based CME Group. CME shut down a fledgling European exchange last year, leaving all its contracts under US oversight.As Mifid II took effect, some traders in energy contracts began closing positions on ICE and opening equivalent ones on CME, a broker said before Wednesday’s announcement. Filing paperwork to European regulators for each individual contract was creating headaches, an oil trader said.Daily volume in CME’s main WTI-Brent difference contract has trebled this month compared to the 2017 average. ICE reported zero volume last week in its WTI-Brent contract, called BTD, with transactions ticking up into the hundreds early this week.The ICE notice said it was shifting the contracts “following the recent growth in demand for execution in certain North American energy contracts in the US”, as well as ICE’s recent acquisition of NGX, a North American natural gas, electricity and oil marketplace. On Thursday, the exchange backtracked on plans to list 10 new contracts on ICE Futures Europe, not explaining why.While traded under US jurisdiction, the contracts would still be guaranteed by the company’s London-based clearing house.In addition, the US-based contracts “will continue to be traded using the same ICE platform technology”, ICE said.The computer “matching engine” for both ICE’s Europe and US exchanges is located in Chicago.

Titular: US exchanges to face lawsuit over dealings with HFT
Subtitular: Appeals court revives claims that high-speed traders were given unfair advantage
Texto: The largest US exchanges will face claims that they cheated investors by favouring high-frequency traders, after a group of pension funds won a federal appeals court ruling on Tuesday.The ruling, which overturns a lower court’s decision to throw the case out, is the latest setback for the New York Stock Exchange, Nasdaq and Cboe Global Markets and comes as exchanges are facing increasing pressure over their practices.The lawsuit was first brought in 2014 by plaintiffs including the City of Providence, Rhode Island, the Plumbers and Pipefitters national pension fund and Great Pacific Securities, at a time when the Michael Lewis book Flash Boys had caused a groundswell of concern about high-frequency traders. The book alleged that markets were “rigged” for the benefit of HFTs.“The lead plaintiffs, institutional investors who traded on the defendant stock exchanges during the class period, allege that the exchanges misled them about certain products and services that the exchanges sold to high-frequency trading firms, which purportedly created a two-tiered system that favoured those firms at the plaintiffs’ expense,” the ruling on Tuesday said.At issue are certain types of buy and sell orders offered by exchanges, as well as the sale of detailed market data to HFTs along with fast access to that information.HFTs typically use sophisticated computer programmes to trade stock positions, sometimes faster than a blink of an eye, collecting a profit on small differences in stock prices rather than holding stocks for long periods.“Relevant to this appeal, the plaintiffs allege that the [HFT] firms engage in predatory practices, such as repeatedly ‘front-running’ other market participants: anticipating when a large investment of a given security is about to be made, purchasing shares of the security in advance of the investment, and then selling those shares to the buying investors at slightly increased prices,” the ruling said.The plaintiffs said they account for nearly three-quarters of exchanges’ equity trading.The appeals court on Tuesday overturned a 2015 ruling that said the exchanges had immunity to such claims based on their regulatory status.Officials for NYSE, owned by Intercontinental Exchange, Nasdaq, Bats Global Markets, now owned by Cboe, and the Chicago Stock Exchange either declined to comment or did not respond to requests for comment. The exchanges have previously moved to dismiss the complaint.They are facing criticism from investors on multiple fronts over their practices and prices.Earlier this month, 24 companies — including Citadel Securities, Fidelity Investments and Vanguard — petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission to require exchanges to conduct a thorough review of the collection, distribution and sale of market data.Data fees have been a hot-button issue in equities markets for years. Exchanges have been pressured by falling profit margins on trading and so have looked to maximise prices for data. Traders, whose profits have been squeezed of late because of historically low volatility, have balked at those prices.

Titular: Isda reopens applications for credit derivatives role
Texto: The swaps industry’s main trade body is reopening the tender to run the controversial committees that determine when a company has failed to honour its credit derivative debts, after a planned handover to a new secretary fell through.The International Swaps and Derivatives Association said on Thursday it would reopen the tender for the role of secretary to the committees that determine if a company defaulted on payments for credit default swaps.Isda holds the role and was due to pass it onto ICE Benchmark Administration (IBA), a unit of US exchanges operator Intercontinental Exchange. However, IBA withdrew last month when the two sides were unable to agree on some of the US group’s proposed changes.The committees judge when a company is in default, seeking to avoid widespread confusion or drawn-out legal disputes in the $10tn market. But its rulings leave winners and losers in the market.Although it administers the process, the DC secretary does not vote on whether credit events have occurred.Last month, an Isda determinations committee hit the headlines when it ruled that attempts to trigger the contracts of commodities broker Noble bilaterally were only valid if backed up with supporting documentation. That led to uncertainty over whether sellers owe money to buyers of credit.

Titular: Fangs futures debut as tech stocks boom inspires a new market
Subtitular: The launch by ICE of a futures contract made up of big tech stocks seeks to tap investor enthusiasm
Texto: A leading exchange operator is getting in on investor enthusiasm for Fangs, a small basket of highly valuable technology stocks, with the launch of a futures contract branded with the catchy acronym.The Fangs — Facebook, Amazon, Netflix and Alphabet, the parent company of Google — are joined by six other tech names in the futures contract that began trading Wednesday on Intercontinental Exchange. “Trade the top of tech,” said ICE in an announcement to customers.ICE, which also owns the New York Stock Exchange, created the NYSE FANG+ stock index in September. The equally-weighted basket is up 58 per cent in the year to date, compared to a 16 per cent gain for the S&P 500 stock index.It is the latest instance of a derivatives market trying to cash in on excitement happening outside its gates. Last week CME Group, the world’s biggest futures exchange operator, said it planned to offer bitcoin futures as prices for the cryptocurrency soar.ICE will next year lose the right to list futures on the Russell 2000 small-stock index as they migrate to CME. The Russell index family is owned by London Stock Exchange Group, an ICE competitor. The FANG+ index is controlled by ICE.Trabue Bland, president of ICE Futures US, said his company invented NYSE FANG+ in response to customer demand. Futures volume had topped 40 contracts at midday in New York.“We were out talking to customers about equity indexes, and this was the product that came back the most. It was the stocks that people were most excited about, and most excited about trading in one basket,” Mr Bland said.In addition to the four stocks captured by the Fang acronym, the equally weighted ICE index includes Apple, Alibaba, Baidu, Nvidia, Tesla and Twitter. The total market value of the 10 stocks is $3.5tn.Nicholas Colas of DataTrek, a research company, said it was unclear what question the product was supposed to answer or who the main users of the product would be, and called the US-listed stocks in the index “remarkably geo-centric”.He was amused by the “trade the top of tech” announcement. “Is it really the top of tech, like 1999?” he asked.Equity investors can already trade the stocks individually or gain similar exposure through exchange traded funds, baskets of securities that trade as a single name on a stock exchange. Last summer an ETF launched with the ticker “FNG” holding many of the same names.In contrast to ETFs or cash equities, trading futures only requires traders to post margin against their positions, tying up less capital. ICE described its products as a “hedging mechanism to quickly increase or decrease tech exposure in equities portfolios”.

Titular: ICE confident it is not over-reliant on sale of trading data
Subtitular: Exchange operator confident even as US Treasury touts recommendations over market fees
Texto: Executives at Intercontinental Exchange, which owns the New York Stock Exchange, on Thursday sought to play down its reliance on the sale of stock trading data amid mounting questions about potential changes in how exchanges handle this information.Data sales have become an increasingly important revenue stream for stock exchanges as profit margins on trading have declined over the past decade with regulatory change and heightened competition. Technological advancement and the rise of high-frequency trading has also made information on the stock market more valuable.In October, the US Treasury delivered a comprehensive report on capital markets to President Donald Trump that included recommendations on market data. The report also highlighted the debate over the rise of high-frequency traders. Critics argue HFTs can seek to use speed along with market data feeds to trade ahead of long-term investors, who see their costs increased.Jeffrey Sprecher, ICE’s chief executive, told analysts on a earnings call on Thursday that “the controversy around this is a legacy issue that’s been going on for a long time and we’re still debating the Flash Boys mentality in a world where I don’t believe that the same dynamics exist today”.In the 2014 book Flash Boys, author Michael Lewis argued that the markets were “rigged” to the benefit of high-speed traders, setting off a firestorm around them that has since died down. Mr Sprecher said that exchanges like NYSE “have gotten more sophisticated in the way we run our platforms to take out arbitrage. We’ve been able to time markets. We measure cables, work with networks and so on and so forth that has essentially taken the Flash Boys type of behaviour out of the markets.”He also said that ICE had fielded “a number of questions” from investors about NYSE’s data sales since the Treasury report.“The sales of NYSE real-time equity data products are expected to be less than $90m in annual revenue to us and their growth has been relatively stagnant,” he said. “These products account for approximately 2 per cent of ICE’s annual revenue and whether their growth continues to slow, stabilise or improve, over time, it will not be particularly meaningful to the growth plan that ICE is pursuing.”In the report, the Treasury recommended the Securities and Exchange Commission consider whether data fees are “fair and reasonable” when approving changes to them, wading into a bitter battle between brokers and exchanges over the cost of market data. It also said that data fees made up nearly a third of exchanges’ $28.3bn in revenue in 2016.Scott Hill, ICE’s chief financial officer, added that the “vast majority” of ICE’s $2bn data revenues come from “a broad array of proprietary pricing data, reference data, analytics, indices, futures data and desktops and connectivity solutions across multiple asset classes and consumed by customers around the world”. He forecast that ICE’s data revenues would grow 6 per cent in 2017 despite a general decline in revenues from real-time cash equity data products.Exchanges also contribute to another data feed called the SIP, but this includes less information on the market making in stocks at any given moment and is delivered at a slower speed than proprietary feeds.Since the release of the report, the SEC has named Brett Redfearn, former global head of market structure at JPMorgan, as the head of its trading and markets division. With Mr Redfearn having previously worked for a broker, the appointment fanned further speculation of an effort to revise the rules around pricing of stock market data feeds.

Titular: ICE to sell commodities trading platform Trayport for £550m
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange, the US group, plans to sell Trayport, a UK commodities trading platform it bought nearly two years ago, to Canadian exchange TMX Group in a deal valued at £550m.ICE said on Friday that it will sell Trayport for £550m in cash, but in return buy the energy broker Shorcan Energy and NGX, an Alberta-based exchange, together valued at £200m.The exchange and clearing house operator had come under pressure for buying Trayport in late 2015 for $650m on the grounds that the deal could curb competition in the European energy trading market.In March, the UK appeals court upheld a ruling by the Competition and Markets Authority that ICE had to sell the business. The CMA’s initial ruling last October was the first time the CMA had demanded a company sell an asset it had already bought since the watchdog replaced the merged Office of Fair Trading and Competition Commission in 2014.The CMA has approved the sale to TMX Group, the owner of the Toronto Stock Exchange, ICE said. ICE added that it had entered into a non-binding memorandum of understanding agreeing to “explore in future further avenues for possible collaboration” with the Canadian group.TMX Group said the deal was expected to have a positive impact on its adjusted earnings per share and be accretive in 2018.

Titular: ICE ramps up move on corporate bond market
Subtitular: US exchanges operator to buy BondPoint from Virtu Financial in $400m deal
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange, the US exchanges operator, has underscored its designs on the corporate bond market by agreeing to buy fixed income trading platform BondPoint from Virtu Financial for $400m in cash.ICE beat competition from other established venues including Tradeweb and MarketAxess, the largest corporate bond trading platform in the US, according to people familiar with the bidding process.It comes as trading in fixed income markets is increasingly being carried out electronically, with a host of established platform providers vying with upstart venues.BondPoint, which focuses mainly on retail investors who trade corporate and municipal bonds, will complement ICE’s credit derivatives platform CreditEx, according to analysts. It will also fit with ICE’s acquisition of Interactive Data in 2015, which provides credit market information to investors.“They have a strong franchise in credit derivatives. They have invested in credit data. It makes sense that they would buy an asset that furthers corporate bond trading as well,” said Kevin McPartland, head of market structure research as Greenwich Associates. “It completely makes sense.”It also sets up the potential for ICE to go head-to-head with MarketAxess in more institutional client-to-dealer trading, said analysts at Raymond James.Jeffrey Sprecher, chairman and chief executive at ICE, said: “We believe adding BondPoint’s capabilities to our data and technology infrastructure will allow us to continue to innovate for our customers as the fixed income markets evolve.”Virtu acquired BondPoint as part of its takeover of KCG Holdings this year but quickly moved to offload the platform as it seeks to streamline the business. A spokesperson for Virtu said that the sale is on top of the target of $250m in cost savings being sought from the KCG merger.The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2018. Virtu said that it would use the proceeds to pay back part of an outstanding loan from the KCG acquisition.“After a thorough analysis, we concluded that BondPoint is a unique asset better suited to operate outside of Virtu’s core operations,” said Douglas Cifu, Virtu chief executive.

Titular: ICE to buy bond trading venue from Virtu for $400m
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange, the US exchanges operator, has agreed to buy fixed-income trading platform BondPoint from Virtu Financial for $400m in cash.Virtu acquired BondPoint as part of its takeover of KCG Holdings earlier this year, but it has quickly moved to offload the platform as it seeks to streamline the business.The deal comes as trading in fixed-income markets is increasingly done electronically, with established exchange providers vying with upstart venues to capitalise on the changing landscape.The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2018.“We believe adding BondPoint’s capabilities to our data and technology infrastructure will allow us to continue to innovate for our customers as the fixed income markets evolve,” said Jeffrey Sprecher, chairman and chief executive at ICE. “We look forward to welcoming the BondPoint team to ICE, and supporting solutions that enable our customers to transact with confidence in an increasingly transparent, automated and data-driven marketplace.”It comes on the same day that ICE announced it has bought a 4.7 per cent stake in Euroclear, one of the world’s largest settlement houses, for €275m.

Titular: ICE buys Euroclear stake from RBS for €275m
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange, the US exchanges operator, has strengthened its hand in the plumbing of European markets, snapping up a 4.7 per cent stake in Euroclear, one of the world’s largest settlement houses, for €275m.Royal Bank of Scotland offload its entire shareholding and the deal values the Belgian-based group at more than €5.7bn. ICE also said it anticipates having a member on the board.The move comes as ICE awaits the outcome of the UK’s negotiations to leave the European Union. ICE has spent more than £4bn to make London the centre of its European operations. ICE also has a clearing house based in the Netherlands.Euroclear has more than €27.7tn assets under custody and its main rival is Deutsche Borse’s Clearstream. Settlement houses hold assets, typically highly liquid assets like top-rated government bonds or cash, for investors to use for securities and derivatives trading.Analysts have tipped Euroclear as a potential target for the London Stock Exchange Group. UBS in August described it as a “hidden jewel”.“We are thrilled to become a shareholder of Euroclear,” said Jeff Sprecher, chief executive of ICE. “We look forward to supporting Euroclear’s role as an independent provider of vitally important financial market infrastructure services.”

Titular: Credit derivatives market woes deepen after ICE exit
Subtitular: NYSE owner took on oversight role almost a year ago to improve transparency of resolution process
Texto: When things go wrong in the $10tn market for derivatives that insure against the risk of a company defaulting, buyers and sellers turn to the industry’s global trade body for answers.Rulings from the International Swaps and Derivatives Association on whether a company has failed to honour its debts are central to the functioning of the market, leaving winners and losers among banks, hedge funds and asset managers depending on which side of the credit default swap they are on.Almost a decade after credit derivatives had an ill-starred role in the financial crisis, ISDA — whose committees decide whether a company has had a so-called “credit event” — is again drawing intense scrutiny. The committees are made up of representatives of banks that often stand to lose or gain from the outcome.The organisation’s troubles deepened this week after Intercontinental Exchange, the owner of the New York Stock Exchange and Liffe derivatives exchange, said it no longer wanted to oversee the administration of the determination committees. ICE had agreed to take on the role almost a year ago in a move by ISDA designed to give the process more transparency and independence.However, the transition to ICE has been scuppered by the exchange operator insisting that the banks that make up the committees provide it legal indemnity in the event rulings trigger lawsuits. A run of recent contentious disputes have highlighted how high the stakes are in the process and the complexity of issues involved.In August, the world’s largest banks ended up in a tussle over CDS written against the debt of troubled commodity trader Noble Group, after ISDA was unable to rule on whether a credit event had occurred for the first time in its history.Many buyers of CDS on Noble demanded payment from the banks that sold them credit protection. Efforts by the buyers to settle the contracts bilaterally jarred the CDS market. The ISDA committee eventually made a ruling a month later that halted these attempts, but only with a qualified and narrow verdict that did not rule on whether Singapore-based Noble had actually triggered a credit event.Given the scope for controversy, Ice Benchmark Administration insisted that it needed some form of indemnity from committee members, according to people with knowledge of the matter.But IBA was unable to reach an agreement on key terms with the banks and investment groups that comprise the five current determination committees. Negotiations were derailed in part by this dispute over who would be legally liable for their often controversial decisions. At present committee members do not underwrite any potential legal liabilities stemming from decisions to ISDA. ICE declined to comment on the matter.“I have no idea why ICE could not reach an agreement, but obviously over the last weeks and months there have been so many difficult determinations with long delays,” says Jochen Felsenheimer, a managing director at XAIA Investment, an asset manager that specialises in CDS.Disclosed in a press release after US markets closed last Friday, the withdrawal of ICE underlines the challenge ISDA faces in finding a third party suited to overseeing the often complex process of adjudicating on defaults, but which is also independent enough to satisfy critics calling for reform.“People manage conflicts of interest all the time, but this is quite a distinct process,” says one CDS trader. “I’m confident that there’ll be a third party doing this at some stage; you just need to find the right platform. It’s not a benchmark and IBA is really a benchmark publisher.”The recent run of disputes in the CDS market comes in spite of ISDA rewriting the rules in 2014. An effort to iron out flaws in the process was conducted after the chaos caused by credit derivatives in the financial crisis, when institutions and investors had to settle masses of these contracts bilaterally and ended up in bitter disputes over whether buyers owed sellers money.“ISDA is committed to safe and efficient markets and ensuring the credit derivatives market remains a viable long-term solution for CDS participants,” ISDA said.Even after the extensive overhaul, it remains difficult to have a uniform set of terms and conditions for a product linked to defaults — frequently unpredictable events in different jurisdictions.“Clearly, the 2014 definitions are a bit tricky and have not made things less complex,” says Dr Felsenheimer.The failure of ICE to reach an agreement means that ISDA will have to continue administering the committees until it can find another solution. The trade body’s term as secretary is due to expire in April and ISDA says it “will now pursue other avenues for the transition” to a third-party secretary.Additional reporting by Philip Stafford

Titular: ICE drops out of Isda credit-derivatives committee role
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange will not administer the controversial derivatives industry committees that determine when a company is in default on its credit default swaps, after the committees failed to back the US group’s proposed rule changes.The International Swaps and Derivatives Association said late on Friday that the determinations committees (DC) – made up of representatives of banks and investors – and ICE Benchmark Administration had been unable to reach an agreement on IBA becoming their secretary. The two sides had been negotiating directly.“As a result, Isda and the determining committee will now pursue other avenues for the transition to a new DC secretary before Isda’s term as secretary expires in April 2018,” it said in a statement.Isda announced in December last year that IBA, as an independent organisation, would take over the role of DC secretary to keep up with rapidly evolving governance standards.The committees judge when a company is in default, seeking to avoid widespread confusion or drawn-out legal disputes. Last month, an Isda determinations committee hit the headlines when it ruled that attempts to trigger the contracts of commodities broker Noble bilaterally were only valid if backed up with supporting documentation. That led to uncertainty over whether sellers owe money to buyers of credit.

Titular: Bank of England policy shift boosts ICE trading
Subtitular: Currency and interest rate futures contract volumes surge
Texto: Expectations of a UK interest rate rise by the Bank of England in the coming months are providing a boost to the financial futures business of Intercontinental Exchange, the US exchanges operator.Volumes for the world’s second largest exchange group by market capitalisation have risen to their highest levels in four years as investors buy contracts that help insulate their portfolios from adverse changes in currencies and interest rates.Financial futures are used by investors to speculate and hedge against expected moves in borrowing costs. Rising average daily volumes in short-term sterling interest rate futures, and euribor futures at ICE, are tied to rates set by the Bank of England and the European Central Bank.Investors are expecting the BoE will raise its current base rate of 0.25 per cent before the end of the year to curtail inflation running above the central bank’s target of 2 per cent. The pound has risen to its firmest level since the June 2016 EU referendum, while the two-year gilt yield has jumped above the current base rate to 0.44 per cent this month.“The lag in the interest cycle of the UK/Europe against the US has clearly been reflected in ICE’s underperforming financial volumes against the CME but the European cycle could be turning,” said Richard Repetto, an analyst at Sandler O’Neill in New York.However, economists noted that the ECB was still buying assets as part of its easing programme, while a UK rate rise would be likely a one-off.“Unless signs of sustained inflationary pressures emerge it’s hard to believe that this will be the start of the tightening cycle — particularly given the UK housing market appears to be close to flat at present,” said Simon Derrick, chief markets strategist at BNY Mellon.Hedging activity has doubled short-term interest rate volumes so far during September versus August. Transactions are averaging 3.8m contracts a day for the month, and are up 60 per cent year on year.The volume figures for ICE are the highest since its record year of 2013, when speculation about the eurozone’s future and changing US monetary policy sent average daily volume in financial products to nearly 3m contracts a day, according to broker Sandler O’Neill.The move represents a change in fortune for ICE, whose financial futures business has lagged behind that of its great rival CME Group in the intervening years.ICE expanded into the market at the end of 2013 by acquiring the London derivatives exchange Liffe as part of the $11bn NYSE Euronext deal.CME’s interest rates business has set volume records in three of the last four years, and is currently averaging a record 8.26m contracts per day in interest rate contracts this year, Sandler added.Chicago’s CME is US-focused, and the home for trading both short-term and long-term US futures. The Federal Reserve has indicated there will be four further rate rises by the end of 2018.

Titular: CME to exit CDS clearing business, cedes ground to ICE
Texto:
CME Group will no longer clear credit default swaps, ceding ground to rival Intercontinental Exchange in a business established after the financial crisis.
Credit default swaps offer investors protection against the default of a borrower or index of borrowers. Exchanges and policy makers moved to push the derivatives on to regulated clearinghouses after uncleared swaps sold by the insurer AIG necessitated its government bailout in 2008.In 2009, both CME and ICE began clearing credit default swaps, but the latter has absorbed more business. The average daily notional value of derivatives cleared at ICE’s US credit clearinghouse is $34bn, according to the company. CME clears about $1.5bn in notional credit default swaps daily.CME has been trimming businesses that don’t make money. Earlier this year it announced the closure of its loss-making London exchange and clearing house after failing to gain traction among European customers.The company said it will exit the credit default swap clearing business by mid-2018, returning $650m in clearing funds to members at the clearing house. Another $50m contributed by CME will be returned to its treasury.CME will continue to clear over-the-counter interest rate swaps and foreign exchange products, where margin money can be offset against margin held for similar futures contracts.Clearing interest rate swaps and credit default swap contracts has contributed 2 per cent of CME’s $3.6bn in annual revenue.

Titular: ICE to ‘Go West’ with Chicago-to-Tokyo network
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange and a consortium of high-speed traders have teamed up to sell access to an ultrafast network between the financial centres of Chicago and Tokyo.Called Go West, the wireless and cable route is set to launch in the fourth quarter.It was started by top traders including DRW, IMC, Jump Trading and XR Trading in an effort to pool resources at a time when market makers are being pressured by an environment of rising costs and low volatility and volumes, the core element of profitable trading.The deal, whose financial terms were not disclosed, will enhance an existing wireless network that ICE sells to financial services companies, while Go West gets a reseller for bandwidth its architects won’t be using, a person briefed the deal said. The Go West network also connects with a data center in Illinois for ICE’s rive CME Group.“We’re excited to add Go West’s key Chicago to Tokyo route to our growing range of connectivity options,” said Jonathan Reeve, global head of connectivity and consolidated feeds at ICE Data Services. “As the demand for data capacity, speed and security increases, Go West extends our network’s geographical reach and offers a new alternative for customers that require ultra-low latency connectivity between North American and Asian markets.”The network uses a system of wireless towers, fiber-optic lines and submarine cables to connect Chicago and Tokyo.

Titular: David Peniket steps down as Intercontinental Exchange reshuffles top brass
Texto: David Peniket, one of the key drivers in Intercontinental Exchange’s growth in London over the last 15 years, is to step down from his role amid a reshuffle of ICE’s top management in Europe.Mr Peniket, who joined ICE when the US group acquired the International Petroleum Exchange in 2002, is to retire and will be replaced by Stuart Williams, promoted from his role as chief operating officer to president at ICE Futures Europe.At the same time ICE also appointed Timothy Bowler from Goldman Sachs to be president of ICE Benchmark Administration, the ICE unit that operates benchmark indices such as Libor, ICE Swap rate for interest rate derivatives, and the LBMA silver price auction, which it won in late August. Prior to Goldman Sachs, Bowler worked for four years at the US Treasury where he last served as counselor to Secretary Jack Lew.Mr Bowler’s appointment will allow Finbarr Hutcheson, the current president of IBA, to move across to become head of ICE Clear Europe, ICE’s London-based clearing house. Mr Hutcheson’s new role had been announced in February when Paul Swann, the current incumbent, also said he would retire this year. All the appointments will become effective from October.Mr Swann and Mr Peniket have been key figures in ICE’s growth in London. Mr Peniket’s role has grown after Atlanta-based ICE has spent more than $4bn on a string of London assets, such as the IPE, the Liffe derivatives exchange and Climate Exchange, whose names have disappeared under the ICE brand. Revenues from its UK operations topped $1.4bn in 2015. Mr Swann oversaw the launch of the first clearing house in London in 100 years when ICE Clear Europe opened in London in late 2008.Jeff Sprecher, chief executive of ICE, welcomed their appointments and thanked Mr Peniket and Mr Swann “for their outstanding contributions to ICE”.

Titular: Massachusetts launches probe into ‘maker taker’ rebate system
Subtitular: State looking at whether payments by exchanges creates a conflict that hurts investors
Texto: Massachusetts on Tuesday entered the debate over sales practices in the US stock market as it launched an investigation into whether paying rebates on bids and offers hurts investors.William Galvin, the state’s secretary of the commonwealth, said it had sent letters to retail brokerages Charles Schwab, Scottrade, TD Ameritrade, Fidelity, E* Trade, Edward Jones and Morgan Stanley inquiring about routing orders to exchanges that pay rebates.“Institutional brokers are responsible for placing millions of dollars of average investors’ life savings in their employers’ pension plans, as well as in mutual funds and variable annuities,” Mr Galvin said. “If financial rebates or kickbacks create a conflict that results in less than the best deal for the investors, this practice must stop.”Rebates are part of a two-way system known as “maker-taker” whereby equity exchanges pay brokers to provide prices on their platforms. Exchanges also charge brokers and market makers for accepting, or taking, bids and offers on their venues. The difference between the two is revenue for the exchanges.The level of both fees and rebates have to be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.Critics of maker-taker have long argued that the system creates the potential for conflicts of interest that would drive brokers to post orders to venues with the highest rebates, which may not ultimately be in the best interest for investors.Others say that eliminating rebates could cost investors, as brokers would have to widen the difference, or spread, between quoting a buying and selling price for a share.Some market participants have said that a new administration in Washington that has promised reform of financial regulation and staff changes at the SEC could create an opportunity to revisit the maker-taker model.In a press release announcing the investigation, Mr Galvin cited a recent editorial in the New York Times by Jonathan Macey, a professor at Yale Law School, and David Swensen, Yale’s chief investment officer, arguing that brokers pick exchanges that pay “kickbacks at a price disadvantage to investors”.Mr Galvin said his office was looking into whether brokers were meeting their obligation to get the best prices for customers.Morgan Stanley, Fidelity, Edward Jones, TD Ameritrade and Scottrade declined to comment while officials for E* Trade and Charles Schwab were not immediately available to comment.A few years ago, Jeffrey Sprecher, the head of Intercontinental Exchange, which owns the New York Stock Exchange, raised the idea of eliminating maker-taker. In a recent blueprint for revitalising markets, Adena Friedman, Nasdaq chief executive, argued for “an intelligent rebate/fee structure”, but also cautioned on “policies that would eliminate or significantly reduce rebates in the context of less liquid stocks where incentivisation of market making is most impactful”.IEX, which became an exchange last year, opposes rebates while Bats Global Markets, owned by the Chicago Board Options Exchange, recently unveiled a flat-fee model for one of its venues in response to industry demand.

Titular: Euronext agrees new derivatives clearing deal with LCH
Texto: Euronext has finalised a deal to keep its derivatives clearing with LCH in France, in a move that ends the European exchange operator’s threat to take its business to rival ICE Clear Europe.The group has agreed a new 10-year deal with the French arm of LCH, its long-standing clearing house, and will swap a 2.3 per cent stake in the parent LCH Group for an 11.1 per cent stake in the French business. The deal was struck in conjunction with the London Stock Exchange Group, which majority owns LCH Group.It has also secured pre-emption rights if the LCH parent company decides to sell more than 50 per cent of the shares in LCH France.Euronext had tried to pressure the LSE in April to reopen talks over the €510m sale of the French clearing house to Euronext, with plans to move its derivatives and commodities business from the unit to rival Intercontinental Exchange. Euronext supplies around half its business and has long been keen on the asset.“LCH SA is a core strategic asset and neither LCH Group nor London Stock Exchange Group have any intention to sell it,” LCH said in a statement on Tuesday.The move will increase the LSE’s ownership of LCH to 59 per cent from 57.8 per cent. The deal with ICE has been terminated, Euronext said.The two parties will aim to achieve cuts of up to 15 per cent in clearing fees. Euronext will also recognise at closing a net capital gain following the share swap of around €24m. A formal deal is likely to be completed in the fourth quarter.Stéphane Boujnah, chief executive of Euronext, said the deal “also provides Euronext with a sizeable ownership position in a leading multi-asset clearing house based in the Eurozone with strong positions in the fast growing fixed income and CDS businesses.”

Titular: ICE pushes further into European energy trading
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange, the US exchanges operator, is preparing to push further into European energy trading after purchasing the 21 per cent it does not own in Endex, a Dutch energy exchange, from Gasunie.ICE said it bought the outstanding stake to help it develop the Dutch gas futures and options market, one of Europe’s most active hubs for trading derivatives in gas.US-based ICE did not disclose the terms of the deal and said it was immaterial to their financial results. It bought its majority share in Endex in 2013 from Gasunie and also set up a joint venture later that year with the European gas infrastructure group. When purchasing the original 79 per cent stake, ICE said the net tangible and identifiable intangible assets acquired were $43m.The Dutch gas market is based on the virtual Title Transfer Facility (TTF) hub. Europe’s benchmarks for natural gas have been emerging in recent years but have yet to develop the deep liquidity seen with US counterparts like the Henry Hub.

Titular: World cotton futures die a quiet death
Subtitular: Existing US benchmark may be flawed, but ICE’s alternative failed to take off
Texto: Creating a new cotton futures contract took Intercontinental Exchange years of planning, multiple rounds of wrangling with cotton merchants and finally an act of US Congress — but the exchange operator has quietly pulled the plug just 18 months after its debut.The global product was designed as an alternative to the US cotton futures contract that has been the industry benchmark for decades, but whose limitations have contributed to wild price swings.The new product, however, failed to take off, underlining the challenge of creating new derivatives products from scratch. Despite early expressions of interest, the global contract never attracted much volume after its launch in November 2015.The last trade took place a year ago. Late on Friday, ICE said it was delisting world cotton futures effective on Monday.The world futures were designed so traders could buy cotton grown on farms from west Africa to Brazil for delivery to warehouses in several countries. Listing the product required an act of Congress to amend rules pertaining to how bales are graded — a legislative saga that included a temporary block by Ted Cruz, a senator from the top cotton-producing state of Texas.Merchants had advocated for a world futures contract to overcome the constraints of the longstanding benchmark, which allows only US-grown bales to satisfy delivery obligations. When domestic supplies are tight, market squeezes and wild price moves sometimes result.“I think the exchange responded to the strong urgings of some of the leading members of the trade, but it never made sense,” said Herman Kohlmeyer, a cotton broker in New Orleans. “And it was too complicated.”The failure of the world cotton futures contract speaks to the difficulty of generating interest in a new derivatives market when liquidity is concentrated in another one, however flawed it might be.The costs of entering and exiting positions in a thinly traded market can outweigh the benefits of a contract that better addresses a company’s risks. Without commercial traders, hedge funds and proprietary trading firms will be reluctant to dive in and provide volume.Despite its drawbacks, the ICE’s US cotton futures contract has registered record open interest of more than 200,000 contracts this year. ICE on Friday called the surviving contract the “global benchmark for cotton prices and risk management”.“When a mill in Bangladesh buys cotton, they consult the ICE price,” Trabue Bland, ICE Futures US president, said at an investor event last week in reference to the US contract.ICE said it would consult with traders about the possibility of relisting the world futures, but did not suggest that would happen. “Based on customer feedback we are reviewing the world cotton contract’s original terms, and how we might improve its usefulness to the global cotton trade,” the exchange operator said.

Titular: IntercontinentalExchange to buy BofA’s fixed income indices
Texto: IntercontinentalExchange on Thursday unveiled plans to scoop up Bank of America Merrill Lynch’s fixed income indices in a move that will give the owner of the New York Stock Exchange a deeper foothold in the rapidly-growing indexing business.The BofA global research platform encompasses more than 5,000 fixed income, currencies and commodities indices and represents the second-most used fixed-income gauges globally by assets under management, ICE said in a statement. After the deal, ICE’s combined fixed income index business will benchmark almost $1tn in assets.The platform will be re-branded as the ICE BofAML indices at the close of the deal.“As the demand for independent indices rises, we are pleased to monetise this valuable set of benchmarks with a strategic owner,” said Candace Browning, head of global research at BofA Merrill Lynch.ICE’s deal comes just a day after Citigroup said it will sell its global bond analytics business to the London Stock Exchange for $685m. The terms of the BofA-ICE deal were not disclosed.The rapid growth of the passive investment industry has been a major boon to the indexing business, since exchange-traded products generally track particular indexes.
