The proposed rule would impose new obligations on market participants. Automated traders would for the first time have to register with the commission if they trade directly on an exchange. CTC Trading Group, a Chicago-based proprietary trading firm, said most of the CFTC’s recommended risk controls had already been adopted by the industry and that exchanges, not the commission, should oversee traders. “It is the primary business of exchanges to stay abreast of state of the art technology, acquire a deep knowledge of the characteristics of market participants, and recognise and nimbly respond to new risks in the marketplace,” wrote Eric Chern, CTC chief executive. Likewise, the National Grain and Feed Association warned that grain merchants could wind up being required to register as automated traders, as some have invested in direct exchange access “simply to attempt to respond to the speed of today’s marketplace”. Exchanges and FIA raised questions about a CFTC provision which would require exchanges to have tools to prevent a firm from trading with itself. Such trading can be illegal if it is intentional. CME Group, the exchange group, said that the percentage of self-trades was less than 0.2 per cent of its total volume, while Intercontinental Exchange — which mandated self-trading blockers for proprietary traders since 2013 — said the proportion was even less. “These numbers clearly signify that the impermissible self-trading the proposal seeks to prevent is an inconsequential portion of the market,” CME said. The rule would also enable the CFTC to examine proprietary traders’ computer “source code” without a subpoena — a prospect that horrifies traders. Citadel, the Chicago hedge fund, compared code to a secret recipe. “Disclosure of a firm’s source code to other market participants would reveal not only the firm’s current investment portfolio, but also its expected future trading activity, exposing its most sensitive proprietary information and leaving it defenceless against the rest of the market,” it said in its letter. Chris Zuehlke of DRW Trading, a big Chicago trader, said source code was “how we make our money”. He warned an audience at the FIA meeting that Reg AT’s source code language as proposed “may not jibe with the fourth amendment”, the US constitutional protection against unreasonable searches and seizures. To overcome the issues, some are looking at examples from Europe, which has gone further than its US counterpart in crafting tighter rules for automated and high-speed trading.Many of the rules proposed by the CFTC are similar but there are nuanced differences. While both the US and EU also focus on testing and pre- and post-trade risk management, the US is unique in wanting traders to store their source code and make it available to regulators. Jaffray Woodriff, chief executive of Quantitative Investment Management, a commodity trading adviser with $2.2bn in assets under management, called for the US regulator to follow Europe’s approach in making a clear distinction between algorithms used for investment and those used in more automated trading. The former tend to be entered into trading systems by a human and present less systemic risk, he argued.

Titular: ICE shakes up scandal-hit Libor
Subtitular: Intercontinental Exchange seeks to restore confidence in benchmark rate
Texto: The new administrators of Libor are overhauling the way it is calculated, reducing its reliance on banker estimates in an attempt to restore faith in the scandal-hit rate.US markets operator Intercontinental Exchange took over administration of the London Interbank Offered Rate in 2014 after a global investigation found traders were influencing the daily rate calculations to benefit their own books.The 30-year-old rate has traditionally been calculated by averaging daily estimates of short-term interbank borrowing rates supplied by bank employees. But a 2012 regulatory review found the rate “not fit for purpose” and a series of banks paid more than $9bn in fines in the manipulation scandal.Now ICE is planning to root the daily rate in market transactions “to the greatest extent possible”. It will use a “waterfall” process that starts with transactions, but relies more on human estimates when the volume of trading falls.This shift to transactions is made possible by expanding the calculation beyond bank-to-bank lending. The new calculation will also include short-term funding that comes from central banks, corporations, non-bank financial institutions and other counterparties.“It’s which data are relevant, how it’s used — that’s prescribed by us and published to all users,” said Finbarr Hutcheson, president of the ICE Benchmark Administration. “That was a complete black hole before. Now it’s explicit to all users, what the banks do and how they do it,” he added.ICE said the decision to include non-bank lending reflects the fall in interbank lending. “The banks have consciously reduced their exposure to other banks and the regulators have been pushing very hard for banks to get longer term and more secure funding, from sources that are less likely to chop and change their behaviour from day to day,” said Mr Hutcheson.Over time, ICE hopes to develop a computer process that could calculate Libor without human estimates, even when transaction volumes are low.“The next generation would be ‘just give us the trades, we’ll work out the algorithm’,” said Mr HutchesonThe changes are the result of 18 months of consultation with regulators, central banks and market participants around the world. ICE says that it has received legal advice that the changes to Libor would not affect existing contracts and are “unlikely to give rise to issues of legal continuity”.ICE administers three UK-regulated benchmarks including London’s century-old gold fix, which it replaced with a new electronic system in late 2014.

Titular: Exchange merger set to raise temperatures in Florida
Subtitular: Fallout from deal will fuel consolidation considerations at global derivatives industry gathering
Texto: The redrawing of the global exchange landscape and its potential fallout is set to dominate the agenda as the global derivatives industry gathers in Florida this week.The announcement of London Stock Exchange Group’s merger with Deutsche Börse — the market’s biggest deal in many years— is likely to add further spice to its biggest annual gathering, the Futures Industry Association conference.The event has long had a history as a hotbed of dealmaking as senior exchange executives mingle with each other and their main users such as hedge funds, asset managers and high-frequency traders, as well as bankers and lawyers.After years spent fretting about industry profitability, customer protections and the impact of new markets and capital rules, executives have seen their world upended in recent weeks.News of the LSE-Deutsche Börse merger to create a European champion was followed by indications that US group Intercontinental Exchange could launch a rival bid; the German group also exited the US options market by agreeing to sell a subsidiary to Nasdaq for $1.1bn.On a smaller scale, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing and SGX, the Singapore exchange, are circling London-based Baltic Exchange, a critical utility in the global shipping market.“The question for us is whether we’re at a turning point in the industry,” said Carl Gilmore, president of Integritas Financial Consultancy and former co-head of Wedbush Securities. “There aren’t many big deals left to try. It feels like everyone is getting their ducks in a row before we see real competition in global trading.”Yet this year the biggest action is taking place 3,000 miles away with the LSE and Deutsche Börse formally unveiling their merger. Many London-based bankers have been restricted from travelling to the event to finalise the deal.“It is on everyone’s mind and it’s not just a European issue . . . it’s a global exchange issue,” said Richard Repetto, principal at Sandler O’Neill.The two groups have confirmed that London will be the location for the holding company and the German exchange’s Carsten Kengeter will take on the mantle of chief executive. However, customers and rivals are keen to see the impact on trading and whether any unwanted assets might become available.Besides ICE, CME Group has also been linked with a bid for one of the two European companies. Both managements will be there although few expect even the merest of details to emerge officially. Adviser chaperones are “shutting down any question even remotely connected to exchange consolidation”, said one banker.The conference, now in its 41st year, has played many supporting roles in the history of the market. In 2007 Intercontinental Exchange launched an unsolicited bid for the Chicago Board of Trade, which had already agreed to a merger with the CME, by slipping an offer under the hotel door of the-then CBOT chairman.Five years later the London Metal Exchange held discussions with a range of potential bidders in the bar in full view of other suitors, in an effort to draw out other offers. That finished with HKEx as the winner six months later, paying £1.38bn to beat ICE to the deal.

Titular: Nasdaq shares fall after deal to buy options business ISE
Subtitular: The $1.1bn acquisition is the exchange’s largest in nearly a decade
Texto: Investors greeted Nasdaq’s deal to buy International Securities Exchange, the US options business of Deutsche Börse, with some scepticism on Thursday, sending Nasdaq’s shares down as much as 3.5 per cent.The acquisition for $1.1bn in cash and debt is the largest for the US exchanges operator in nearly a decade and will extend its leading share in the highly competitive US options market.It comes as Deutsche Börse is closing in on a merger with the London Stock Exchange Group, although Atlanta-based Intercontinental Exchange has signalled that it may make a bid to try to break up the deal. Chicago’s CME Group has also been linked with bids for its two European rivals.The deal gives Nasdaq about 40 per cent of the market for US equities options where more than a dozen exchanges fight for business. ISE operates three equity options markets with a combined market share of 15 per cent. Nasdaq said bringing the two options businesses together will mean more competitive pricing in the industry.“The main concern here is that this is the options market and, at the end of the day, it has been very competitive,” said Ashley Serrao, market structure analyst at Credit Suisse. “Other competitors are on the horizon who may be entering the space and are we going to trigger a price war.”Rivals are competing over a shrinking pie. Options volume in 2015 totalled 4.14bn contracts, a 2.9 per cent decrease from 2014, even as volatility returned to the stock market, according to Tabb Group.Mr Serrao said these concerns were somewhat mitigated by the potential to exceed cost savings projected in the deal, which Nasdaq targets to be at least $40m on an annualised basis by the time the deal closes in 18 months.At midday in New York, Nasdaq shares were down about 1.5 per cent.The purchase is Nasdaq’s biggest acquisition since it bought Nordic stock market operator OMX for $3.7bn in 2007.Nasdaq said that it did not expect the deal to have a significant effect on its leverage, dividend or share buyback programmes, but some analysts were unconvinced.The deal will raise Nasdaq’s leverage to 3.1 times gross debt to earnings before interest taxes depreciation and amortisation, but the company has put a priority on reducing that to 2.3x to 2.7x.Nasdaq “has a strong history of deleveraging and we expect it to reach its target within a year of transaction closure, but until then we do not expect any meaningful shares repurchases”, said Peter Lenardos, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets, in a note.The exchanges operator suspended share buybacks in 2013 when its leverage rose after acquisitions, but resumed them the following year.As part of the deal Nasdaq will double its stake in The Options Clearing Corporation, the world’s largest equity derivatives clearing corporation, to 40 per cent. The deal excludes Deutsche Börse’s stake in Bats Global Markets, the exchanges operator, and Digital Asset Holdings, a US blockchain start-up.

Titular: D Börse sells ISE options unit to Nasdaq
Subtitular: Deal comes as German group closes in on merger with London Stock Exchange
Texto: Deutsche Börse has agreed to sell the International Securities Exchange, its US options business, to rival Nasdaq for $1.1bn, as global exchanges swap assets in an industry shake-up.The deal will extend Nasdaq’s leading share of the highly competitive US options market, in which more than a dozen exchanges fight for business. ISE operates three equity options markets with a combined market share of 15 per cent.The move comes as Deutsche Börse is closing in on a merger with the London Stock Exchange Group, although Atlanta-based Intercontinental Exchange has signalled that it may make a bid to try to break up the deal. Chicago’s CME Group has also been linked with bids for its two European rivals.The ISE sale will mean a loss for Deutsche Börse which paid $2.8bn in 2008. However, the German group has already taken impairment charges of more than €800m on its investments after a downturn in trading after the financial crisis.“We are pursuing the goal to become the number one or two player in every business in which we operate. This goal requires an active management of our business portfolio,” said Carsten Kengeter, chief executive of Deutsche Börse. “In areas where we are not able to meet this goal, we are evaluating other options.”Deutsche Börse said it expected to register a gain of hundreds of millions of euros with the deal.The transaction will give Nasdaq a market share of around 40 per cent in a battle with Bats Global Markets and the CBOE.“We are number one with respect to market share [in US equity options],” said Bob Greifeld, Nasdaq chief executive. “For us to extend that lead, that …is a great opportunity.”We are pursuing the goal to become the number one or two player in every business in which we operate …In areas where we are not able to meet this goal, we are evaluating other optionsMr Greifeld said Nasdaq had had its eye on the ISE for several years but that it became “actionable” in the past few months. The sale was not conditional on the LSE-Deutsche Börse deal going through, he said.Nasdaq will pay with a mix of debt and cash, but does not expect the deal to have a significant effect on its leverage, dividend or share buyback programmes.The deal will yield at least $40m of annualised cost savings within 18 months of closing in the second half of the year.The acquisition is Nasdaq’s largest in nearly a decade. It bought Nordic stock market operator OMX for $3.7bn in 2007.As part of the deal Nasdaq will double its stake in The Options Clearing Corporation, the world’s largest equity derivatives clearing corporation, to 40 per cent. The deal excludes Deutsche Börse’s stake in Bats Global Markets, the exchanges operator, and Digital Asset Holdings, a US blockchain start-up.Perella Weinberg advised Deutsche Borse on the deal.

Titular: Nasdaq to buy options operator ISE for $1.1bn
Texto: Nasdaq OMX Group on Wednesday revealed plans to buy an options exchange operator from Deutsche Börse for $1.1bn as its ramps up its exposure to the derivatives market.The purchase of the International Securities Exchange gives New York-based Nasdaq control over three electronic options exchanges that account for 15 per cent of US options trading, the exchange operator said.“The equities options business has been core to our long-term strategy, and we believe an essential component to the strength of the Nasdaq franchise,” said Bob Greifeld, Nasdaq’s chief executive.Exchange operators, including Nasdaq rival IntercontinentalExchange, have benefited from the trading of derivatives, which is more lucrative than equities trading.The move also comes as Germany-based Deutsche Börse looks to merge with the London Stock Exchange in a deal that could face tough antitrust challenges.

Titular: Brokers must prepare for unparalleled conditions
Subtitular: Top advisers face grim task of navigating crisis for clients
Texto: The coronavirus pandemic is first and foremost a human tragedy whose scale is yet to be fully comprehended.The resulting economic shock of recent weeks has also created unprecedented disruptions which have left many people confronted with pressing questions about job security, threats to household income, tax liabilities, and the survival of their businesses. Financial advisers now face the task of dealing with many clients who, beyond all this, will probably have suffered sharp falls in the value of their assets.Louise Gunderson, an FT 400 adviser with UBS Financial Services in New York, has vivid memories of the last financial crisis. When the US stock market began dropping in February, the first thing she did was check that her clients had enough cash. “After 2008, I make sure people have at least a year of cash flow available,” Ms Gunderson says.Like many other advisers, Ms Gunderson and her team of seven have spent most of their time in recent weeks reassuring investors about their long-term plans and talking through clients’ personal worries.Against the distressing backdrop of crisis, the eighth annual edition of the Financial Times 400 Top Financial Advisers provides a snapshot of the best professionals at traditional US broker-dealers.The scale of assets under management is important in selecting the FT 400, as is a positive record in growing this figure, which is a measure of client retention and investment performance. But the list also recognises that advisers’ jobs extend to acting as consultants, life coaches and even amateur psychologists.More advisers have advanced industry designations such as those for financial planners, retirement specialists or financial analysts. Some 72 per cent of the FT 400 advisers have at least one such credential, up from 69 per cent last year.Managing client relationships will be more important than ever this year, in the wake of a crisis many commentators say is without modern precedent. Advisers had already been emphasising services besides investing such as longer-term financial planning and tax management.In recent years, a growing number of advisers have also given up assembling their own mix of investments for clients in favour of selecting from an array of model portfolios. These are computer-aided blends of stocks, bonds and funds that are actively managed to the investor’s risk tolerance and financial goals. Some 20 per cent of advisers say they have increased their use of model portfolios over the past year, while only 10 per cent have decreased such use.Managing client relationships will be more important than ever in the wake of this crisisSelecting investments is not financial advisers’ biggest worry, according to our survey conducted in November and December of 2019. Instead, the top challenge cited by 70 per cent of FT 400 advisers is managing their day-to-day operational requirements. That is a change from the prior year when the FT 400 picked meeting client demands as their biggest burden.Operational challenges are only intensifying in response to coronavirus, as nearly all meetings with clients have shifted to phone calls or video-chat services such as Zoom and Skype. Advisers may long for an eventual return to consultations in person, but some say they might continue to use video or screen-sharing technology more often when things return to normal.Any return to normal cannot be predicted. Brokers who offer investment advice are also planning for the new Securities and Exchange Commission “Regulation Best Interest,” that could be the biggest rule change to their business in many years. The new regulation will limit brokers to recommendations that serve their clients’ best interests, and includes new standards for disclosing brokers’ potential conflicts of interest. The rule is scheduled to take effect on June 30. The SEC has indicated it intends to stick to this deadline despite the pandemic and its consequences.As usual, the larger states with higher concentrations of wealth have more FT 400 advisers. New York has the largest number of advisers on the list with 77, followed by California with 67. Florida is in third place with 21, followed by Illinois with 20.Many first-rate advisers missed the list. Competition is tight, so the gap between those who made and missed the cut can be narrow. The advisers in this year’s listing benefited from strong financial markets last year; the average adviser managed $2bn in assets as of June 30, up from the $1.8bn average in the previous year’s list. This year’s markets in June are highly unlikely to provide such a boost.How is coronavirus taking its toll on markets, business, and our everyday lives and workplaces? Stay briefed with our coronavirus newsletter.Sign up hereListed advisers come from 23 broker-dealers, and the best-represented companies are Merrill Lynch (with 18 per cent of advisers) and Morgan Stanley (16 per cent). Wall Street’s dominance is not guaranteed to last for ever, though. Such national brokerages with the broadest array of services, known as the wirehouses, have focused on retaining successful brokers over the recruitment of a high volume of additional advisers.And many successful brokers have been leaving wirehouses to run their own businesses. The four wirehouses, which also include UBS and Wells Fargo, have the smallest concentration of advisers on the list in its eight-year history: 48 per cent of the FT 400, down from 53 per cent the previous year.It is still unclear how the pandemic and its attendant disruptions will affect the long-term changes under way in the financial advice industry. Fortunately for their clients, the top advisers are used to turbulence.

Titular: Investors push bullish oil bets to new record
Texto: Hedge funds and money managers increased their bets on a higher oil price to a new record.Weekly futures and options data from InterContinental Exchange published on Monday showed they increased their net long positions in Brent crude by 22,171 lots to 342,460 for the week to March 1. This is the highest since records began in 2011, reports Anjli Raval, oil and gas correspondent.Prices have rebounded since hitting 2003 lows of below $30 a barrel in January. On Monday, prices rose 59 cents to $39.31 a barrel by 1pm London time.“More and more speculative financial investors are jumping on the bandwagon, thereby reinforcing the upward trend,” said analysts at Commerzbank.Oil market sentiment has improved on the back of chatter about a meeting of Opec and non-Opec prouducer countries in the next several weeks. Saudi Arabia, Russia, Qatar and Venezuela agreed last month to freeze their output at January levels providing other producers joined them, in an effort to tackle the global oversupply.Additionally, US crude production dropped for a sixth consecutive week in the week ending in February 26, to just over 9m b/d, the lowest level since November 2014, according to US government data. The number of rigs drilling for oil in the US has continued to decline.“US shale producers continue to pull rigs from the ground in an effort to conserve capital,” said analysts at ANZ.Speculators unwound bearish bets in US crude West Texas Intermediate as anxiety about the prospect of $20 a barrel oil eased.Hedge funds reduced their short positions in the week ended March 1 by 25,639 contracts of futures and options to 150,718, according to US Commodity Futures Trading Commission data. This was the fastest pace since April.

Titular: LSE reiterates case for Deutsche Börse tie-up
Texto: The London Stock Exchange is putting on a handsome display while it is circled by potential suitors, with its results for the whole of 2015 boasting a hefty rise in revenues and profits.LSE chief Xavier Rolet says today that a proposed merger with German counterpart Deutsche Börse, which has been a live possibility since the end of last month, represents a “compelling opportunity to strengthen each other.” There was no mention of the potential rival bid from Intercontinental Exchange.It said:The combination of LSE and Deutsche Börse’s complementary growth strategies, products, services and geographic footprint would be expected to deliver an enhanced ability to provide a full service offering to customers on a global basis. LSEG and Deutsche Börse believe that the potential merger would offer the prospect of enhanced growth, significant customer benefits… as well as substantial revenue and cost synergies and increased shareholder value.All key businesses of LSEG and Deutsche Börse would continue to operate under their current brand names. The existing regulatory framework of all regulated entities within the Combined Group would remain unchanged, subject to customary and final regulatory approvals.While talks with Deutsche Börse rumble on, the LSE says “one thing is certain – we remain committed to delivering enhanced service and products for our customers and value for our shareholders.”On that note, it today reported a 78 per cent rise in total revenues, to £2.28bn, with information and technology services leading the pace of growth while revenues from post-trade services dipped somewhat. Adjusted pre-tax profits rose by 31 per cent to £643.4m.

Titular: ICE move for LSE could include spin-off of Borsa Italiana
Subtitular: US exchange’s potential bid may involve the divestitures of Italian and French businesses
Texto: A potential bid by Intercontinental Exchange for the London Stock Exchange Group could include spinning off the UK company’s Italian business and French clearing arm, say two people familiar with the matter.The Atlanta-based group is exploring divestitures of two eurozone-based assets as it considers launching an offer to rival an all-share merger that the LSE is working on with Deutsche Börse, the German group.The US company this week confirmed it was considering an offer for the LSE but had neither decided nor approached the UK group. A move would dramatically solidify its position running a powerhouse for derivatives trading in London, one of the world's biggest hubs for off-exchange markets. ICE already owns futures trading, clearing and data businesses in the City.If it bids, ICE may expand on plans being considered by the LSE and Deutsche Börse to spin off the French arm of clearing house LCH.Clearnet, say people familiar with the discussions. ICE may also dispose of Borsa Italiana, which the LSE bought for €1.6bn in 2007. The latter comprises equities, derivatives trading and post-trade businesses.The LSE is already considering spinning off Paris-based Clearnet SA, said those familiar with the talks. ICE declined to comment.A spin-off would echo ICE’s treatment of Euronext, the owner of the Paris, Amsterdam, Brussels and Lisbon exchanges. ICE bought it as part of its $11.2bn deal for NYSE Euronext in 2012 but included plans to float Euronext. The value of the shares, listed in Paris, has doubled during its 21 months as an independent company.A move by ICE for the LSE would focus on capturing LCH.Clearnet, the largest clearer of interest rate derivatives, say people familiar with the talks. The group would, like Deutsche Börse, look to offer banks and investors billions of dollars of savings, reducing margin costs of trading by netting them under one organisation.Selling Borsa Italiana as well as Clearnet SA would also help ICE finance a move for the LSE.Rich Repetto, principal at Sandler O’Neill and Partner in New York, said: “Based on various assumptions, including the Deutsche Börse deal price, we think ICE can generally do a deal for the LSE at a slight premium to where it’s currently trading, but much above that would require divestitures or other creative financing.”Some users have been concerned that change of ownership at LCH may reduce competition for derivatives clearing in the market. Michael Spencer, chief executive of ICAP, the interdealer broker, said: “We need clarification on whether ICE would maintain LCH as an open-access clearing platform.”The disposal of eurozone-based assets is likely to interest Euronext, which is working on a strategic plan under Stephane Boujnah, the new chief executive, to increase revenues. Clearnet SA is its main clearing house. It also has more cash than debt.Putting Clearnet SA under the control of a Eurozone-based business would be an attempt to allay concerns about regulation if the UK votes to leave the EU this year. It would keep the euro-dominated business under the supervision of the European Central Bank.www.ft.com/tradingroom

Titular: ICE interest pours cold water on LSE-DB love-in
Subtitular: US group could trigger counterbid with cold, hard cash attached
Texto: Special relationship or ever closer union? The choice between a transatlantic or European partnership recurs in British politics and could be posed in financial form as Intercontinental Exchange of the US considers a bid for the London Stock Exchange. That would likely kill off a nil-premium merger between LSE and Deutsche Börse.LSE investors should be grateful for the intervention of ICE, owner of the venerable New York Stock Exchange. The merger looks like a takeover on the cheap to some of them. Popular LSE chief executive Xavier Rolet was to stand down, leaving DB’s relatively untried Carsten Kengeter to run the combined group and investors in DB with 54 per cent of the shares.Now there is the prospect of a takeover battle, spiced up by the complexity of the UK’s forthcoming Brexit referendum. The poll has been interpreted as shark deterrent and helpful to the proposed LSE-DB merger. ICE founder and chief executive Jeff Sprecher appears inclined to call that bluff.ICE will have to work out whether it is willing to shoulder the risk of bidding for LSE when the value of the company might be reduced by hostile European financial regulation in the wake of Brexit. If euro-denominated securities clearing was restricted to the eurozone, it could, however, route the business through its Holland Clearing House. Antitrust objections would probably be on a par with those facing DB-LSE.ICE, which has an effective tax rate of about 21 per cent, according to S&P CIQ, might also contemplate a tax inversion. This would help the group finance a decent cash component in its offer for LSE. ICE’s net debt is on the steep side at three times historic earnings before nasties, though expected to drop with the integration of previous acquisitions.DB and LSE have doubtless been working up a synergies number that is both credible and big enough to persuade sceptical investors of the benefits of a merger. This may now prove to be of little use except in supporting a share component in a counterbid from DB that also includes cold, hard cash.It appears that Google’s driverless cars are like flesh-and-blood drivers: deeply fallible yet convinced that their skills surpass those of other road users.Last week, one of the vehicles pulled out into the path of a bus in California in the belief that the bus driver would slow down. When do they ever? Buses are big and heavy. This gives them a right of way over all other road users, apart from black Range Rover Discoveries doing the school run in Battersea.The driverless car crash has been attributed to deficient “road etiquette programming”, which is a good example of how fancy terminology can make a stupid decision sound less stupid. Google says that the car confronted a “tricky set of circumstances”. That could happen to anyone. Lombard once reversed into a bollard while attempting to placate an infant by putting on a Wind in the Willows CD.The autonomous vehicles have had several prior crashes, but Google says they were never at fault, which is uncanny. Because all bangs, scrapes and collisions suffered by Lombard have been the fault of other drivers, too.Driverless technology may be achieving human levels of self-belief. Where it will struggle is in simulating theory of mind. This is the ability to intuit thoughts and feelings to others. We expect a young man in a pimped hatch back to drive differently to a granny in a Fiesta. Blue neon underlighting and a filling-rattling sound system are danger signals that it still takes a human driver to pick up.Michael Dobson, who is to step down, has become a City landmark in his 14 years as chief executive at Schroders. As determinedly old-fashioned as anything Lutyens built, he has towered over flashier fund managers. His career has been buttressed by traditional virtues of discretion and client service and a close relationship with the Schröder family, which controls 48 per cent of the company.Mr Dobson’s disinclination to leave earlier resulted in heir apparent Peter Harrison acquiring the nickname “the Prince of Wales”. Dobbo is at least as posh as the Queen, if not quite as elevated as the better class of French maitre d’hotel.On his watch, Schroders shares have produced a total return of about 450 per cent, and assets have risen to almost £300bn. The bulk of this has been achieved without acquisitions, of which Mr Dobson disapproves. He made an exception for Cazenove Capital in 2013. Something to do with that blue-blooded name, maybe?Mr Dobson has a reputation for prickliness. His enjoyment of a joke is a closely guarded secret. Colleagues who fancy tweaking the old lion’s tail as he goes should stage a huge leaving party. If there’s one thing he hates, it’s a fuss.jonathan.guthrie@ft.com

Titular: ICE eyes bid for London Stock Exchange to rival Deutsche Börse deal
Subtitular: US exchange offer would scupper planned ‘merger of equals’ with German operator
Texto: European ambitions to establish a dominant exchange to rival the US were thrown into doubt after Intercontinental Exchange said it was considering bidding for the London Stock Exchange, just days after Deutsche Börse revealed friendly merger plans with the UK bourse. ICE, which owns the New York Stock Exchange, said on Tuesday it was looking at a proposal, but had not yet approached the board of the LSE and that “there can be no certainty that any offer will be made”.The LSE is already in advanced talks with Deutsche Börse over a £20bn deal, which would create a globally competitive European champion in derivatives, clearing and financial market data.News of ICE’s interest also fuelled speculation that other leading exchange operators, including Chicago’s CME Group and Hong Kong’s HKeX, could also enter the fray and spark a transatlantic bidding war.“We are in the endgame for the LSE. The question now is how we manage the process,” said one top 10 shareholder in the London bourse.Shares in the LSE soared 7.8 per cent, adding to a recent surge in its stock price and marking the first time the company has been valued at almost £10bn.ICE’s entry could ignite a political storm over who should own the LSE and regulate its activities. A deal with the German bourse would increase London’s prominence as a financial capital, creating a UK-based holding company with dual headquarters in the UK capital and Frankfurt.The LSE said in a statement it had not received a proposal from ICE and that discussions between it and Deutsche Börse were progressing.A takeover by Atlanta-based ICE would hand LSE’s desirable clearing house to the Americans, which bought Liffe, the derivatives exchange, in 2013. The potential deal would also unite two of the world’s most high-profile venues for stock market listings.ICE, which was established in 2000 to challenge the now-defunct energy trader Enron has grown at an astonishing pace under chief executive Jeff Sprecher. The company is now worth $27.8bn after a series of deals, most recently paying $5.2bn for Interactive Data Corp.Shares in ICE were down 4.1 per cent just after midday in New York.Deutsche Börse deliberately launched its bid for the LSE amid the political uncertainty surrounding Britain’s “Brexit” vote to steal a march on US rivals.Under rules guiding UK takeovers, Deutsche Börse has until March 22 to table a firm offer for the LSE or walkaway and ICE has until March 29.“Never to be left out, ICE has taken a half-step forward for the LSE, though there is not much downside to letting the public know of their interest,” said Rich Repetto at Sandler O’Neill.Owen Jones, an analyst at Citigroup, added Deutsche Börse would not want to find itself in a bidding war.“Its balance sheet is stretched already . . . and a revision to its offer would see either a higher proportion of the combined entity go to LSE shareholders, or it would involve an equity raise, we think.”Listen to the podcast2000 — Intercontinental Exchange founded in Atlanta by a group of seven banks and energy companies as an online electronic market to trade over-the-counter energy, metals and other commodities contracts2001 — ICE buys London-based International Petroleum Exchange2005 — Floats on the New York Stock Exchange2007 — Acquires New York Board of Trade, a physical commodities exchange trading futures and options on sugar, cotton, coffee, cocoa and orange juice, in addition to interest rates, currencies. It is renamed ICE Futures US2010 — Acquires the Chicago Climate Exchange, North America’s largest and longest running greenhouse gas emissions trading exchange2012 — Announces $8.2bn deal to acquire NYSE Euronext2013 — As part of the NYSE deal, Liffe, the London derivatives exchange, transfers contracts to ICE trading platform2016 — ICE confirms it is considering a bid for the London Stock Exchange

Titular: ICE may have to make hefty offer in potential bid for LSE
Subtitular: LSE purchase would make the US group London’s dominant market infrastructure
Texto: If as expected Intercontinental Exchange launches a bid for the London Stock Exchange Group, it would mark a return to the city that is one of the pillars of the US company’s $30bn empire.Executives and analysts alike say the LSE is officially “in play” after it revealed last week it was in talks about an all-share “merger of equals” with Deutsche Börse. On Tuesday ICE indicated it too may make a bid. “The LSE is a pretty hot target and is a massive foothold in European financial markets. Now the LSE is in play you can’t afford not to be a bidder,” said Niki Beattie, head of Market Structure Partners, a consultancy.From the outset the 16-year old ICE has looked to the UK capital to help give its business scale, purchasing assets such as the International Petroleum Exchange and Liffe, whose names have disappeared under the ICE brand.However, Atlanta-based ICE faces political and regulatory hurdles and may have to make a hefty offer if it is to walk off with London’s biggest exchange asset.Analysts said that the rationale for a bid is much the same as the one that drives the Deutsche Börse deal. Global regulations have forced banks to place billions of dollars of collateral and margin as insurance to back their derivatives trades. As a result, billions of dollars of capital are being held at clearing houses such as Deutsche Börse’s Eurex, ICE Futures Europe and LCH. Clearnet. Bringing the clearing houses under one roof would allow customers to net their margin for swaps and futures.Ms Beattie, a former bank head of electronic trading, thinks a deal for the LSE will happen after years of unconsummated bids. “I think that’s why the banks won’t lobby against it this time — the cost savings [from netting margins] will be too great for banks exhausted by regulatory issues.”Adding the LSE would make ICE London’s dominant market infrastructure. Besides Liffe and the IPE, it has also bought emissions trading platform Climate Exchange, energy trading platform Trayport and also opened the first new clearing house in London in more than 100 years, in 2008.Jeff Sprecher, ICE chief executive, has been a vocal critic of several of Europe’s planned markets regulations, but his interest in the LSE indicates the continent is still his target.However, the LSE and Deutsche Börse have an agreement and have been working for several weeks on getting political and regulatory support from London, Berlin and Brussels. They want to use their deal as a bridge to Europe and help kick-start regional economic growth and lessen the reliance on banks for corporate fundraisings. “The company is continuing its merger talks with LSE with no change,” Deutsche Börse said in a statement.Moody’s, the credit rating agency, said an LSE-Deutsche Börse tie-up would be positive for bondholders and a credible rival to CME and ICE, “albeit at lower relative margins”.But ICE’s approach came as investors began to anticipate a competing bid, either from ICE or Chicago’s CME Group, the ICE rival that is closely watching developments.LSE shares “had begun to trade above the implied level of the [Deutsche Börse] agreement, after adjusting for dividends,” noted Owen Jones, an analyst at Citigroup.CME is also rumoured to be looking at an approach but declined to comment. People close to the LSE said a US approach would likely be a different type of bid, “with a proper change-of-control premium”.“If we assume 50 per cent of the LSE’s expenses could be eliminated and each transaction was structured as an all-stock deal, we calculate ICE could pay up to £34 while CME could pay up to £44 [for LSE],” said Christopher Harris, an analyst at Wells Fargo.A bidding war would be bad news for Deutsche Börse, Mr Jones said. “Its balance sheet is stretched already, judged on a gross debt to earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation basis . . . and a revision to its offer would see either a higher proportion of the combined entity go to LSE shareholders, or it would involve an equity raise, we think.”Inevitably, the size and diversity of the LSE’s business — from indices, data, clearing and trading, creates potential issues for all bidders. Nevertheless European exchange executives are hoping it could mean parts of the LSE are spun off to ease the deal, such as Clearnet, the French clearing house and Millennium IT, the LSE’s technology business. Euronext, which ICE spun off two years, ago is understood to be interested in purchasing Clearnet.Shareholders, who may be asked to decide between two different bids, may take their lead from Xavier Rolet, the LSE chief executive, who could lose out come what may.“The fact that Xavier wanted to go put a whole different complexion on the [DB] bid. That was very disconcerting for us — disappointing and surprising,” said one top 10 shareholder. “He is the one that knows the market.”Equally, shareholders may see a US bid as more disruptive. “Perhaps that indicates that the proposed merger of equals with two open access derivatives groups, one in London, one in Paris, could be quite compelling,” said Jake Pugh, an independent consultant.Additional reporting by Kate Burgesswww.ft.com/tradingroom

Titular: London Stock Exchange: the ICE men cometh
Subtitular: A rival bid for the UK stock market would be a straight takeover
Texto: It is always nice to be courted. And the London Stock Exchange often is — no fewer than four different suitors have asked for its hand in marriage in the past 15 years, some more than once. This time is no different.Last week, the LSE and Deutsche Börse confirmed they were in talks. On Tuesday, Intercontinental Exchange said it was considering a bid for LSE. No further detail was provided.A deal involving the LSE and ICE would offer similar attractions as one with Deutsche Börse. It would combine two big clearing houses, which should mean cost savings for both owners and the users. LSE shareholders would gain exposure to Liffe, the derivatives business that they have long coveted, rather than Eurex. And it would bring together two major stock markets. LSE’s index business would also dovetail neatly with Interactive Data, which ICE acquired last year.If the industrial logic of the two deals is broadly similar, then success will come down to price and structure. There could be no pretence that an ICE/LSE combination is a merger of equals; the US company’s market value is double that of its UK target and its earnings (before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation) are almost three times higher. An ICE bid would be a takeover.Take the company’s 2013 acquisition of NYSE Euronext as a blueprint. The same 37 per cent premium to the undisturbed price would equate to £31.70 a share for the LSE, against Tuesday’s price of £28.60. If ICE structured a bid along the same lines — one-third cash and two-thirds shares — and consolidated the LSE’s borrowings within its own, then its end-December net debt of $6.6bn could easily double (taking it to almost six times ebitda). Its shares trade at a lower multiple of profits than the LSE’s, so a deal may initially dilute earnings.That is not necessarily a reason to demur. ICE has been adept at bringing debt down after previous deals; this strong record means investors may well support a cash call. It is less certain that Deutsche Börse, with a relatively new chief, could do likewise. More radically, it could divest London’s cash equities business, as it did with Euronext, or structure the deal as a tax inversion in order to reduce its tax bill.None of which means ICE holds all the aces. Deutsche Börse could sweeten its own offer. CME Group or Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing could enter the fray. Get set for an intense courtship.Email the Lex team at lex@ft.com

Titular: Jeff Sprecher: exchange dealmaker
Subtitular: Possible bid for LSE by ICE founder and chief shows why he is one of sector’s biggest risk-takers
Texto: Jeff Sprecher has rarely seen a deal he does not like — as long as it has the potential to disrupt.By considering making a bid for the London Stock Exchange Group, the founder and chief executive of the Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) has once again demonstrated why he is one of the biggest risk-takers in the world of exchanges.Few could have imagined that an Atlanta-based businessman who started his career in electricity generation in California in the 1980s would end up as the owner of the venerable New York Stock Exchange.Exchanges — long seen as stuffy, slow-moving businesses — were run until not so long ago by their members, not by profit-driven dealmakers. ICE was founded as an obscure online gas and power trading platform in 2000.But in late 2012 Mr Sprecher pounced on NYSE Euronext, the then owner of the Wall Street icon. His aim? To get hold of the lucrative, London-based derivatives trading platform known as Liffe, then owned by the US-based group.That deal followed an even bolder — ultimately unsuccessful — move to break up an attempted combination of NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Börse. While that saw Mr Sprecher team up with Bob Greifeld, chief executive of Nasdaq, the ICE chief has never embraced the clubby world of exchange leaders. He is nobody’s friend across a boardroom table.“We spend every day fighting with CME Group, [ICE’s main US rival], working out how to bash them over the head . . . if Nasdaq want to join the market, we’ll see them outside,” Mr Sprecher once said.Five years earlier, Mr Sprecher launched an audacious bid for the Chicago Board of Trade — which was in talks with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange — by slipping an envelope with his offer under the hotel room door of the CBOT’s then chairman while the two were attending an industry event in Florida.While Mr Sprecher’s strategy has seemed opportunistic — even pugilistic — it has always been driven by a keen understanding of market structures. His chess moves have been a powerful driver of change in the derivatives and clearing business, and he has negotiated the shifting sands of post-crisis global regulation nimbly, often outwitting the CME with its roots in Chicago’s storied futures trading markets.That has allowed Mr Sprecher to amass 11 exchanges and seven clearing houses in a portfolio that makes ICE the dominant global operator in key financial products that influence everything from the crude oil price and the price of jet fuel used in aircraft, to credit default swaps and the price of soft commodities such as coffee and cotton.Yet while Mr Sprecher has been one of the most opportunistic and active consolidators in the exchange industry, the 61-year old native of Wisconsin has always been the ultimate industry outsider.He rose to prominence not from an exchange, nor at one of the investment banks from which exchanges typically recruit their chief executives these days.Instead, Mr Sprecher ran a power generation business for 17 years before persuading a group of Wall Street banks to fund an online power trading platform designed to compete with the now-defunct Enron.He and his wife live in Atlanta, preferring charity work and a quiet social life in the city to the glitzy potential of New York and London. The pair can often be found meeting friends at a favoured steak restaurant in the city’s Buckhead district. Watches and fast cars are among his passions.Nor does Mr Sprecher indulge in other common routines of the C-suite — such as regular exercise. “My work is my gym,” he once said.Whether Mr Sprecher proceeds with a bid for the LSE — and succeeds in breaking up the planned deal with its German partner — may be unclear. But judging from his record, the temptation to press the “disrupt” button may just be too great.

Titular: Boom time for exchange options trading
Subtitular: Human factor being reduced as the market embraces an electronic approach
Texto: Investors and traders are increasingly buying and selling options on futures contracts for managing their portfolios, rather than spending precious cash reserves, spurring a boom in activity for the sector.Along with other areas of finance, technological change and deep-seated structural reform is sweeping through the listed options market.For many investors, the use of options represents a cheaper and more flexible method of altering their portfolio exposure to various asset classes, without moving the market price against themselves.Option contracts provide investors with the ability to pay an insurance-like premium that can protect their portfolios against changes in asset prices within a defined period.Sellers of options receive the premium and are required to pay out should the underlying market price move in favour of the buyer.“For the most part, regulatory reserve requirements for options on futures contracts are lower than for regular futures contracts,” says Andy Nybo, partner and global head of research at Tabb Group, a capital markets consultancy.“For example, asset managers seeking to effect rebalancing programs will have greater costs when purchasing a basket of underlying equities or bonds in terms of fees and market slippage.”The use of options has long followed activity in futures contracts — however, that relationship has been subverted in the last year.Electronic options volumes on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, including trading in the vast eurodollar interest rate options market, has climbed 15 per cent to more than 1.4m contracts a day.In January alone, the numbers soared 37 per cent year on year to an average 4.3m contracts per day, marking an acceleration of a trend across other exchanges in recent years.“That mix — always goes up and down, but this is something that I have never seen in my 36-year history to see the options growth outpace the futures growth,” said Terry Duffy, executive chairman of CME Group on a recent analyst call.Options on futures contracts in all instruments — interest rates, energy and equities — have seen a compound annual growth rate of 12.8 per cent since 2009, according to Tabb Group.Options markets have long been a haven for the human trader, as the instruments entail a greater complexity than other markets — like Black-Scholes modelling — and are often only part of a trade that can include many components.But inexpensive computer software that is able to crunch vast quantities of data has reduced the human factor.As the market embraces an electronic approach, traders across the world can transact outside of regular US business hours.Indeed, electronic trading on CME and Intercontinental Exchange accounted for 56 per cent of total trading in the first nine months of last year, up from just 18 per cent in 2009.In turn, greater activity also begets more options trades, bolstering growth within the sector.“Synthetic long futures requires two option positions [long call and short put] in order to establish the same exposure. More complex option structures would just enhance the pattern,” says one options trader in Chicago.The effect of the Basel capital rules on banks’ balance sheets is beginning to have an effect on the market. Increased electronic market activity is encouraging new market makers to sidestep banks and quote to wholesale counterparties.Start-ups like Akuna Capital, XTX Markets and Dash Financial are beginning to move in alongside bigger and more established options trading firms like Spot Trading and Wolverine Trading.But whether that means that the market is replacing the role historically taken on by banks’ market-making desks is another question.Thomson Reuters says there are equally radical changes on bank-dominated foreign exchange markets. Trades on its options platform between banks and their customers soared 166 per cent last year to record volumes. The number of market makers on its dealer-to-client venue rose 38 per cent last year to 36.It attributes the growth to scandals over the FX market and Libor lending rates, together with tougher requirements that force both banks and fund managers to show they got the best price for their trade.“Over the past two years, banks have reached the point where they can make an electronic price,” says Phil Weisberg, global head of FX, rates and credit at Thomson Reuters. “Customers are at the point where many need to compare prices from more than one source.”He argues that the rising numbers are not representative of overall OTC market volumes, but that “there are more exchange things happening, it’s more automated”.While liquidity and pricing may change, off-exchange markets may remain different. “People using exchanges are alternative market makers,” says Mr Weisberg. “Trading listed versus OTC is very different. Corporate hedgers would prefer an OTC transaction.”

Titular: FTSE 100 hits two-month high
Texto: London’s FTSE 100 has hit a new two-month high in early trading today, boosted by gains in commodities stocks and the emergence of a rival bid for the London Stock Exchange’s merger.The mining heavy index climbed as much as 0.8 per cent to 6148.74 in early morning, helped by commodity stocks. With oil prices showing signs of stabilisation, shares in Anglo American and BHP Billiton moved up 4.2 per cent and 2.4 per cent respectively.But the leader of the pack is the LSE itself, now up by 7.5 per cent, after the Intercontinental Exchange confirmed it is pondering whether to submit a bid for the UK group to rival Deutsche Börse’s.At the other end of the spectrum is Barclays, down by 11 per cent after the UK bank cut its dividend by more than half in 2016 and 2017 to boost its capital buffer, and Ashtead, down by 14 per cent.

Titular: LSE shares jump 8.8% to record high on possible ICE bid
Texto: Shares in the London Stock Exchange have leapt as much as 8.8 per cent this morning to a record high of £29.14 after the Intercontinental Exchange confirmed it is pondering whether to submit a bid for the UK group to rival Deutsche Börse’s.LSE shares have surged more than 26 per cent since news of Deutsche Börse’s proposed tie-up first emerged last week.

Titular: ICE confirms potential rival bid for LSE
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange confirmed on Tuesday it is considering making a bid for smaller rival London Stock Exchange Group and breaking up the UK group’s planned merger with Deutsche Börse.The US group said it was considering making a bid but “no approach has been made to the board of London Stock Exchange Group, and no decision has yet been made as to whether to pursue such an offer”, writes Philip Stafford.It added that:There can be no certainty that any offer will be madeThe story was first reported by Bloomberg. The news comes amid growing speculation that either ICE or its big US rival CME Group was considering a rival offer to that of Deutsche Börse, which is set to be in the form of an “all-share merger of equals”.“Neither comes as a huge surprise,” said Owen Jones, an analyst at Citigroup. “The LSE is an asset that has received rival bids before and, despite the Brexit risk, it is a sought after asset.”However Mr Jones said that Deutsche Börse would not want to find itself in a bidding war:Its balance sheet is stretched already…and a revision to its offer would see either a higher proportion of the combined entity go to LSE shareholders, or it would involve an equity raise, we think.A move by ICE for the LSE would also see the US group again return to London for a high-profile deal.ICE chief executive Jeff Sprecher has frequently purchased the city’s financial market infrastructure as he has built ICE over the last 17 years, including the International Petroleum Exchange in 2001, Liffe, the London derivatives exchange in 2013, and Trayport, the energy trading platform last year.Purchasing the LSE, would, like for Deutsche Börse, allow ICE to offer investors billions of dollars of savings on their derivatives trades.Global regulations have forced more deals to be backed by collateral and margin as insurance.As a result, billions of dollars of capital are being held at clearing houses such as Deutsche Börse’s Eurex, ICE Futures Europe and LCH.Clearnet. However, bringing them under one roof would allow customers to net their margin for swaps and futures.ICE is currently integrating its $5.2bn purchase of Interactive Data Corp, which it bought at the end of December. However it may receive a windfall in coming months from its 12.5 per cent stake in Cetip, a Brazilian fixed income clearing house. Brazil’s BM&F Bovespa may return with a bid for Cetip in coming days. ICE paid $512m for the holding, although took a $190m impairment charge two years ago.Shares in LSE are up 7.8 per cent at publication time to £28.71.

Titular: BATS Global Markets withdraws support for IEX exchange push
Subtitular: Exchange operator claims start-up trading venue misrepresented the operations of other traders
Texto: BATS Global Markets has withdrawn its support for efforts by IEX, the start-up trading venue, to become a registered exchange, in the latest sign that the fracas over IEX’s application shows no sign of dying down.In a letter submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday, BATS claimed that IEX has repeatedly misrepresented the operations of other exchanges to preserve aspects of its own business that may not meet the legal requirements for a registered exchange.The second-largest US exchange operator said it had “serious concerns about entrusting a registered national securities exchange licence — a licence which conveys self-regulatory and quasi-governmental authority — to an applicant whose repeated misrepresentations of facts to the SEC and the public …call into question the applicant’s professional judgment”.BATS argued that IEX had falsely characterised parts of BATS’ business as well as that of rivals Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange either deliberately or by not doing enough homework to verify its claims. It also said IEX has launched “a public relations campaign” of similar distortions and “gross omissions of fact” about its own business.Brad Katsuyama, chief executive of IEX, responded: “IEX will vigorously defend our market, even if it means pointing out double-standards, duplicity and other practices that harm regular investors. It is clear that any exchange that prioritises and sells speed will seek to block a new entrant that is creating a level playing field.“When you compare the broad support that IEX has received to the narrow interests of exchanges and certain high-speed traders, it has never been more obvious why true competition is needed in the US stock market.”IEX’s bid to become an exchange has sparked a heated debate in the industry with the SEC fielding more than 400 comment letters from both supporters such as asset managers and critics such as NYSE, Nasdaq and the hedge fund Citadel.As chronicled in Flash Boys, the book by Michael Lewis, IEX launched in 2013 as a “dark pool” and marketed itself as a cure for unequal US markets, where ultra-fast traders buy data feeds from exchanges and exploit market movements.IEX will vigorously defend our market, even if it means pointing out double-standards, duplicity and other practices that harm regular investorsA successful exchange application would put IEX on an equal footing with BATS, NYSE and Nasdaq.The linchpin of IEX’s strategy is a 350 microsecond delay it says is to offset advantages enjoyed by high-frequency traders.Some industry participants have argued that the delay could threaten the sanctity of the price quotes from the exchanges that form the basis of official market prices.Jeff Sprecher, chief executive of NYSE parent Intercontinental Exchange, last week said IEX’s plan to become an exchange was “not fair” because it was in effect seeking an exemption from a federal rule that requires such venues to provide instantaneous price quotes. He also called the plan “un-American”.BATS had previously supported IEX’s application, but opposed the structure of IEX’s affiliated broker-dealer router which is not subject to the 350 microsecond delay.

Titular: Chinese group to buy Chicago Stock Exchange
Texto: The Chicago Stock Exchange, one of America’s oldest stock exchanges, is set to be bought by a group of investors led by China’s Chongqing Casin Enterprise Group, the exchange said on Friday.The buyout, which is subject to US regulatory approval, would mark the first time a Chinese company took control of an American bourse.While the Chicago Stock Exchange accounts for a minuscule amount of trading volume relative to rivals like the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq Stock Market — it processes around 0.5 per cent of US trading volume — it would give Casin a foothold in the American equities market since trades legally need to take place on the exchange offering the best price.Shengju Lu, the founder of the Casin Group, said that the acquisition will help “develop financial markets in China over the longer term and … bring exciting Chinese growth companies to US investors,” writes Adam Samson in New York.China has been gradually opening its markets to outside investors. For instance, it launched the Shanghai-Hong Kong Connect in 2014 in a move that paved the way for foreign investors to access Mainland China stocks with fewer restrictions than was previously the case.At the same time, there has been consolidation among US financial exchanges as new regulations in light of the financial crisis have made the trading business less lucrative. The IntercontinentalExchange Group, a derivatives marketplace, for example, bought the parent of the New York Stock Exchange in 2014.John Kerin, the chief executive of the Chicago Stock Exchange, said that it agreed to the sale following a strategic review. The terms of the sale weren’t disclosed.Founded in 1882, the Chicago Stock Exchange is working a new product called CHX|snap an on-demand auction that can be performed during the regular trading session that seeks to pull business back from so-called dark pools, exchanges that are operated by investment banks outside the public market.Mr Kerin said the buyout by Casin would allow the exchange to roll the product out by this spring. The IEX Exchange, another group, has made waves in the exchange marketplace with the introduction of a product that would create a “speed bump” that would slow down high-frequency traders who are accused of exploiting open markets.

Titular: ICE chief calls IEX speed bump plan ‘un-American’
Subtitular: NYSE owner says upstart trading venue is seeking monopoly status
Texto: IEX, the upstart stock-dealing venue, is taking an “un-American” approach to slowing down high-speed traders, the owner of the New York Stock Exchange has charged in comments that will further inflame debate over markets.Jeff Sprecher, chief executive of Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) said on an earnings call that IEX’s plan to become an exchange is “not fair” because it is in effect seeking an exemption from a federal rule that requires such venues to provide instantaneous price quotes.IEX launched in 2013 as a “dark pool” private trading venue and marketed itself as a cure for unequal US markets, where ultra-fast traders buy data feeds from exchanges and exploit market movements.After gaining fame in Flash Boys, the book by Michael Lewis, IEX has now applied to the US Securities and Exchange Commission to become a registered exchange. That status would allow it to provide equity trading on an equal footing with ICE’s NYSE, Nasdaq and BATS Global Markets.But IEX’s application has drawn fierce opposition because it wants to continue using its much-discussed “speed bump” system. IEX says its 350-microsecond delay, one thousandth of the time it takes to blink an eye, offsets the advantages currently enjoyed by high speed traders.On Thursday, Mr Sprecher said he did not oppose IEX becoming an exchange, but rather the idea of allowing it to use the speed bump without changing the rules for its competitors as well. Current regulations require equity price quotes to be immediately accessible in order to be counted toward the official bid and offer in the market.Mr Sprecher, who is based in Atlanta, blasted what he said would be “a one-off deal that benefits somebody that’s trying to patent and receive a regulated monopoly. I don’t think it’s fair. It is un-American, and it’s not fair and it’s not the way that our system should work.”Mr Sprecher said he supports instead a broad reassessment of rules on equities markets dominated by high-speed and automated strategies.“The ideas that they [IEX] are promulgating are not bad ideas at all. But the method that they’re going about it, we’re objecting to,” Mr Sprecher said. “This is solely for their benefit, not for the benefit of the industry. Frankly, if that were to go forward, IEX would actually hurt the other people in the industry.”But IEX says it believes its speed bump system is allowed by existing rules and that the other exchanges impose their own delays in different ways.“We think it is legal and don’t think we are asking for any special treatment or exemption,” Matt Trudeau, IEX head of product, told the Financial Times.IEX chief executive Brad Katsuyama argues that the NYSE and its other critics have been lobbying to stall its application in Washington. “It’s ironic that the supposed centrepiece of American free-market capitalism is using behind-the-scenes political pull to obstruct a new entrant from competing,” Mr Katsuyama said in an email.The IEX exchange application has prompted hundreds of comment letters from supporters and detractors, including a letter of support from Mr Lewis. ICE reportedly looked at buying IEX before Flash Boys catapulted the trading venue into the public eye.Mr Sprecher spoke after ICE reported net profit of $370m in the fourth quarter, up 28 per cent from $288m the same period a year before. Per-share earnings of $3.29 handily beat estimates, aided by a $100m drop in income-tax expense. ICE was down 6.7 per cent to $245.41 at midday in New York.The stock exchange represents a relatively small corner of ICE’s markets empire, which includes derivatives exchanges and market data vendors. Of $875m in fourth-quarter revenue, 7 per cent came from cash equities trading and 12 per cent was from listings.

Titular: Credit default swaps activity heats up
Subtitular: Record $15.7bn in gross notional positions of single name CDS cleared by investors in January
Texto: Asset managers and hedge funds are reviving a corner of the credit derivatives market, with a record number of cleared trades reflecting higher transactional volume so far this year.Credit derivatives — tarnished by the financial crisis and a subsequent tougher regulatory regime for banks — are experiencing renewed growth after a long period of decline. Recent market volatility has bolstered their appeal as investors use credit default swaps, which track the likelihood of default of a company, to insure their bond portfolios from specific losses and also implement derivative based trading strategies.A record $15.7bn in gross notional outstanding positions of single name CDS was cleared by investors during January according to the Intercontinental Exchange, the largest credit derivative clearing house. ICE effectively stands between trades in the market, a process that aims to reduce the counterparty risk of market participants such as banks, asset managers and hedge funds.ICE said the majority of the volume had come from new business, as opposed to investors pushing longstanding positions through the clearing house for the first time.The rise in activity comes after a group of 24 big asset managers and hedge funds, including Blue Mountain, Citadel, BlackRock and Anchorage, recently pledged that they would clear their own single name CDS trades in an attempt to bolster trading in the product. “A considerable amount is coming from the US but it’s also coming from around the world . . . because the pain that is felt is felt by all,” said Peter Borstelmann, head of corporate development at ICE Clear Credit in the US.Regulators have sought to push more of the opaque over-the-counter swaps market through centralised clearing houses, mandating certain interest rate and credit products to be cleared. Single-name CDS is not required by regulators to be cleared but investors are hoping the shift will help return liquidity to the product, even if the cost of clearing trades is initially higher.Citadel have submitted a comment letter to the Securities Exchange Commission that became public on Thursday, calling on them to mandate central clearing for the most highly traded single name CDS contracts.The advent of higher capital requirements has weighed on bank participation in the market. Central clearing is seen as mitigating some of the impact, with the aim of encouraging banks and new dealers to provide liquidity to the market.“The product has had some reputational issues that may have deterred some investors from taking it up,” said Steven Kennedy, head of public policy at the International Swaps and Derivatives Association. “But there are also issues around capital efficiency that are weighing on it. That is what we are engaged in now.”Cleared trades last month represent more than the combined amount for the last three months of 2015, taking the total notional cleared to $47.5bn. January set daily and weekly volumes records, added ICE.In spite of the uptick in cleared volumes, the CDS market remains a fraction of its size before the financial crisis, reflecting tougher capital standards for banks and fallout from being blamed for helping inflate the global credit bubble.The current outstanding gross notional for all single name CDS is currently around $6.8tn compared with $14.8tn at the end of 2008, according to data from the Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation.

Titular: Hedge funds cut back on short oil positions
Texto: Did hedge funds cover short positions because oil rallied or did oil rally because hedge funds covered?Nobody knows, is the short answer, but what the latest exchange and regulatory data undoubtedly shows is that hedge funds were closing out bets against the oil price at an astounding rate last week, reports David Sheppard in London.In North Sea Brent, the international benchmark, funds’ so-called net long position – the difference between bets on rising and falling prices – leapt by 52,801 futures and options contracts to a net long of 260,954 last week, data from the IntercontinentalExchange showed. That is a paper position equivalent to almost 261m barrels of crude.That move was led by the closing out of almost 25 per cent of all bets by funds against the price, with short positions shrinking by 34,179 futures and options contracts in the week to January 26.After hitting a 12-year low on January 20 of $27.09 a barrel, Brent prices have since rallied by almost a third, trading back above $35 a barrelFunds had amassed a near record bearish position in crude oil in New York and London at the start of the year, leading to warnings from some commentators that the market could snap back if traders moved to take profits on bets against the price.The exchange data only covers until last Tuesday, after which oil continued to rally, so it is likely the short position has shrunk further.Funds have also been building a bullish position in Brent in anticipation of a snap back in prices. Long positions in Brent have now reached the highest on record at the equivalent of 365m barrels of crude.

Titular: NYSE acts to improve equity market structure
Subtitular: Controls under scrutiny after China fears spark August flash crash
Texto: The New York Stock Exchange has called for co-ordinated changes to market controls for stocks in the wake of extreme market volatility last year.The exchange, a unit of Intercontinental Exchange, identified on Thursday some areas to improve market structure following an external review by McKinsey, the management consultancy.NYSE has come under pressure since concerns about an economic slowdown in China sparked a disjointed opening hour to trading on August 24.As some large stocks fell more than 20 per cent, wide gaps opened between the net asset values of exchange traded funds and their underlying securities. Nearly 1,300 products — mostly ETFs but also some stocks — were suspended for sharp moves.The episode highlighted NYSE’s role as a price-setter for a range of equities and exchange-traded products and weaknesses in controls put in place to safeguard investors in times of market stress.NYSE has been tweaking some of its own processes, but it also hired McKinsey to survey market participants regarding their experience on August 24 and potential solutions.Among the changes, NYSE will no longer accept stop-loss orders that many retail investors use to manage risk, as the orders “have a higher risk profile than they historically had, especially during volatile periods”.NYSE also has applied to regulators to widen the collars — or limits — on trading in securities when they reopen after suspension, a feature that market participants have said impeded rebounds in shares on August 24 without triggering new suspensions.In a 38-page report it published on Thursday, NYSE outlined a series of recommendations to further shore up market structure.The day’s events marked the first real test of so-called “limit up limit down” rules, which require trading suspensions for large price swings, implemented after the flash crash.NYSE said that the sheer number and rapid-fire nature of the halts reduced transparency and impeded rebounds in securities, and it has called for the rules to be amended, including aligning the way securities reopen after suspensions.It also called for rules for trading suspensions and cancelling erroneous trades to be better aligned as well as protections for investors around stock loss orders.Others have criticised NYSE’s opening process, which still includes the input of human traders. The exchange believes the hybrid approach damps volatility but rivals say it exacerbated it on August 24.“I do have one simple recommendation for them,” said Bob Greifeld, chief executive of Nasdaq, NYSE’s rival. “They should open their market at 9:30. All of those downstream problems would go away.”NYSE has already revised its opening processes to allow human traders to open more stocks electronically in times of market-wide stress, allowing them to focus on securities with the biggest anticipated moves.“The changes we are making will continue to have the benefit of human oversight but include more automation,” said Stacey Cunningham, NYSE’s chief operating officer.The report also called for further study of aligning halts in equities, exchange traded funds and futures markets. It follows similar assessments from BlackRock, one of the largest ETF providers, and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Titular: Oil climbs as exit from bearish positions begins
Subtitular: Traders have started to increase bets on a recovery by year end
Texto: Traders have started to increase bets on a recovery in oil by the end of the year, backing the view that recent selling has been overdone and the downturn in prices cannot last with so many producers burning through cash.Since hitting a 12-year low on Wednesday, Brent crude has jumped by more than 16 per cent as hedge funds have started to bank profits on positions designed to gain from the crash in prices and tentatively rotate into bullish strategies.There has been a flurry of buying of derivative contracts which give the owner the right to buy oil at $50 a barrel in December, according to exchange data, a move that suggests some traders and hedge funds believe current prices are “irrational”.Figures from the Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) show the number of $50 call options outstanding has increased to 46,233 — the equivalents of 46m barrels of oil — from 27,315 at the start of the year.There has also been a sharp rise in the number of $40 call options for December 2016.“The open interest in crude options continues to increase at a very strong pace and more on calls than puts,” said Olivier Jakob at Petromatrix, a consultancy in Zug, Switzerland.While some of the contracts may have been purchased by large oil consumers such as airlines seeking to lock in prices for the year, they also reflect a more positive view on oil.Many analysts and industry executives cannot be sustained and are not justified in the medium term by the fundamentals of supply and demand.On Thursday, Khalid al-Falih, the chairman of Saudi Arabia’s state oil company and one of the most influential voices in the industry, described the collapse in oil prices to below $30 as “irrational” and predicted they would be higher by the end of the year.“The market has overshot on the low side and it is inevitable that it will start turning up,” Mr Falih, told the World Economic Forum in Davos.The 18-month downturn in prices has left US drillers and other high cost producers teetering on the brink, while oil majors have shelved nearly $400bn of spending, pushing back millions of barrels a day in future output from areas including the Gulf of Mexico, Africa and Kazakhstan.On top of that, the number of countries calling for action to counter low prices has started to rise. This week Venezuela called for an emergency Opec meeting, while Oman said this week it was ready to cut production by 5-10 per cent.“The list of producer countries that are hyperventilating about the low price is however starting to get longer and with that the geopolitical premium should not be discounted,” said Mr Jakob.Brent crude, which fell to a 12-year low of $27.10 a barrel on Wednesday, was trading at $31.50 on Friday. West Texas Intermediate, the US oil benchmark was $31.65, up $26.19 a barrel on Wednesday.In spite of the rally, oil prices on both sides of the Atlantic have still fallen sharply this month. Brent is down more than 15 per cent and WTI almost 14 per cent.
