Utility stocks have recently pared solid gains this year – the S&P utility sector is up 12.8 per cent in 2007 – as investors have become concerned at the sector’s low dividend yield as compared with rising bond yields.“Utilities have run a little further beyond reasonable valuations,” said Mr Ablin.Verisign was 5.3 per cent higher at $29.43 after chief executive Stratton Sclavos resigned. The internet infrastructure company’s stock is up 22.1 per cent this year on the back of expansion and diversification of its operations.

Titular: ICE signs exclusive deal with CBOE
Texto: The Intercontinental Exchange has signed an exclusive deal with the Chicago Board Options Exchange in a move which could boost the appeal of its unsolicited bid for the Chicago Board of Trade.The ICE-CBOE pact, announced on Wednesday, aims to end the long-running legal battle between the Board of Trade and the city’s options exchange, which has coloured the two rival bids for the CBOT.The Atlanta-based ICE is seeking to break up the agreed merger between the CBOT and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with its own all-stock offer, and the deal with the CBOE is the latest part in a complex puzzle of interlocking relationships in the fast-growing global derivatives sector.The CBOE is the largest US options exchange by volume, and its rapid growth and product innovation has made it a target as the 34-year old group prepares for its own initial public offering next year.The CBOT argues that some of its members are entitled to an equity stake in the options group, which was spun out of the Board of Trade in 1973 and is valued at $2.3bn based on current prices for its 931 seats.The options exchange maintains a CME-CBOT deal invalidates any such claims – though this is refuted by the two Chicago futures exchanges – and the issue is due to come before a Delaware court on Wednesday.The ICE has leveraged the Chicago conflict in its pursuit of the Board of Trade, a deal that would marry its own energy and commodities businesses with the CBOT’s positions in financial and agricultural futures and options.While CBOT directors continue to recommend the CME deal – which was sweetened earlier this month – its terms put it below both the ICE offer and the CBOT share price.Jeff Sprecher, chief executive of the ICE, opened discussions with his opposite number at the CBOE when he launched the unsolicited offer for the CBOT in March.The deal expected on Wednesday would see CBOT members receive $500,000 in cash or convertible stock for each so-called “exercise right” held at the CBOE, if the CBOT is eventually acquired by the ICE, though the deal could be overturned in court. The ICE and the CBOE would share the $665.5m cost equally between them.The ICE and the CBOE also agreed a commercial partnership to develop and distribute products on their respective electronic and floor-based trading platforms.The agreement comes ahead of the first open meeting between Mr Sprecher and CBOT members, scheduled for Thursday.CBOT’s influential membership remains split over the merits of the competing offers and the option of remaining independent, but analysts said the meeting would raise further concerns among Merc executives that it might fail to win backing for its agreed bid.Some members note that the CME – which has not closed a takeover despite the flurry of consolidation in the exchanges sector – has had nine months to broker a settlement with the CBOE, but has opted to pursue a settlement through the courts.Pressure from CBOT members has already forced CME to boost the terms agreed last October after the value of its all-stock offer fell 30 per cent below that of ICE’s proposal.CBOT directors have intensified talks with members and shareholders in recent days ahead of a July 9 vote on the proposed CME deal, with registration for applicable shares closing on Tuesday.While CME offer continues to lag both the ICE proposal and the CBOT share price, its value is expected to rise if it secures clearance for the deal from the justice department. A decision is expected as early as next week.The regulator has been examining the all-Chicago deal since last December amid a furious lobbying effort by some investment banks and intermediaries, which claim the enlarged exchange would damage competition.

Titular: ICE gears up to resume battle for CBOT
Texto: The Intercontinental Exchange will meet members of the Chicago Board of Trade next week in an effort to win backing for its $11bn takeover bid and break up the rival deal with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.CBOT’s influential membership remains split over the merits of the competing offers and the option of remaining independent, but analysts said the meeting would raise further concerns among Merc executives that it might fail to win backing for its agreed bid.Pressure from Board of Trade members forced CME to sweeten the terms agreed last October after the value of its all-stock offer fell 30 per cent below that of ICE’s proposal.Jeff Sprecher, founder and chief executive of ICE, has held meetings with individual CBOT members and users, seeking to assuage concerns that the smaller exchange lacked the technology and infrastructure to handle volumes at the Board of Trade.CBOT directors continue to recommend a deal with CME, which would create the world’s largest futures exchange and regain a position challenged by recent deals involving Deutsche Börse and the recently-formed NYSE Euronext.ICE cancelled a meeting with CBOT members in March at the request of its target’s directors. CME executives subsequently met Board of Trade members.”For an exchange that has championed transparency, integrity and fairness of its markets, it is about time those values were applied to the ICE’s interest in acquiring it as well,” said John Lothian, head of electronic trading at The Price Group and publisher of a respected industry newsletter.CBOT directors have intensified talks with members and shareholders in recent days ahead of a July 9 vote on the proposed CME deal, with registration for applicable shares due to close on May 29.While CME offer continues to lag both the ICE proposal and the CBOT share price, its value is expected to rise if it secures clearance for the deal from the justice department. A decision is expected as early as next week.The regulator has been examining the all-Chicago deal since last December amid a furious lobbying effort by some investment banks and intermediaries, which claim the enlarged exchange would damage competition. The Chicago exchanges said they expected regulatory approval for their proposed deal before the July 9 meeting, though are also contesting a lawsuit from one shareholder calling for the vote to be delayed because CBOT accepted an offer lower than both the ICE proposal and its market value.The Chicago exchanges also need to find a solution to the long-running spat with the Chicago Board Options Exchange over CBOT members’ so-called exercise rights, which could provide Board of Trade investors with a stake in the CBOE’s upcoming initial public offering. A court hearing on that issue is also scheduled for next week.

Titular: ICE steps up CBOT takeover bid
Texto: The Intercontinental Exchange has hired a high-profile proxy firm to press the merits of its takeover bid for the Chicago Board of Trade in a sign that it is prepared to appeal directly to shareholders with a deal now valued at $11.3bn.The move comes as CBOT directors launch focus groups to back their continued recommendation of a takeover by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, whose all-stock offer still lags behind the ICE proposal by $1.6bn in spite of being raised this month.Jeff Sprecher, chief executive of the ICE, has retained Innisfree M&A, a proxy group whose clients include AirTran, a US low-cost airline pursuing a takeover of rival Midwest, according to two people close to the situation.This comes ahead of any direct move to go over the heads of the CBOT board, which maintains the Merc offer is “superior” because of synergies and long-term growth prospects. The ICE and Innisfree declined to comment.The value of the ICE – and its offer for the CBOT – has been boosted in recent days amid speculation it could be targeted by NYSE Euronext.ICE stunned executives at both Chicago exchanges with its offer for CBOT on March 15, upsetting the CME’s plan to create the world’s largest futures exchange.While CBOT directors reaffirmed backing for the CME deal ahead of a shareholders’ meeting on July 9, the discount to the ICE offer and the CBOT share price has widened.The ICE and its advisers continue to hold meetings with individual CBOT shareholders and users, seeking to assuage concerns that the smaller exchange lacks the technology and infrastructure to handle volumes at the Board of Trade.Mr Sprecher remains keen to hold a briefing with CBOT shareholders and members after cancelling an address in March at the request of the Board of Trade.Charlie Carey, CBOT chairman, recently told the Financial Times it would not oppose such a meeting.While the ICE wants to avoid a hostile move on the CBOT, the widening gap between the competing offers and the hiring of a proxy firm intensifies pressure on the CME.The Merc continues to enjoy rapid organic growth, but has failed to close any acquisitions at a time when rivals have expanded.

Titular: CME tries sweetener to sway CBOT bid
Texto: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange on Friday sweetened its bid for the Chicago Board of Trade to about $9.95bn in an effort to head off a competing offer and avoid losing ground in the consolidation of the global derivatives sector.CME executives insisted the 16 per cent rise in its all-stock offer was driven mainly by increased synergies from a combination that would create the world’s largest futures exchange.The enhanced terms still leave the CME deal, which retained its recommendation from the CBOT board, trading below both the Board of Trade share price and the unsolicited offer from the smaller Intercontinental Exchange made in March, now valued at $10.58bn.On Friday, Charlie Carey, CBOT chairman, told the Financial Times that the new CME offer was superior to the ICE bid because of its long-term strategic fit and synergies. However, some CBOT members suggest the CME could have to revise the terms again to secure investor approval at a vote on July 9, amid growing calls for the Board of Trade to retain its independence and seek a better deal next year.The CME, which had previously resisted calls to raise its offer, is under pressure to join in industry consolidation. In the past it has failed to secure deals in both the US and Europe while rivals such as Deutsche Börse and NYSE Euronext expanded through acquisitions and targeted an increased share of the US and global market.CME shares gained 7.7 per cent on Friday, lifted by its suggestion that regulators would approve the all-Chicago tie-up before the July vote. Craig Donohue, chief executive, told the FT that the justice department probe was “substantially complete” amid furious lobbying against the proposed deal from some leading banks and brokers, who claimed it would reduce competition.Mr Donohue said recent efforts by NYSE Euronext and the ICE to establish their own futures clearing houses showed there was healthy competition in clearing and settlement, a key part of the antitrust probe.The ICE on Friday said its existing proposal offered “greater immediate and long-term value” than the CME bid and Mr Carey said the Atlanta-based exchange could follow the example of the Merc last month and address Board of Trade members on the merits of its offer.

Titular: Wall St rallies on inflation data
Texto: Wall Street rebounded on Friday, and that enabled the S&P 500 index to narrowly maintain its weekly winning streak that began at the end of March.A sharp sell-off on Thursday saw the major benchmarks suffer their largest one-day decline in two months following weaker-than-expected chain store sales.Investors were also worried that inflation concerns at the Federal Reserve could impede a rate cut later this year.Analysts described the pullback as a healthy correction and, indeed, buyers emerged on Friday, buoyed by an unexpected cooling in core production inflation for April.Moreover, the continued run of inconclusive economic data appears to be putting a ceiling on long-term interest rates, allowing the continued availability of relatively cheap financing, fuelling the boom in mergers and private equity buy-outs.Doug Peta, equity strategist at J&W Seligman, said: “There is a powerful structural force between buyouts and robust stock buybacks by companies that is reducing the supply of outstanding shares in the market.”He said that until there was an event that forced corporate bond rates to rise from current historically low levels compared with Treasury yields, “the acquisition boom will swamp economic fundamentals”.As stocks rose on Friday, the S&P edged out of negative territory for the week.At late-afternoon, the S&P 500 index closed up 1 per cent at 1,505.85, for a gain of 0.015 per cent this week.Technolgy and materials stocks were a bright spot among the main industry groups in the S&P. In contrast, healthcare and consumer staples stocks were the worst-performing stocks during the week.The Nasdaq Composite rose 1.1 per cent to close at 2,562.10, but lost 0.4 per cent this week.The Russell 2000 index of small companies was 0.4 per cent lower this week, after setting a record close on Wednesday.Blue chips maintained their recent streak, and on Friday the Dow Jones Industrial Average rallied 0.8 per cent to 13,326.22, a rise of 0.5 per cent since Monday. The Dow set its 21st record close this year at 13,362.87 on Wednesday.Deal activity this week was led by Alcoa’s hostile $27bn bid for Alcan, its Canadian aluminium producer rival.Alcoa rose 6.6 per cent to $38.03, and is up 27 per cent in 2007, while Alcan had soared 31.2 per cent to $80.05 for the week.In other deals, Armor Holdings agreed to be bought by UK defence contractor BAE Systems for $4.1bn. Armor rose 3.7 per cent to $85.17 this week, and is up 55 per cent so far this year.Deal chatter in the steel industry pushed shares in AK Steel 14.9 per cent higher to $35.59, while US Steel posted a 6.4 per cent gain to $111.08.Countrywide Financial rose 8.1 per cent to $41.08 this week as the mortgage lender is seen as a likely buyout candidate in the wake of the recent deal for student lender SLM.Trading activity before the recent $25.2bn buyout of SLM, also known as Sallie Mae, was the latest target of regulators as they investigated suspicious option trades. SLM’s shares fell 1.2 per cent to $54.15 this week.On Friday, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange made a revised bid for CBOT Holdings, the rival derivatives exchange.CBOT’s board accepted the new bid valued at about $9.2bn, and rejected the competing unsolicited offer made by the Intercontinental Exchange of about $10.1bn launched in March. Shares in CME jumped 7.7 per cent to $536.30 on Friday, while CBOT rose 3.8 per cent to $201.35 and ICE rallied 4.2 per cent to $140.55.Hopes for News Corp’s recent $5bn bid for Dow Jones receded this week, as Dow’s share price slipped 4.8 per cent to $53.10, below the $60-a-share offer.News Corp was 1.2 per cent lower at $23.30 this week, and it reported a 6.2 per cent rise in profits for its fiscal third quarter, meeting estimates.Shares in Yahoo lost 3 per cent to $30.05 this week as hopes for a merger with Microsoft faded.Cisco weighed on the Nasdaq this week. Its fiscal third quarter profits rose 34 per cent from a year ago, but the company disappointed investors with its revenue guidance.The computer network operator fell 4.6 per cent to $26.63.In other earnings news, Whole Foods’ first quarter profits fell 11 per cent year on year, missing estimates amid slowing sales growth and rising costs. Shares in the organic food retailer slid 9.5 per cent to $40.97.This week, same-store sales figures for April arrived and 85 per cent of retailers missed their forecasts. The sector was hit hard, with shares in Jones Apparel down 5.7 per cent at $28.85.A notable laggard this week was Dendreon. The drugmaker plunged 68.5 per cent to $6.11, after the Food and Drug Administration sought more information about its prostate cancer vaccine.Shares in Johnson & Johnson and Amgen slid 3.4 per cent to $62.27 and 11.7 per cent to $56.30, respectively, after an FDA panel said their anti-anaemia drugs should face further restrictions.Barr Pharmaceuticals rallied 10.2 per cent this week to $54.83 as the company reiterating its earnings outlook on Wednesday.

Titular: Battle for CBOT
Texto: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange’s latest salvo in the fight for its crosstown rival, the Chicago Board of Trade, does not look like being a killer blow. But it raises the pressure on Intercontinental Exchange, which upset CME’s plans with a counterbid for CBOT in March. For all the bluster about strategic merits outweighing mere price considerations, CME could not ignore the 22 per cent discount that had opened up between its own offer and ICE’s prior to yesterday. Rumblings that anti-trust watchdogs were intensifying scrutiny of the proposed CME-CBOT tie-up raised doubts about execution.CME’s new bid does not close the gap entirely; it is still between 6 and 7 per cent below ICE’s implied offer and CBOT’s actual share price. Moreover, CME has in effect cut the cash element for CBOT’s shareholders. Under the old terms, they could elect to receive up to $3bn in aggregate, in place of CME stock. Now, they will potentially share in a $3.5bn share buy-back post-completion: worth $1.2bn based on pro-rata ownership of the combined company of 35 per cent.Still, when all the combatants are trading on 35 times 2007 earnings or more, using paper as ammo makes more sense. And the underlying message of CME’s bid is strong. Backed by CBOT’s reaffirmation of the merits of the deal, it signals confidence that the deal will not be blocked by regulators. Combining CBOT with CME, rather than ICE, makes more sense due to greater overlap and existing clearing links.ICE could always raise its bid further, but its own shareholders already face being diluted down to less than 50 per cent ownership of the combined entity under its existing offer terms. That, at least, should mean ICE would not be afraid to court suitors for itself if it does end up losing the battle for CBOT. That ICE’s own shares rose on the news of this apparent setback suggests some investors are already positioning for this eventuality.

Titular: CBOT investors cool on bids
Texto: The fate of the Chicago Board of Trade was in the balance on Thursday night as shareholders increased pressure on the second-largest US futures exchange to walk away from two competing bids at current prices.People familiar with the situation said the CBOT and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, its larger cross-town rival, were trying to reach an agreement on a higher offer that would satisfy shareholders in the CBOT.Last week, the value of the agreed deal with the CME fell to 31 per cent below the more recent unsolicited offer from the IntercontinentalExchange, now worth $10.6bn.The value of both all-stock offers has see-sawed since the ICE sought to break up the all-Chicago combination, agreed last October – a deal that promised to create the world’s largest futures exchange.The slumping value of the CME deal – weighed by weak April volumes – has encouraged some CBOT members to push for it to retain its independence.They argue that the franchise has been strengthened by the launch of side-by-side electronic trading of agricultural futures last August. While trading of financial futures, mainly Treasury bonds, dominates volume at the CBOT, volatility in the corn and soyabean markets has helped push agricultural dealing up by more than 50 per cent in the past year. More than half of the deals are now made electronically and carry fatter margins than financial futures.The recent takeover of the International Securities Exchange by Deutsche Börse’s Eurex subsidiary has also encouraged some CBOT members – who retain 80 per cent of its shares – that frothiness will remain in the exchange sector.While they recognise the stock would fall if they rejected both offers at a July 9 shareholders meeting, some say the drop would be small and overtaken by future gains and the emergence of another offer.The CME would have to raise its offer by 40 per cent to reach what members view as a knock-out level of $2.10-$2.20 a share. It has the right to change its terms up to July 9, even if the CBOT withdraws its recommendation.The CBOT would avoid the $240m break-up fee if shareholders rejected the CME proposal at the meeting but the Board of Trade is barred from entertaining another takeover bid for a year after that.CBOT directors have so far retained their recommendation of the CME deal while they evaluate the rival ICE offer.All of the exchanges declined to comment.

Titular: Exchange clearing
Texto: The back office is moving to front and centre. In the battle for leadership in exchanges, the hitherto Cinderella activity of clearing has emerged at the vanguard. Clearing – acting as a central counterparty to both sides of a trade – encourages total strangers to buy and sell with one another. That has become more important as the range and volume of contracts, particularly derivatives, traded over-the-counter have exploded.It is no accident that Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) is leading the charge. The US energy trading platform plans to create a global clearing service for its users. That follows its acquisition of the New York Board of Trade – bringing with it in-house clearing expertise – completed in January. At a tactical level, ICE’s move can be interpreted as a means of strengthening its hand in its battle against the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to take over the Chicago Board of Trade.There is more for which to play, particularly in energy. In the 1990s, oil, gas and power were traded between a relatively small number of industrial companies, most with robust credit ratings of their own. Those that did not eventually came to rely on Enron as a de facto clearing house. Enron’s collapse left the market bereft, as well as prompting a lot of ex-traders to set up operations of their own, helping to fuel the current boom in trading volume.As the big commodities exchanges compete more aggressively – look at how ICE barged its way into the West Texas Intermediate oil contract – clearing helps to attract and hold liquidity. A unified clearing operation, enabling the netting of positions across products and geographies, reduces margin calls for traders. And until regulators force a more competitive market in OTC futures clearing, there is the simple attraction of economics: net profit margins are estimated at 50 per cent or more.

Titular: ICE’s CBOT offer raises stakes for CME
Texto: The pressure on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to sweeten its agreed bid for the Chicago Board of Trade intensified on Monday as the premium in the rival offer from the Intercontinental Exchange touched $1.5bn for the first time.The Board of Trade last week said it was nearing the end of its review of the ICE proposal, with some directors continuing to push the CME to at least match the terms proposed by the smaller, Atlanta-based ICE.The CBOT continues to recommend a combination with its cross-town rival, but the board is expected to outline its stance as early as this week, in spite of emphasising that price will not be the sole driver.The CME hopes to create the world’s largest derivatives exchange by adding the Board of Trade’s strength in financial and commodity products to its interest-rate, equity and commodity futures and options.But the rival ICE proposal – which would add its energy and over-the-counter portfolio to the CBOT franchise – now commands a premium of 17.5 per cent over the CME bid, based on Monday’s movements in the all-share bids. The gap started at 10.5 per cent when the ICE offer was announced in March.CME executives have derided the premium as “illusory”, questioning the ability of the ICE to integrate its target and provide clearing and settlement services for the enlarged entity. They have continued integration work with the Board of Trade, and rescheduled shareholder meetings for July 9 to vote on the deal.But the agreed deal has yet to be approved by antitrust regulators, and the ICE has been able to exploit concern from some large banks about the pricing power of an enlarged Chicago exchange to win support for its own proposal. Exchange experts said this reflects concern among institutions about the CME’s expansion.ICE shares closed at $127, valuing its offer at $9.56bn, a 16 per cent premium to the CME’s $8.23bn bid.

Titular: Deutsche Börse lands in US via ISE
Texto: Eurex has not sat idly by and watched US rivals steal its number one slot among global derivatives exchanges.With the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Intercontinental Exchange still vying for control of the Chicago Board of Trade, Eurex – a joint venture between Deutsche Börse and Switzerland’s SWX exchange – yesterday sneaked through an acquisition of its own.The deal to buy the International Securities Exchange moves the German-controlled group into the fast-growing realm of US options, after an unsuccessful foray into US futures.A 70 per cent stake in Eurex US was sold off to Man Financial, the UK futures broker, last year, after the unit had tried, and failed, to break the US futures market off its own bat.The ISE deal was a surprise to investors on Monday, who sent ISE stock up 45 per cent but a logical consummation of a long-standing relationship with Eurex – the two had come close to a deal five years ago.It marks the culmination of a US expansion effort for Eurex that goes back to the start of the decade.Among the biggest stumbling blocks for Eurex – and its rival, Euronext Liffe which made a similar foray into the US at the same time – was that futures products in the US are not “fungible”.That is, each exchange clears its own contracts; and a contract cannot be opened on one exchange and closed on another.In effect, neither European exchange could ever attract the liquidity it needed to launch a credible competitive threat.But the US options market is a different animal. Options are regulated, like equities, by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is committed to promoting competition in order to cut costs for consumers.In the US, options trading is fungible, with all exchanges clearing through the user-owned Options Clearing Corporation.The ISE itself is a creature designed to shake up what once was a cosy options market. It was the first to offer electronic dealing.Moreover, it was a trailblazer that burst the historic business model in which the various options exchanges agreed which contracts they would list, each agreeing not to offer competing products.Within a few years, its competitors moved to electronic trading as well. But in the meantime, spreads on options tightened, cutting costs and bringing increasing liquidity to the market overall.Options trading is the fastest growing securities segment in the US market. Overall, volumes are up 22 per cent for the first quarter of 2007.Indeed, both the NYSE and Nasdaq have announced plans to open their own options platforms, increasing the competition.However, analysts note that the recent acquisition by NYSE of Paris-based Euronext and its London-based futures subsidiary, Liffe, may be behind the Börse’s move.NYSE itself has been rumoured as a possible bidder for the ISE, although it has said it is not eager for any further acquisitions right now. However, with its acquisition, the Börse is entering what analysts believe is the most fiercely contested business operated by US exchanges today.That view has led several analysts to question the price being paid, a 47 per cent premium to where the ISE’s shares closed at the end of last week.“They appear to be paying a whacking great premium,” said Andrew Mitchell, analyst at Fox Pitt Kelton, who follows Deutsche Börse from London.“The more difficult thing to gauge is whether that is justified.”If the Börse can use the ISE platform, for instance, to launch products currently traded on its Eurex platform, it could see significant volume growth.Moreover, analysts are concerned that profit margins may be eroded by the roll-out of “penny pricing”, a move inspired by US regulators.Penny pricing means reducing the bid/offer spread on options contracts, which had been as wide as 5 cents or more, to a penny.

Titular: ICE plans to set up clearing unit
Texto: The Intercontinental Exchange said on Monday it plans to launch a European clearing house to work with its US clearing operations.The move by the Atlanta-based energy and soft commodity market is a further sign of the global ambitions of securities and derivatives marketplaces and the potential they see in providing services to over-the-counter derivatives markets.It is a blow for LCH.Clearnet, Europe’s largest clearing house, which made an estimated $50m in fees from ICE customers last year.The US group entered the clearing business this year when it acquired the New York Clearing Corporation as part of its $1bn purchase of the New York Board of Trade.LCH.Clearnet announced fee cuts for ICE users in March, in a move thought to be aimed at encouraging customers to put pressure on the ICE to keep clearing its London trades through LCH.Clearnet.But the ICE responded by raising transaction fees, keeping the benefits of LCH.Clearnet’s tariff reductions to itself. Monday’s announcement suggests the ICE plans to phase out the European clearer’s role.The new unit, ICE Clear Europe, to be based in London, is preparing an application to the UK’s Financial Services Authority to become a recognised clearing house, and is scheduled to begin clearing energy futures and over-the-counter contracts in July 2008.The ICE estimates that it could make $25m to $30m in fees for clearing services in 2008, and clearing revenues in excess of $60m in 2009.ICE is also competing with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to buy the CBOT Group. ICE’s $10bn offer for the owner of the Chicago Board of Trade in March took the futures industry by surprise, raising the prospect of a bidding war.Jeff Sprecher, founder and chief executive of the ICE, has suggested that regulators could block the all-Chicago plan to create the world’s largest derivatives exchange.Analysts see any boost to the ICE’s clearing capability as raising the credibility of its bid for CBOT.

Titular: Deutsche Börse to buy NY-based ISE
Texto: Deutsche Börse on Monday announced plans to buy the International Securities Exchange for $2.8bn in cash, extending the group’s US foothold with the addition of an options platform and a fledgling equities business.The agreement with the German group’s Eurex derivatives arm was expected to trigger another potential bidding war in the US derivatives sector, despite a price viewed as rich by analysts, with the recently-formed NYSE Euronext seen as a possible suitor.Deutsche Börse had appeared to be left without an obvious partner after losing out to the NYSE in the protracted battle for Paris-based Euronext at a time when Chicago’s two largest derivatives exchanges had agreed to merge, before the recent counterbid for the Chicago Board of Trade by the Intercontinental Exchange.The frenzy of consolidation in the global exchange sector is driven by the increasing appetite for risk management and speculation tools by global investors, with exchange operators looking to maximise the scale and breadth of products offered through their platforms to secure economies of scale..The New York-based ISE is the second-largest US options platform by volume after the Chicago Board Options Exchange - another potential NYSE target - with double-digit percentage growth rates exceeding even expansion in the futures business. New rules aimed at bringing spreads on options trading to a penny - currently being tested - are expected to help boost volumes even furtherThe arrival of Eurex - whose expansion in US derivatives foundered two years ago - comes amid growing interest by many exchanges in the options sector. The NYSE is already expanding its Arca business, while the Nasdaq has targetted a 20 per cent market share through a green-field launch or an acquisition, having recently held talks with the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.The ISE transformed the US market with its launch as an all-electronic exchange, forcing its five existing rivals to follow suit and abandon all or part of their existing floor-based business models.Eurex and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange both held talks with the ISE three years ago, before it decided to become the first US options exchange to seek an initial public offering. The Board of Trade also sought a merger with the CBOE last year, with the options exchange now planning its own IPO as early as 2008. CBOE seats prices reached a new record on Monday amid expectations of renewed interest in the exchange or a higher potential flotation price.ISE shares rose 46 per cent during Monday trading, peaking just short of the $67.50 a share being offered by Eurex, which is jointly owned by Deutsche Börse and the SWX Swiss Exchange. The offer represents a 48 per cent premium to last Friday’s close.Deutsche Börse said the agreed combination would overtake NYSE Euronext as the largest transatlantic derivatives exchange, with 2.1bn contracts a day based on 2006 data. It would retain the ISE brand and regulation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.The market leadership of the ISE in US equity options would add to the strength of Eurex in interest-rate futures and, increasingly, equity-based futures.

Titular: Concern over Nigerian polls lifts oil prices
Texto: London’s InterContinental Exchange is to launch a contract for Middle Eastern sour crude oil futures to compete with the contract that will trade on the Dubai Mercantile Exchange. The DME intends to start its contract in June, but ICE, which sponsors the Brent sweet crude contract, said it would launch on May 21, pending UK regulatory approval.Oil prices rose Friday as traders’ attention turned to Nigeria’s presidential elections this weekend and the possibility of disruptions to supplies from the world‘s eighth largest crude exporter.ICE June Brent rose 39 cents to $66.33 a barrel, down 3.4 per cent this week. Brent came under pressure on reports from Nigeria that Shell had resumed limited production from the 380,000 b/d Forcados field, although the company did not confirm this. However, dealers were concerned that if Nigeria’s presidential elections were tainted by allegations of vote rigging, further violence could affect supplies.Nymex May West Texas Intermediate contract, expiring Friday, gained $1.05 at $62.88 a barrel, down 1.2 per cent this week. June WTI added 44 cents at $63.76 Friday.US gasoline stocks have fallen for 10 consecutive weeks as supplies tighten ahead of the summer driving season. Nymex May RBOB gasoline rose just under 2 cents to $2.1079 a gallon Friday but fell 3.3 per cent over the week.Gold rose 1 per cent to $691.80 a troy ounce this week, supported by dollar weakness and news of progress in Iran’s nuclear programme.Platinum gained 3.2 per cent at $1,313 a troy ounce, helped by renewed fund interest following plans by Zurich Cantonal Bank and ETF Securities to launch platinum exchange traded funds. Two major platinum producers voiced concerns, fearing the ETFs could cause a price spike and damage jewellery demand.Base metals displayed resilience despite concerns that China might be forced to raise interest rates to cool rapid economic growth.Copper rose 3.3 per cent this week to $7,960 a tonne, supported by concerns over supply disruptions at the giant Grasberg copper mine in Indonesia, where workers have threatened to extend their protest for a month if welfare benefit demands are not met.After hitting a contract record of $15,200 on Wednesday, tin fell 4.3 per cent this week to $13,750 a tonne after the Indonesian government approved export permits for two smelters this year.Nickel added 5.2 per cent to $48,900 a tonne as available stocks remain critically low at around 2,900 tonnes.May wheat futures rose 4.9 per cent to $5.02 a bushel in Chicago this week on reports of frost damage to US planting. Global wheat stocks stand at near record lows and concerns are mounting about drought affecting the Australian harvest.Wet weather has slowed spring corn planting but conditions are expected to improve in the midwest in the next few days. May corn fell 1.5 per cent to $3.63½ a bushel this week.

Titular: USFE seeks new friends on MySpace
Texto: The US Futures Exchange is 99 years old and male, at least according to its new MySpace page in what market experts view as the first move by the derivatives sector into the world of social networking.The details provided by the Chicago-based exchange which, like its peers, prides itself on the transparency of its markets, could just catch the eye of regulators. The USFE is in fact less than one year old, formed in late 2006 when Man Group took over the US exchange formed by Eurex, the derivatives platform controlled by Deutsche Börse. Its sex was previously undisclosed.The appearance of the USFE on a site beloved of teenagers and musicians comes as it launched its inaugural contract on Friday, based on the outcome of the two-way battle for control of the Chicago Board of Trade.The ”binary” contract is viewed as an opportunistic move ahead of the formal launch of the USFE, target retail investors with the exchange’s initial product offerings before widening to attract institutions and hedge funds.Binary futures offer an all-or-nothing pay-out on a range of defined outcomes, such as the Chicago Mercantile Exchange or the Intercontinental Exchange winning the CBOT bid battle or the acquisition of CBOT by a third party.The USFE has been working on its Myspace page for a number of weeks and was first reported by John Lothian, a Chicago-based trader who publishes a widely-followed blog and newsletter. “For the longest time I had only one [MySpace] friend, said Mr Lothian who, like many in the sector, was previously unaware of the social networking site before signing up to view the USFE offering.Mr Lothian is now joined by 13 other friends on the USFE page.

Titular: DTCC to handle Turquoise settlement
Texto: A group of leading investment banks intent on setting up a pan-European trading platform to rival the likes of the London Stock Exchange and NYSE-Euronext on Wednesday appointed a company to provide settlement services for the new venture.The initiative, which is known as “Turquoise” and is backed by seven banks, including Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse, has selected EuroCCP, a European subsidiary of the US-based Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation, to provide clearance and settlement services for the new venture.Consolidation has been sweeping the global exchanges sector in the face of competition from start-ups like BATS and Instinet in the US and Virt-X in Europe. Exchanges are also under pressure to provide cheaper dealing costs.The NYSE bought Euronext at the end of last year in the first transatlantic exchange deal and the Intercontinental Exchange is trying to break up a planned merger between the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.The LSE fought off Nasdaq to retain its independence but has been forced to cut costs for users in order to keep their business.The seven investment banks, which also include Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch, UBS and Citigroup, currently account for about half of all equity trading volumes in Europe.Total trading costs on Turquoise are expected to be less than half the cost on traditional exchanges when the platform launches at the end of this year or the beginning of next year.The platform is designed to take advantage of a European Union directive which comes into force in November and will slash the cost of trading in Europe, traditionally higher than in the US.DTCC, the biggest provider of settlement and clearance services in the US, is setting up EuroCCP to provide clearance and settlement services for Turqoise. The venture will be based in London.A spokesman for Turquoise said the banks are expected to select a trading platform “in the near future” before naming key executives to launch the project.DTCC is owned by its users, which include banks and brokers in the US who trade equities, bonds and derivatives. It does not offer settlement or clearing for futures or options.

Titular: ICE starts due diligence on CBOT
Texto: The Intercontinental Exchange has started formal due diligence on its proposed $9.3bn purchase of the Chicago Board of Trade, although it has yet to schedule a formal meeting with members of the second-largest US derivatives platform.The Atlanta-based ICE is seeking to break up an agreed merger between the CBOT and the larger Chicago Mercantile Exchange with its own higher offer. The bid premium hovered at about 10 per cent on Tuesday.The Chicago exchanges postponed a shareholder and member vote on their proposal, which is still backed by the CBOT board, from April 4 until July 9. The CBOT is continuing to hold talks with the ICE, but had previously engaged in only an “exchange of information” with its rival suitor.The launch of formal due diligence is not expected to lead to an amended ICE offer but would pave the way for the exchange to seek a meeting with CBOT members, who still control about 80 per cent of its shares according to people familiar with the talks.The ICE and the CBOT declined to comment, though the CBOT has insisted its definitive agreement with the CME allowed it to examine competing offers in a fair and balanced manner.Executives from the CME addressed CBOT members last month and in spite of savaging the rival offer and promoting the benefits of its own deal, which would create the world’s largest futures exchange, many members have pressed the CME to match the ICE offer.CME executives have dismissed the ICE premium as “illusory”, questioning the claimed synergies and raising doubts about its rival’s ability to integrate the CBOT. The all-Chicago proposal is still being probed by US antitrust officials.ICE executives could face more questions about plans for the CBOT’s remaining open-outcry business after complaints this week about the treatment of floor traders at the New York Board of Trade, which the ICE acquired this year.The ICE specialises in all-electronic trading of energy and over-the-counter products, and has been converting the Nybot, which focuses on soft commodities such as sugar, to more screen-based business.The exchange last week lifted a fee on electronic trading at the Nybot, which had helped preserve the smaller floor business.“We felt like we needed to warn the traders in Chicago not to trust ICE’s management when they claim they want to protect floor trading,” Dennis Lepre, a veteran Nybot trader who is organising the opposition, told the New York Post. The group plan to highlight their position in Chicago newspaper adverts this week.The ICE said it supported both screen and floor-based trading so long as there was demand from clients.CBOT shares closed at $192.90 on Tuesday, valuing it at $10.2bn, with the all-stock offers from the ICE and the CME valued at $9.8bn and $8.9bn respectively.

Titular: Volumes soar at CBOT and CME
Texto: Chicago’s two dominant futures exchanges handled record trading volumes during March as rising volatility combined with more electronic trading by clients.The Chicago Board of Trade – the subject of a two-way bid battle between the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Intercontinental Exchange – Monday reported a 30 per cent rise in March volumes to an average of 11.7m contracts a day.That lifted the overall first-quarter total by 24 per cent and provided fresh clues for valuing the world’s third- largest futures exchange.The CME, which trails only Eurex by volumes, is likely to have overtaken its German-Swiss rival with a 30 per cent quarterly gain in trading volumes and a 45 per cent rise in March.The CME used its monthly report to stress its organic growth and ability to handle sharply higher trading volumes as it awaits a CBOT board review of the surprise counterbid from the ICE.A 0.6 per cent share price rise in CME helped narrow the gap with the richer ICE offer for the CBOT to $12.37 a share, or about 6.8 per cent. The ICE reports its March volumes Tuesday.The Atlanta-based ICE says the CME’s offer undervalues the CBOT and underplays its growth potential – claims denied by the CME – though Board of Trade members have indicated the larger Chicago exchange should raise its bid.The all-Chicago deal was agreed last October and the Board of Trade’s agricultural volumes have been a key driver of growth since, led in part by uncertainty in the corn market where prices have reached 10-year highs.Corn future volumes grew 67 per cent in the 12 months to March 31, helped by the introduction of electronic trading last August. Options volumes rose 153 per cent.While interest-rate products remain the dominant source of earnings for the Board of Trade, overall agricultural volumes outpaced financial products and also provided the highest margins – in terms of rate per contract – according to data for February, the latest month available.The Merc traded an average of 6.5m daily contracts while average volumes on its Globex electronic platform climbed 40 per cent to 4.8m.The CME provides clearing services for Board of Trade and lists contracts for the New York Mercantile Exchange on Globex, which also reached record levels.The Merc has questioned the ability of the ICE to handle the Board of Trade’s rising volumes as the Atlanta exchange expands its own in-house clearing system.

Titular: Plenty of life left in exchanges battle
Texto:
The gloves are off as the rival suitors for the Chicago Board of Trade exchange increasingly hard-hitting comments about the merits of their respective offers, whose differential has narrowed from as high as $1.3bn to $840m on Wednesday.The outcome of the unfolding battle for control of the CBOT is likely to determine the future shape of the fast-growing global derivatives business.The Intercontinental Exchange launched its unsolicited offer two weeks ago – on the CBOT’s 149th birthday – in a move which clearly stunned the Board of Trade’s arranged suitor, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.The Board of Trade, the second-largest US futures exchange, is certainly no corpse. Demand for its suite of interest-rate and agricultural futures has surged with the increasing sophistication of global risk-management strategies and the shift to more electronic trading, pushing its market value up threefold since
its flotation at the end of 2005.Jeff Sprecher, the founder and chief executive of the ICE, argued that the CME’s October 2006 merger proposal undervalued the Board of Trade franchise and restricted its growth potential.He argued that his business, offering energy and soft commodity futures and a platform for trades in the larger over-the-counter sector, could leverage undermanaged potential in the CBOT business.This message has been rejected by the CME, but has invigorated the CBOT membership, who still control about 80 per cent of the stock.They made it clear at last week’s CME presentation that they would have voted down the Chicago merger plan, a realisation which saw the April 4 ballot postponed.Craig Donohue, CME chief executive, has called the premium offered by the ICE “illusory”, though members also signalled they expected the Merc to at least match the terms offered by the Atlanta-based exchange. Mr Donohue and his board have so far declined to make such a move.The greatest pressure is on Charlie Carey, the CBOT chairman feted by members for taking the exchange public and breaking down other barriers such as electronic trading of agricultural products. The emergence of an offer at one point valued at some $1.3bn above the existing terms is viewed as an embarrassment among CBOT members. “Charlie has lost his sheen,” said one trader.The stand-off by members – reluctant to leave any money on the table – has forced Mr Carey and his board to open talks with the ICE and “exchange information” with the rival suitor.However, the ICE has not publicly said it is conducting “due diligence”, and advisers point to lock-ups in the merger agreement between the Chicago exchanges.Both the ICE and the Board of Trade have declined to comment on their negotiations. However, Terry Duffy, the CME chairman who brokered the merger, told the Financial Times that the Merc would not change the “criteria” in the agreement which determines what data the CBOT can share. The Merc maintains that the CBOT is not restricted in its ability to talk to third parties.Any reluctance to open the CBOT books in the same fashion afforded to the Merc will draw fire from members and shareholders, and risks devaluing the CME’s efforts to defend the merits of its own plan and its questioning of the rival ICE offer.Mr Donohue has already questioned the ICE proposal’s synergy targets, the robustness of its trading platform and the future value of its stock.

Titular: ICE steps up effort to break rivals’ merger
Texto: The Intercontinental Exchange on Monday insisted it could handle trades for the Chicago Board of Trade “within six months” as the US-based futures exchange stepped up efforts to break up the agreed merger between its two larger Chicago rivals.The ICE is expanding the clearing platform acquired with its purchase of the New York Board of Trade, and dismissed comments from the CME that it would be unable to meet the demands of handling business from the CBOT if it wins an increasingly fractious bid battle.Jeff Sprecher, the founder and chief executive of ICE, on Monday moved to counter what he described as “extremely misleading and disingenuous” comments from CME executives about his rival offer, which is being examined by the Board of Trade.The ICE also strengtened the bid team led by Morgan Stanley. UBS, the world’s largest futures broker, and Société Générale, whose futures arm is merging with Credit Agricole’s derivatives unit, signed up in a move which highlights the importance of clearing and settlement in the futures industry. JP Morgan is the lead advisor to the CME.“We believe we could have the required scale in clearing within six months,” said Mr Sprecher on an investor call on Monday which offered a detailed rebuttal of the offensive against his bid launched by the CME last week.However, the premium in the ICE proposal on Monday fell to its lowest level since the bid was announced on March 15. CBOT stock continued a three-session decline after the CME indicated it would not raise its own bid, despite calls for improved terms from many CBOT members at a presentation last week.CBOT shares dipped 1.8 per cent to $186.90 by midday in New York, while the ICE fell 2 per cent to $121.03 and CME shares lost 0.5 per cent at $538.38.The proposed ICE premium has now halved to less than 6 per cent, which analysts said reflected the preference expressed by CBOT members for a sweetened offer from the Merc, as well as a shift by the stocks towards trading on their fundamentals.Both Chicago exchanges are expected to report higher first-quarter earnings after volumes spiked during last month’s turmoil in the equity markets.Craig Donohue, the CME’s chief executive, last week declined to be drawn about a higher offer, though dismissed the ICE premium as “illusory” in a wide-ranging attack which also questioned the proposed sysnergies and highlighted lingering tensions with the large banks which still dominate futures transactions.The banks continue to act as intermediaries between the exchanges and customers such as hedge funds, and Mr Donohue said end-users remained supportive of the all-Chicago combination.The ICE has recieved high-profile support from some of the large banks, which Mr Sprecher said reflected the competition which the smaller exchange would bring to the market, as well as enhanced opportunities in over-the-counter market.The Atlanta exchange, which operates Nybot and the former London-based International Petroleum Exchange – now known as ICE Futures - already generates half its revenue from handling OTC deals, a segment which the CME is targeting with an array of initiatives which it said have irked some of the banks which currently doiminate the sector.

Titular: Obama shelves CBOT/CME merger support
Texto: Illinois senator Barack Obama has quietly shelved his support for an agreed merger of Chicago’s two biggest futures exchanges while directors of the Chicago Board of Trade evaluate a rival offer from the Intercontinental Exchange.The presidential hopeful was one of 10 signatories to a letter sent to Alberto Gonzales, the US attorney general, backing the all-Chicago deal as a way to protect the city’s financial community and the broader interests of the US in international markets.Senator Dick Durbin, the Senate majority whip, reiterated his support for the CME-CBOT agreement last week after a higher all-stock proposal from the Atlanta-based ICE.However, Mr Obama has opted not to repeat the backing he gave, with other members of the Illinois congressional delegation, in the letter, dated November 20.A person close to the presidential hopeful said: “Senator Obama supported the merger between CBOT and CME because of the boost it would provide for the Chicago financial community. We await the conclusions of the review by the CBOT Board on the unsolicited ICE proposal so that we can determine our position on that bid.”The Chicago exchanges still retain substantial political backing and influence in Congress, though the ICE on Wednesday played down its significance. “The politicians will defer to the [CBOT] members,” said Jeff Sprecher, the founder and chief executive of ICE, in an interview with the Financial Times.CBOT directors have yet to meet with the ICE or exchange information, after announcing on Monday that they would hold talks and permit limited due diligence.The board has retained its recommendation for the CME’s all-stock offer, though analysts believe the Merc will have to raise its bid to close a $1.3bn gap with the ICE proposal. The CBOT also postponed an April 4 vote of members and shareholders to approve the CME deal.The two Chicago exchanges are due to address members and investors on Thursday. The CME has described the ICE offer as “inferior”. Mr Sprecher defended his proposal and said the CME had undervalued the CBOT franchise.The ICE is split evenly between energy and commodities’ futures and over-the-counter products. Mr Sprecher said there were opportunities to leverage the CBOT’s interest-rate futures to provide OTC products.

Titular: CBOT delays key vote on CME merger
Texto: The Chicago Board of Trade on Tuesday evening postponed an April 4 shareholder vote on its agreed merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The delay allows investors to review the $9.9bn unsolicited offer from the smaller Intercontinental Exchange.CBOT said in a statement on Tuesday the merger “remains in effect”.CME quickly reiterated CBOT’s confidence. ”We fully expect the CBOT’s board, after completing its review, will recognise that the CME/CBOT merger is superior to ICE’s unsolicited proposal - financially, strategically, and operationally,” CME said late on Tuesday.The Atlanta-based ICE maintains the “CME rhetoric will not fool CBOT shareholders” as the gap between the value of its richer all-sock offer and the Merc’s existing proposal continued to widen.Tuesday’s public spat between the rival suitors pushed the market value of CBOT to a record high of almost $10.5bn.The ICE is expected to take its case to the CBOT this week after the Board of Trade agreed to talks and limited due diligence, while retaining its recommendation in support of an all-Chicago combination.The CBOT board can also change its recommendation on Thursday under the terms of its CME agreement, which includes a $240m break-up fee.CME’s bid could yet be derailed by the US justice department amid concerns over its dominance in clearing and interest rate products, although officials do not expect it to be blocked.Jeff Sprecher, chief executive of the ICE, is expected to arrive in Chicago on Wednesday to meet CBOT executives and explain the merits of his own exchange’s bid.CME executives, including executive chairman Terry Duffy and chief executive Craig Donohue, will address Thursday’s meeting.They will argue that ICE’s estimated synergies appear exaggerated and say that the ICE proposal could limit the CBOT’s comparative future growth potential. “In our view, the ICE proposal is significantly inferior to the CME CBOT merger – financially, strategically and operationally,” said Mr Donohue.He added that the CME/CBOT transaction provides “more value to our respective customers through reduced expenses and greater trading opportunities”.ICE plans this week to unveil a 10-fold increase in the capacity of its in-house clearing system.

Titular: ICE plans huge boost to clearing system
Texto: The Intercontinental Exchange plans to unveil a 10-fold increase in the capacity of its in-house clearing system in a bid to persuade members of the Chicago Board of Trade that it can consummate its planned $10bn merger of the two US-based futures platforms.The impact on electronic clearing of contracts is among a number of concerns expressed by CBOT members after the ICE last week unveiled an unsolicited plan to merge with the Board of Trade.The surprise bid challenged the agreed combination of the CBOT with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced in October, stirring an industry which had just settled following the bruising takeover battles for Euronext and the London Stock Exchange.Directors at the CBOT on Monday agreed to hold talks with the Atlanta-based ICE, a specialist in energy futures and handling over-the-counter trades which has already acquired the International Petroleum Exchange and the New York Board of Trade during its seven-year existence.Jeff Sprecher, the ICE’s founder and chief executive, also secured backing to start due diligence on an offer which he maintained offered better value to shareholders than the CME merger plan.CBOT shares ended up 3.5 per cent at a record $196.71 amid speculation from analysts that the CME would be forced to sweeten its existing offer for control of the 159-year-old CBOT, which specialises in financial, metal and agricultural derivatives.The CME declined to comment, but the gap between its offer and the higher ICE proposal widened following Monday’s share-price movements. The all-Chicago combination carries a $240m break-up fee, but analysts said the CME could afford to pay up to $220 a share before losing the accretive value from buying the CBOT.The ICE postponed a briefing of the CBOT’s members – who still control around 80 per cent of its stock following its 2005 flotation – scheduled for March 21, when it is expected to meet CBOT executives. However, the improvements to the electronic ICE clearing system are intended to alleviate concerns that its smaller ICE platform would be unable to handle the larger volume of CBOT trades.The Board of Trade uses CME’s clearing system for its electronic trades – it retains an open-outcry floor – under a deal recently extended until 2009, providing the Merc with an estimated $80m in revenues this year. “We have a lot of time to grow the scale of these systems,” Mr Sprecher told the Financial Times.He has also raised the spectre of regulators blocking the all-Chicago deal, though CME executives express confidence that antitrust officials will not hinder its plan to create the world’s largest futures exchange, despite an ongoing probe by the justice department into its dominance in clearing and interest-rate products.

Titular: Wall Street rises modestly aided by M&A deals
Texto: Wall Street rose modestly on Thursday as a flurry of deals helped offset concerns about inflation and economic growth ahead of quarterly derivative contracts on stocks expiring on Friday.Stocks briefly shed gains when Alan Greenspan, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said woes in the subprime mortgage market were “not a small issue” and could spill over into other sectors.At the close of trade on Thursday, the S&P 500 was 0.4 per cent firmer at 1,392.28. The Nasdaq Composite rose 0.3 per cent to 2,378.70 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average had rallied 0.2 per cent to 12,159.68.Fears that the subprime mortgage market would harm financial stocks were allayed when Bear Stearns reported rising first quarter earnings, boosting its shares by 2.2 per cent to $148.50. This week’s solid earnings from Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs had already eased concerns that subprime woes would spread. But analysts warned that the worst for financial stocks could still be ahead.Materials led, buoyed by news that Dow Chemical was seeking a joint venture with Reliance Industries, India’s leading petrochemical maker. Shares in Dow rose 5.6 per cent to $45.80.The Intercontinental Exchange launched an unsolicited $9.9bn bid for CBOT Holdings valued at $187.34 a share.CBOT is on course to complete an $8bn merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in May.Shares in CBOT rose 17.4 per cent at $194.95 – and set a high of $195 in early trade – as investors contemplated a bidding war.Brad Bailey, senior analyst at Aite Group, said “the bid puts pressure on CME to move its attention away from post-merger planning to try to get the deal done”.Shares in ICE fell 2.9 per cent to $128.10, reversing an earlier jump to $133.50. CME fell 5.5 per cent to $532.88, making it the worst performing stock in the S&P 500.The mood in stocks briefly soured when the producer price index for last month rose much more than expected. This kept inflation concerns on the radar.Peter Cardillo, chief investment economist at Avalon Partners, warned that investors would watch closely the consumer price index report due on Friday. A sharp rise in core CPI “would give the market a nasty case of indigestion”.In other deals, General Electric’s Capital Solutions and Blackstone Group reached agreement to acquire PHH Corp for $31.50 a share in an all-cash purchase valued at about $1.8bn. Shares in the mortgage and fleet management services company rose 11.8 per cent to $31.10. GE was up 0.6 per cent at $34.52.Cisco said it would acquire WebEx Communications in a $3.2bn cash deal for the online meeting company. Shares in WebEx jumped 22 per cent to $56.38. Cisco shares fell 0.15 per cent at $25.81.

Titular: Wall St falls for the week as subprime fears intensify
Texto: Wall Street plumbed new lows for the year this week but stocks recovered as investors regained composure after subprime mortgage scares.The talk on Wall Street yesterday after a week of severe volatility, was mostly about a report that Blackstone, the private equity group, was planning an initial public offering.A market debut by Blackstone is likely to be taken as a sign of confidence in the face of recent weakness in global equities. Details of the offer are unclear, but Blackstone is understood to be in advanced stages of preparation. The prospect of a flotation is likely to cause a big stir.Shares in Fortress Investment, the private equity group and hedge fund manager, almost doubled on its market debut in February amid intense demand from retail investors. By the close on Friday Fortress had fallen 30 per cent to $25.74 from its intra-day record high $37 reached on the day of its market debut.The Blackstone talk came at the end of a tumultuous week in which stocks were propped up by the seemingly relentless flow of deals, including a dramatic bid for CBOT Holdings.After the tentative gains made in the previous week, technical analysts had been anticipating a “test” that would indicate whether the recent turmoil would develop into a longer-lasting bear market.When the “test” came on Tuesday and Wednesday, it was once again related to subprime mortgage problems. But familiarity with the issue was little comfort to investors watching stocks plunge across the board.At one stage the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell below the 12,000 mark; a plunge of 5.9 per cent from its record high in February.The Dow closed 0.4 per cent lower on Friday, to stand 1.3 per cent down for the week at 12,110.41. The S&P 500 Index was 1.1 per cent lower at 1,386.95. The Nasdaq Composite slipped 0.6 per cent to 2,372.66.Financial groups led the slide down, and the way back up, as three big investment banks reported results. In the event, Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns all met or exceeded expectations. But with rumours of losses swirling round the market, the announcements were a source of anxiety and reassurance by turns.Persistent worries about Lehman’s exposure to subprime mortgages sent its shares at one point 10 per cent below Tuesday’s opening. But the stock rallied as executives said the group was well-hedged. Lehman was finished the week 6.1 per cent down at $71.19. Goldman Sachs was 1.3 per cent down at $199.Some analysts expected that volatility would continue. “Long-term investors should pull up a lawn chair and enjoy the fireworks,” said Marc Pado, chief market strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald. “Until we get through some of the crazy action, the sidelines should be a safe and comfortable spot.”Stuart Schweitzer, global markets strategist for JPMorgan Private Bank, said the market “will need much greater clarity about corporate earnings before a meaningful rally can ensue”.Carmakers skidded this week. General Motors reported better fourth quarter profits and revenues. But its stock plunged 5.9 per cent to $29.17 on concerns about its US sales amid a possible economic slowdown. Rival Ford fell 4.9 per cent to $7.55.In deal news, the future of CBOT was thrown into doubt after the Intercontinental Exchange launched an unsolicited $9.9bn bid. CBOT was set to merge with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Shares in CBOT rose 12.5 per cent to $190 as investors contemplated a bidding war.Speculation that Dow Chemical was seeking a joint venture with Reliance Industries, India’s leading petrochemical maker, lifted its shares 5.2 per cent to $45.25.Retailers remained under pressure as confidence in consumer spending flagged. Wal-Mart, which withdrew its application to open a specialty bank on Friday, fell 2.6 per cent to $46.21. Target slid 3.4 per cent to $59.77.Homebuilders were in the doldrums on fears of tighter lending affecting the spring home selling season. Pulte Homes fell 8.5 per cent to $26.31 while DR Horton was down 6.3 per cent to $22.83.Accredited Home Lenders said it had agreed to sell $2.7bn of its subprime mortgage loans at a discount to free up cash to pay its creditors. Accredited surged 15.7 per cent to $10.90 on Friday.

Titular: CBOT to discuss ICE bid on March 20
Texto: Directors from the Chicago Board of Trade will meet on Tuesday to evaluate the surprise counterbid launched on Thursday by the Intercontinental Exchange, though officials have yet to decide whether to open the books to their Atlanta-based suitor.The unsolicited all-stock bid from the ICE came just three weeks before CBOT members were due to vote on an agreed merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which has so far declined to comment on whether it will sweeten its own bid with more cash.CBOT shares dipped 2.7 per cent to $189.79 in early trading, just above the value of the indicative offer from ICE based on Wednesday’s closing prices. Shares in both the ICE and the CME were narrowly down, reducing the value of their current offers.Sources close to the Board of Trade suggested directors were unlikely to let the ICE go hostile and appeal directly to its members, opting instead to evaluate the proposal and seek a higher offer from the CME. All three exchanges declined official comment.Analysts said the CME had the greater financial firepower to raise its bid – with some suggesting it could go as high as $220 a share before it failed to become accretive.However, Jeff Sprecher, the founder and chief executive of the ICE, has raised the spectre of regulators blocking or diluting the all-Chicago plan because of its impact on competition in interest-rate futures and clearing. Mr Sprecher said this week he had “intimate” knowledge of the probe being conducted by the justice department, and said CBOT shareholders should be “concerned” about the outcome.Executives from both Chicago exchanges this week reiterated their confidence that the deal would not be blocked, although they also said demands for any concessions could result in the collapse of the pact.The executives maintain that opposition to the deal is being driven by banks’ concern about the inroads that an enlarged CME Group could make into their profitable over-the-counter business, rather than competition issues.

Titular: ICE chief seeks to calm storm in Windy City
Texto: Jeff Sprecher plans to exchange contracts on a new home in Chicago on April 2, but his welcome in the city is far from certain.The chief executive of the Atlanta-based Intercontinental Exchange on Thursday launched an audacious bid to break up one of the most celebrated deals in the city’s history – the agreed merger of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade.Mr Sprecher’s surprise move could alienate many in the city, where exchange leaders and traders of the two Chicago exchanges – buoyed by high-level political support – buried decades of fierce rivalry to secure support for the merger plan announced last October.Dick Durbin, the Illinois senator and Senate whip, on Thursday reiterated his support for the existing Chicago deal, a position held by his junior partner, the presidential hopeful Barack Obama.The CME and the CBOT portrayed their deal as a bid to maintain Chicago as the self-styled “derivatives capital of the world”, but Mr Sprecher echoed this claim, and dissected the perceived weaknesses of the transaction.CBOT traders, who had cheered Terry Duffy, CME chairman, when the merger was announced in October, indicated they would take the new proposal seriously. Mr Sprecher offered the promise of ending a rancorous dispute with the Chicago Board Options Exchange, paving the way for Board of Trade members to claim a disputed share in its planned initial public offering.The prospect of additional business from combining the ICE business in soft commodities such as cocoa and sugar with the CBOT’s larger agricultural business also drew some applause, though some traders still argued the synergies from an all-Chicago combination remained more impressive.However, Mr Sprecher played on lingering fears that regulators could block or dilute the merits of the CME-CBOT plan because of its sheer scale in the US and near-monopoly on clearing exchange-traded futures, a claim which CME leaders have rejected.He also appealed to the ego of the Chicago trading community by promising a global growth platform, painting the Chicago combination as a defensive move.CBOT shareholders would retain control of the enlarged organisation, which would keep its name and Chicago trading floor, as well as the metals business which was threatened with closure because of the CME’s existing involvement in the segment through a joint venture with the New York Mercantile Exchange.While the management structure of an ICE-CBOT combination has yet to be revealed, only one senior Board of Trade executive was due to remain with the enlarged CME Group, encouraging managers faced with redundancy to give support for the ICE proposal. The olive branch to the CBOE could also help marshal broader support in the Chicago exchange community.Mr Sprecher’s move could double the size of the ICE, which expanded into the energy sector by acquiring the London-based International Petroleum Exchange in June 2001, launching a fierce rivalry over the trading of oil futures with the Nymex and providing a clearing relationship – through LCH.Clearnet – which afforded its move into an OTC business that now provides half its revenues.Mr Sprecher guided the ICE through the fallout from the collapse of many US energy traders in the wake of the Enron scandal, and has also maintained the independence of the exchange, deflecting past interest from both Nymex and the CME.The $1bn purchase of the New York Board of Trade last September moved the ICE into soft commodities such as cocoa and sugar, and also provided its own clearing house for the first time, which Mr Sprecher said had been expanded to deal with the volume of CBOT business from the proposed acquisition.He is committed to retaining both the existing Nybot and CBOT trading floors – despite the migration of the majority of their business to the screen. The key test will be whether the rapturous reception given to CME and CBOT executives last October on the Board of Trade floor is repeated if he gets to proceed with his own plan.

Titular: ICE makes $9.9bn offer for CBOT
Texto: The consolidation of global exchanges was thrown into flux on Thursday as the Intercontinental Exchange of Atlanta shocked the financial world by launching an unsolicited $9.9bn offer for the Chicago Board of Trade that would break up the CBOT’s agreed merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.The proposed bid – which was 10.5 per cent higher than the CME’s indicative offer – was timed to coincide with a major futures industry conference in Boca Raton, Florida, and led to immediate predictions of a bidding war for the CBOT.Analysts said that if the combination of the two Chicago exchanges was derailed, Deutsche Börse might be tempted to seek a deal with the CME, and the NYSE Group could become more likely to bid for the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the biggest US options exchange.“People are walking around stunned,” said Gary DeWaal, general counsel at broker Fimat and Florida conference delegate. “This is a tremendous wild card and opens up the process dramatically. It may alter the whole chemistry of the landscape.”ICE officials made it clear they were seeking to take advantage of concerns on Wall Street that an enlarged CME would wield excessive power in the growing global derivatives market.The CME-CBOT deal is being vetted by the US justice department on antitrust grounds.Jeff Sprecher, ICE founder and chief executive, said: “We believe we are in the best position with the regulators.”Under the ICE proposal, CBOT shareholders would retain a narrow majority of shares in the combined company – which would retain the CBOT name and Chicago headquarters.Mr Sprecher said the ICE’s all-stock proposal could introduce a cash element to sweeten its deal. (Letter to CBOT)The business would combine the Board of Trade’s business in financial and agricultural commodity futures with the ICE focus on energy, soft commodities and OTC transactions.The CME insisted it would proceed with the CBOT purchase but has become concerned about the opposition marshalled by the banks ahead of shareholder and member votes on April 4.Executives of the Chicago exchanges have defended the near-monopoly it would have on exchange-traded futures in the US – a focus of the justice department probe – because of the globalising nature of the derivatives business.Executives maintain opponents are motivated by the potential loss of profits rather than any “public good”.CBOT shares rose as much as 15 per cent to a record $192.42, above the $187.34 proposal from the ICE. ICE, which floated in November 2005, fell 3.7 per cent to $127.13, and CME dropped 3.8 per cent to $542.63.Additional reporting by Daniel Pimlott in New York

Titular: ICE’s counterbid for CBOT
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange hopes to break up Chicago’s marriage of the year in the nicest way possible. It has trumped the Chicago Mercantile Exchange’s offer for girl-next-door the Chicago Board of Trade with an approach of its own. Can it succeed?Besides the higher price, ICE’s all-stock bid has two potential advantages. It panders to political sensitivities. CBOT’s shareholders would retain a slim majority in the combined entity and the headquarters would be in Chicago. In addition, regulators may be more comfortable with a pro forma market share in US futures trading of about one-third – compared with the almost 90 per cent estimated for the combined CME-CBOT.Still, ICE is unlikely to walk away the winner with this bid, which is probably why it set its implied premium to CME’s competing bid – based on Wednesday’s close – at a tantalising but not blockbusting 10.5 per cent. Investors were clearly surprised, as CBOT’s shares have traded in line with CME’s offer since it was made last October. They jumped by 17 per cent on Thursday.CME has powerful incentives to counter ICE’s offer. Apart from lost synergies, CME could lose out if money it now makes clearing trades on CBOT migrates to ICE. Citigroup estimates these at 7 per cent of CME’s revenues. Assume a net profit margin of 50 per cent and that equates to almost $70m in earnings, based on consensus forecasts for 2008. On a multiple of 30 times – at the bottom end of the sector – that is potentially worth more than $2bn in terms of market cap. CME is worth $19bn.ICE’s great hope, therefore, lies with regulators derailing CME’s plans. For now, the market is more hopeful of a bid battle developing – CBOT is trading at a 7 per cent premium to ICE’s higher offer. That in turn probably explains why ICE’s shares, which rose on the initial announcement, have fallen since.

Titular: Commodities exchanges
Texto: Where can you buy exposure to a heady cocktail of energy, metals, market volatility and the bets made by hedge funds? The answer for many is listed commodities exchanges. The big four in the US – Nymex Holdings, CBOT Holdings, Intercontinental Exchange and Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings – trade on multiples of anywhere between 34 and 50 times 2007 earnings.There is a lot behind the buzz. Growth in traded volumes of futures and options has been phenomenal. Tight markets in the likes of oil and copper have fuelled a craze for commodities as an asset class and boosted volatility in those markets. Hedge funds’ speculative forays add to the mix. Pre-tax margins are 40 per cent or more. US regulations mean futures exchanges operate their own clearing houses, mitigating competitive pressure. Further consolidation is expected.Given all that, it may seem odd that Nymex, which floated in November, appears to be the target of heavy short-selling. Short interest in the stock in February was equivalent to more than half of the free float, according to data from Bloomberg. The free float is now just 8 per cent. But that could increase soon. Last month, Nymex said it would canvass shareholders’ interest in a secondary issue, possibly to occur before May, when the first lock-up period was originally expected to expire.If Nymex was a bargain when it floated – its stock more than doubled on day one – there are signs that now would be a good time to lock in some profits. That should not mean a general sell-off: shares in rivals have breezed through earlier lock-up expirations. But for the sector as a whole, current multiples discount frenzied commodities markets, rampant hedge funds, synergistic mergers and high barriers to entry continuing for a long time.
