Investors should be concerned when the long-term view sounds uncannily like the immediate past.

Titular: Nymex seeks to close UK subsidiary
Texto:
The New York Mercantile Exchange is seeking to close its UK subsidiary Nymex Europe as an exchange with the UK regulatory authorities, closing out its option to list its futures contracts on its London exchange.Nymex launched an open outcry exchange in London in September 2005 to compete with the IntercontinentalExchange in the Brent crude futures market. But meaningful trading on the floor never took off and it abandoned the scheme after a few months.Since then, it has used Nymex Europe as an electronic exchange for trading Brent and NorthWest Europe gasoil futures, but these markets have also attracted small volumes.“The decision to close NEL [Nymex Energy Limited] follows careful review of the Nymex group’s European strategy and significant changes in the market place and manner of trading for exchange-traded products over the last few years,” Nymex Europe said in a letter to its members.The letter said that Nymex Europe had listed its products alongside those of
its parent on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange’s Globex electronic trading platform.“Although the parallel electronic listing provides many commercial advantages, it has also highlighted the value of having one consistent set of rules to govern related products that are listed on the same platform, rather than by competing regulatory agencies whose rules pose significant cross-jurisdictional challenges,” said the letter, which was signed by John Mackeonis, Nymex Europe chief compliance officer.The letter said Nymex remained wholly committed to enhancing its European presence.

Titular: Nybot chief executive dies at 66
Texto: Harry Falk, president and chief executive of the New York Board of Trade, died Wednesday, aged 66.Mr Falk was elected chairman of Nybot’s board of governors in October 2000, before being named interim president and chief executive in April 2002, a position confirmed in July 2003.Mr Falk guided Nybot through one of its most turbulent periods after the September 11 terrorist attacks which destroyed its trading floor in the World Trade Center.Nybot recently agreed to merge with the Intercontinental Exchange, and the company said his death would have no effect on this agreement.Falk had been instrumental in securing the merger and had been engaged in a public debate about actions of the rival New York Mercantile Exchange, that were, he said, designed to ‘interfere’ with the merger.Nymex, which specialises in energy and metals, plans to introduce six agricultural futures contracts.These would directly compete with the soft commodity products already trading on the Nybot, which leases space in Nymex’s building on the banks of the Hudson in downtown Manhattan.A member of the Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange since 1970, Mr Falk joined the CSCE board of managers in 1989 and was appointed vice-chairman in 1990.His association with the CSCE began in 1958 as a clerk for Czarnikow-Rionda, a Cuban sugar company, where he rose to become a partner in the company.Mr Falk lived in Rockland County, New York, with his wife Joan. They had five children and 12 grandchildren.

Titular: Probe into ETP’s energy swaps trades
Texto: Energy Transfer Partners, operator of the largest intra-state natural gas pipeline system in the US, is under investigation by federal regulators over physical gas purchases and gas swaps trades done on the Intercontinental Exchange, the energy derivatives market.Regulators have subpoenaed the New York Stock Exchange-listed company after a report that a subsidiary artificially lowered the price of natural gas at the main gas purchasing hub in Texas in an apparent attempt to influence the outcome of a series of swaps trades.The development comes as Democrats in Washington appear poised in January to press for legislation to tighten oversight of the over-the-counter (OTC) energy markets.Such calls, spearheaded by California Senator Dianne Feinstein, have been mounting since a report in June by a congressional committee claiming that speculation in OTC energy markets was contributing to record energy prices.They have been fuelled by trades at hedge fund Amaranth, whose bets in energy swaps on ICE this year went wrong, causing losses of around $6bn.OTC markets are where trades are negotiated privately between parties and are regulated more lightly than exchange-traded markets.Atlanta-based ICE is one of the most active markets for OTC trading, dominating trading in gas swaps, which are based on dozens of trading hubs across the US.Critics of the regulatory regime are concerned that regulators of physical and derivatives markets may be unable to spot manipulation given the lack of any regular reporting of such trades to regulators.Such reporting – known as “larger trader reporting” - is routine in exchange-traded markets.OTC energy markets were exempted from such oversight by passage of the Commodity Futures Modernisation Act (CFMA) in 2000. Participants in such markets were deemed able to self-regulate.John McReynolds, president of Energy Transfer Equity, a holding company that owns Energy Transfer Partners (ETP), said the company had received subpoenas from regulators as a follow-up to “several data requests”.He declined to name the regulators but they are understood to be the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, (CFTC), which oversees futures markets, and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.FERC regulates the inter-state transmission of oil, natural gas and electricity. Both agencies declined to comment.ETP operates 12,000 miles of natural gas pipelines in the US, mostly in Texas. The company generated revenues $8.1bn in fiscal 2006, which ended May. It posted earnings that year of $730m.A report in Platts, an energy publication, in September detailed allegations that an ETP unit, Energy Transfer Co, last year used its dominant market presence at the Houston Ship Channel gas hub in an apparent attempt to influence the outcome of its gas swap trades on ICE.It detailed a series of moves involving the purchase by ETP of large amounts of natural gas at the hub with the aim of driving prices lower.Such prices were then allegedly reported to a pricing index operated by Platts which is widely used by natural gas participants as a benchmark for gas pricing.The report alleged that ETP then used the index price as the basis for pricing certain swap transactions with other counterparties.ETP has not been charged with any offence. However regulators want to establish whether an artificial price was created in physical natural gas with the aim of benefiting the company’s OTC swap trades on ICE.Mr McReynolds told the Financial Times the Platts report was inaccurate.A reported “disconnect” between the normal physical gas prices at the Houston Ship Channel and the Henry Hub natural gas hub in Louisiana, off which New York Mercantile Exchange gas futures are priced, was due to supply disruptions caused by hurricane Katrina last year, he said.ETP has set aside around $30m to settle “regulatory inquiries” into trading activity at that time.The company said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing last week that while it was “unable to predict the final outcome of these inquiries, management believes it is probable that the industry regulators will require a payment in order to conclude the enquiries”.Mr McReynolds said ETP had complied with “all laws and regulations”. The $30m provision was a “pure contingency on a hypothetical possibility”.To bring lawsuits against those suspected of price manipulation or false reporting of energy prices, regulators must not only show that manipulation took place but also that there was intent to do so.Mr McReynolds said: “There was no intentional wrongdoing and we have not found any wrongdoing of any kind. However companies will often make a payment of some kind just to settle a matter because under these vague statutes or regulations there is no clear right answer.“We have done a most thorough internal review of anything to do with this and there has been nothing untoward so that any money paid would have to do with a settlement of a dispute on interpretation,” he said.The funds set aside were intended for use in “a range of regulatory and legal matters, including ones in which we would be a plaintiff”, Mr McReynolds said.Last month, the American Public Gas Association (APGA), a non-profit association of publicly-owned US natural gas distribution systems, wrote to the Senate’s agriculture committee – which oversees the CFTC – warning that “the vast majority of natural gas derivatives are traded without government oversight”.“While the CFTC monitors trading of natural gas contracts cleared through the Nymex it receives very little information regarding trading of natural gas derivatives on the Intercontinental Exchange or on the over-the-counter market where tens of thousands of trades are placed each day,” it said.Calling for the need for “position reporting” in OTC markets, it said: “Trading activities or other actions intended to distort the price reporting process cannot be detected or deterred when the government is receiving no information concerning the trading in question.”An APGA source said the organisation would be “pushing for more transparency” when the next Congress meets in January.Defenders of the current regime, which include Wall Street banks and the International Swaps and Derivatives Association, argue that requiring participants to send regulators trading reports would expose a trader’s private commercial decisions to market rivals.They lobbied strongly in favour of “lighter touch” regulation for OTC energy markets ahead of passage of the CFMA.The CFTC only has enforcement authority in OTC markets, allowing it to pursue traders in the event any wrongdoing is suspected.Asked if he believed if it was justified to have greater oversight over OTC energy markets, Mr McReynolds said: “I am not convinced that more regulation would fix the problems that [Ms] Feinstein is talking about. If you increase regulation the crooks and cowboys will still find ways to be crooks.”The ETP case also highlights increasing concern that there is insufficient oversight of physical energy markets – including inter- and intra-state pipelines.Physical markets have a close pricing relationship with OTC and on-exchange futures markets. Traders often speculate by arbitraging between physical, OTC markets and futures markets.In addition, there are concerns that reporting of prices to indices such as those run by Platts are voluntary, resulting in an incomplete picture of pricing and trading at the dozens of natural gas hubs across the US.APGA last month told the FERC that increased transparency in the natural gas markets could be achieved by making price reporting compulsory. It proposed that this be done at a central hub.“All would submit data to a single repository which would match, verify and scrub the data and then provide the resulting clean data for published indices,” APGA said.The CFTC’s inability to see trading activity on OTC markets in the same way as it can see such activity on exchanges - such as Nymex - is a source of frustration for some in the agency.That is because there is increasing interplay between energy contracts traded on markets like ICE and on Nymex – yet the regulator only receives large trader reports from Nymex and thus cannot see activity in the whole market.The CFTC has nonetheless in recent months stepped up its enforcement activities in the OTC markets.As of last month, the CFTC had filed 35 enforcement actions involving 31 companies since 2002. It obtained over $300m in civil monetary penalties in such cases.The latest case came last month, when the CFTC settled with two traders at Mirant, a US energy company, in a case alleging that they submitted false natural gas trading information to a natural gas price index.The traders were accused of submitting the false natural gas trade information to companies that calculated natural gas price indexes including Inside FERC Gas Market Report, Gas Daily, and Natural Gas Intelligence, in an attempt to skew that index at multiple natural gas delivery locations to “benefit their trading positions”, according to the CFTC.

Titular: ICE keen on keeping LCH partnership
Texto: The IntercontinentalExchange (ICE), the electronic commodities exchange, is interested in forming a clearing house partnership with LCH.Clearnet if its proposed acquisition of fellow commodities exchange the New York Board of Trade, which has its own clearing house, is completed.Jeffrey Sprecher, chairman of ICE, said his exchange was keen to maintain a relationship with LCH.Clearnet, which clears all of the trade that is conducted on ICE, including trading in its Brent and West Texas Intermediate crude futures contracts.“We have not talked in any detail about a specific structure, except to say that we think there are opportunities for both sides to explore,” Mr Sprecher told the Financial Times in an interview.One possibility is for LCH.Clearnet, the European clearing house, to clear all the ICE trades that are done by European-based customers and US investors will have their trades cleared through the New York Clearing Corp, which is owned by Nybot.Another structure could be an alliance between the two clearing houses, which would give ICE greater flexibility in launching new contracts and offering clearing services to the over-the-counter market.If ICE decided to switch all its clearing away from LCH.Clearnet, in which it is a minority shareholder, it would have to give the London-based clearing house a year’s notice.“So far there is no global clearing house structure. We have global financial markets, global commodity markets, but clearing houses have been confined to operating under one regulatory system,” said Mr Sprecher.“I think this is because regulators fear that if there is a default at a clearing house in one jurisdiction, there could a ripple effect on the other clearing houses that it is connected to.”Mr Sprecher said talks with LCH.Clearnet were still in the early stages as the Nybot take-over was not expected to be complete until next year. “LCH.Clearnet also has a number of its own issues to sort out as it looks like there is going to be a change of shareholding,” he said.Euronext, the Paris-based exchange, is in talks with LCH.Clearnet to reduce its stake to as low as 5 per cent from its existing 41.5 per cent. Mr Sprecher would not comment on whether ICE would increase its stake in LCH.Clearnet.The success of ICE’s $1bn offer for Nybot will depend on next month’s vote by member of the coffee, cocoa and sugar futures exchange, and US regulatory approval.

Titular: Blistering debut for Nymex as shares soar
Texto: Nymex Holdings, owner of the world’s largest energy exchange, on Friday recorded the best market debut by a US company in six years as its shares more than doubled on issue.The blistering debut by Nymex, which owns the New York Mercantile Exchange, has boosted the wealth of its shareholders, including many individual oil traders that trade in the exchange’s heaving pit and former traders who have retired to Florida and California.Nymex shares reached an intra-day peak of $150 a share, and its stock closed up 125 per cent at $132.99, which gave the company a market value of $11.6bn, within range of the New York Stock Exchange’s valuation of $14.8bn.The share price rise gave the 134-year-old exchange a greater market capitalisation than the $8.5bn for the Chicago Board of Trade, which is under offer from the $19bn Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Nymex’s market value is more than double that of its rival IntercontinentalExchange.Shares surged well beyond the company’s issue price of $59 and the original IPO pricing range of $48 to $52 a share.JPMorgan and Merrill Lynch were the book runners for the float.“I don’t believe it was mispriced; it was priced on industry comparables – it is just that demand was so high,” said Richard Schaeffer, chairman of Nymex.One of the biggest beneficiaries of the float is General Atlantic, the private equity group, which paid the equivalent of $20.83 a share, or $170m, for its 10 per cent stake, which is now worth $1.1bn.Michel Marks, who was chairman of Nymex when it first introduced energy contracts on to the exchange in 1978, is another big gainer from Friday’s float.Mr Marks and his family own almost 100,000 shares, making them the biggest shareholders among former traders.Nymex will have raised about $375m, pre-expenses, from the offering of about 7 per cent of its issued capital. “Wall Street is placing a lot of confidence in us,” said Mr Marks.Nymex’s appeal to investors is the potential for further exchange consolidation, as well as the exchange’s pick-up in trading volume growth following its recent link-up with the CME’s electronic trading platform Globex, which now handles most of its West Texas Intermediate benchmark oil contract.

Titular: Callout to legal sector: join us to tackle Covid-19 problems
Subtitular: Hackathon will develop answers to a range of challenges faced by business, governments and society
Texto: A global hackathon supported by the Financial Times is inviting organisations and individuals in the legal sector to develop solutions to problems created by the coronavirus pandemic.The FT Innovative Lawyers reports have over the past 15 years recognised innovators from across the global legal sector for their skills in solving complex problems for business and society. Now we are asking these innovators to help tackle some of the urgent challenges posed by Covid-19. The deadline to register as a participant or to suggest a challenge is April 26.Organised by Global Legal Hackathon (GLH), and supported by FT Innovative Lawyers, the hackathon will take place online from April 27 to May 17. It will bring together legal professionals, software developers, designers and businesspeople to develop solutions to problems identified by organisations, governments, and individuals.Organisations of any type are invited to submit challenges, which can relate to their business, industry, staff, clients, communities, their country, or the world. Participants in the hackathon will then form teams to address challenges which might range from the online functioning of courts to helping migrant workers caught in lockdown limbo.The overall objective is to harness the collective capability, energy and innovation of the world’s legal industry to support communities, governments and industries during this global emergency.A hackathon traditionally involves teams of professionals, software developers, designers and other experts working intensely over short periods of time to build prototype software solutions. The FT Innovative Lawyers-Global Legal Hackathon Challenge will seek to solve a range of legal and related challenges through technology or other means. It will be held online over three weeks.We are inviting all law firms, company legal teams, law companies, legal technology companies, public sector and non-profit organisations to get involved in one or more of the following ways:Individuals working in the legal industry, public sector and non-profit organisations, or who are studying in the law can get involved in one or both of the following ways:We welcome ideas from now for challenges from any public, private or non-profit organisation. The challenges will be published prior to the start of the hackathon on April 27 on the FTIL-GLH website here.Challenges can be submitted directly by registering online here. You will need to provide the following details:- Name and short description of the problem to be solved- Relevant background, including key potential stakeholders/beneficiaries- Scope of the challenge: for a business, organisation, government, community, industry, country, region or global remit- Your contact details- Whether you intend to be named or remain anonymous as the challenge contributorIndividual participants and teams can register to participate in the hackathon here.Once registered, participants will be able to found a project related to one of the listed challenges, or request to join another project team via the FTIL-GLH website.Global Legal Hackathon will provide participants with access to business and technical tutorials, guides, and training resources on how to develop and present solutions, and how to collaborate remotely, prior to the event.To find full conditions for participation in the hackathon, please read Global Legal Hackathon’s terms and conditions on the FTIL-GLH website.Deadline to contribute a challenge to the hackathon: April 26, 2020 via a form here.Deadline to register to participate in the hackathon: April 26, 2020 via the registration form here.The hackathon goes live: The hackathon will run from April 27 to May 17. Teams can spend any amount of time during this period to collaborate and develop their project solutions.Presentation of solutions: On or before May 17 2020, teams should submit a five minute or less video presentation of their solution, a pitch deck, and/or links to software or applications that have been developed.The chance to be showcased in the Financial Times: A selection of solutions developed during the hackathon will be showcased on FT.com in June. This will include case studies and summaries written by FT journalists and RSG Consulting.Contact detailsFor questions about the hackathon please contact RSG Consulting on +44 (0)20 7831 0300, ftresearch@rsgconsulting.com.To find full conditions for participation in the hackathon, please read Global Legal Hackathon’s terms and conditions on the FTIL-GLH website.The FT and RSG Consulting reserve the right to decide which challenges are published and which solutions are showcased in the FT.The FT reserves the right to cancel, postpone or suspend its participation in the FT Innovative Lawyers-Global Legal Hackathon Challenge at any time.

Titular: The transformation of Nymex
Texto: Executives from the New York Mercantile Exchange have been invited to the New York Stock Exchange next week, when the world’s largest energy futures exchange plans to list its shares on the big board in a $4.5bn initial public offering.Nymex’s transformation from a squabbling member-owned exchange to a potential growth stock has been dramatic and rapid.The key change has been its link-up with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange’s electronic trading system Globex, which has overtaken the heaving open-outcry pits at Nymex as the most popular place to trade the benchmark crude futures contract – West Texas Intermediate (WTI). This trend is a concern for the crude oil brokers on the Nymex floor, as well as its smaller rival the IntercontinentalExchange (ICE), which launched its electronic-only WTI contract in February and found it a key source of growth.Last week, more than 1.4m Nymex energy futures contracts were trading through Globex, representing more than 56 per cent of the total 2.5m Nymex energy futures contracts traded. The addition of Globex has boosted Nymex average daily volumes to about 500,000 contracts from an average of less than 450,000 last year.The growth in electronic trade has come at the expense of trading in the pits, Nymex shareholders say. For example, last Friday 234,852 WTI contracts were traded on Globex, compared with about 152,000 on the floor. Before Nymex energy futures started trading on Globex in October, average daily volume on the floor this year fluctuated between 250,000 and 300,000 contracts.“There is no doubt that trading has migrated from the floor to the screen,” says one Nymex shareholder, who estimated that more than one-third of Nymex floor trading had switched to the screen since the beginning of September.This has meant that traders wanting to buy and sell crude oil futures on the Nymex floor – which has been the main global stage for setting the price of oil for a third of a century – are not prepared to pay as much for the trading rights as they were a few months ago.According to Nymex, the exchange’s trading right, or access to the floor, changed hands for $650,000 on Tuesday, less than half of the record $1.35m paid in May, just before Nymex decided to abandon its own electronic trading system and link up with Globex. Those Nymex shareholders that already own trading rights, but lease them out to other traders, have also seen their monthly lease rates fall.“Not too long ago, some leases were costing $20,000 a month, now the rate is closer to $12,000,” says the Nymex shareholder. But oil traders are still prepared to pay a larger sum for one of Nymex’s 816 seats, as seats give their owners shares as well as trading rights. Currently, a seat gives the owner 90,000 Nymex shares.On Tuesday, a Nymex ownership seat sold for $5.8m, beating the previous record of $5.5m set in April. This gives an implied value for Nymex shares of $64.44, well above the expected IPO price of $48-$52 a share.The 134-year-old exchange, which traces it origins back to the Butter and Cheese Exchange of New York, plans to raise about $245m of new capital in its listing, expected on November 17. Existing shareholders who decide to sell a portion of their holdings will share about $55m based on a share offer price of $50.The strong growth in Nymex energy trading volumes is worrying for ICE, which had exploited the initial reluctance by its bigger rival to embrace electronic trading. ICE grew to capture more than half of total trading in the world’s two benchmark crude futures WTI and Brent. This share has since slipped below the 50 per cent mark, following the surge in Globex WTI trade.Nymex’s move to Globex was prompted by ICE’s early success and the influence of its 10 per cent shareholder General Atlantic, the private equity group, which is very focused on technology.Traditionally, Nymex has been wedded to the floor, as many of its top executives are former floor traders. It advocated open out-cry trading until last autumn and had opened a trading floor in London, but this closed months after inauguration due to a lack of interest.Nymex said in its third quarter earnings on Tuesday that the closure of the London trading floor cost the exchange $6m. This was one of the few blemishes on Nymex earnings, which showed a 50 per cent in-crease in net revenues to $381.5m for the nine months to September 30, while net income rose 122.8 per cent to $112.5m.

Titular: ICE warns over derivatives scrutiny
Texto: The IntercontinentalExchange on Thursday suggested that increased regulatory scrutiny of the over-the-counter derivatives market was likely to deter banks and other users from launching alternatives to its own highly-profitable trading system.The Atlanta-based group, which also operates a futures exchange, has become a focus of a growing clamour from some US lawmakers and industry groups for greater oversight of the OTC energy markets.This followed the meltdown of Amaranth, a hedge fund that lost $6bn on natural gas trades, many of which were conducted through the ICE.Jeff Sprecher, ICE chairman and chief executive, said it continued to “dialogue” with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission over the natural gas market, providing the regulator with information on large trading positions in the OTC market, where it clears trades from users in return for fees which account for half of its revenues.“We are one of the few venues in the US which provides the CFTC with this level of transparency in the OTC market,” he told analysts after ICE reported a 159.5 per cent rise in third-quarter profits to a record $43.6m.Mr Sprecher acknowledged that ICE’s high operating margins – 69 per cent in the third quarter – were likely to attract efforts by users to bypass it by developing alternative systems or products.However, he said the liquidity garnered by the ICE’s clearing system and the prospect of tighter regulation gave it “a very strong defensible position”.“We continue to work very closely with the CFTC as oversight of the OTC space is evolving,” he said. “I don’t know what appetite third-parties have to take on that challenge in the way we have.”Mr Sprecher also welcomed this week’s decision by the CFTC to rule out extending its supervision to the company’s London-based ICE Futures unit, which offers benchmark oil and gas futures under the oversight of the UK Financial Services Authority.The New York Mercantile Exchange, which offers a rival West Texas Intermediate crude oil contract regulated by the CFTC, complained earlier this year that ICE appeared to be taking advantage of a more lenient regulatory regime in the UK to gain an edge.The ICE has grown its share of benchmark crude futures – which includes the Brent contract alongside WTI – from 36 per cent at the start of the year to around 50 per cent in the third quarter.The market is evenly split with the Nymex, whose own volumes have soared after agreeing to list its floor-based contracts side-by-side on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange’s Globex electronic platform.Mr Sprecher also said members of the New York Board of Trade were expected to vote “within 12 weeks” on its planned $1bn acquisition by the ICE, which it hopes to complete in the first quarter of next year.The proposed deal would add Nybot’s agricultural commodity and financial futures contracts to the ICE complex and, crucially, its own clearing platform. LCH.Clearnet, the London-based clearing house, currently clears all of the ICE’s futures and OTC products.

Titular: Energy leads Wall Street higher at close
Texto: US stocks closed higher yesterday, led by the energy sector, with investors responding to a fresh batch of company results as the third quarter earnings season shifted up a gear.Financial services company Wachovia fell 2.16 per cent to close at $55.25, recovering slightly in late trading, after the bank reported a 13 per cent rise in third-quarter profit, but revenue came in lower than expected.Mattel shares rose 2.9 per cent to close at $21.30 after the maker of Barbie dolls said third-quarter profits came in ahead of analysts’ expectations.Energy stocks gained across the board as oil, natural gas and metal prices surged, pushing shares of their producers higher. Exxon Mobil was up 2.1 per cent or $1.43 at $69.83. American Depository Receipts of BP rose 2.36 per cent or $1.56 to finish at $67.53.The S&P 500 index was up 0.25 per cent, or 3.44 points, at 1,369.06. The Nasdaq Composite was up 0.28 per cent, or 6.55 points, at 2,363.84 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose by 20.09 points, or 0.17 per cent, to 11,980.60, another closing high.Many analysts expect the Dow to breach the 12,000 mark this week, having closed at an all-time high in seven of the past 10 sessions.The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies advanced 0.82 per cent or 6.28 points to 768.93 at the close.There was limited reaction to a speech by Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, at the annual meeting of the American Bankers Association.He steered clear of commenting on the wider economy and limited his remarks to the state of bank regulation.LaBranche, the New York Stock Exchange’s largest market maker, said profits had fallen in the third quarter because of rising margin interest expenses. Shares in LaBranche sank by17.92 per cent to close at $9.07 on the news.Charles Schwab, the nation’s largest discount brokerage, said quarterly profits were up 29 per cent on last year but overall revenue fell short of expectations. The stock fell 46 cents, or 2.62 per cent, to $17.10.Alcoa shares rose 2.6 per cent to $27.32 as the stock recovered some of the value lost last week, when the company reported third-quarter profits that missed analysts’ forecasts.Shares in JLG Industries soared 32.82 per cent, or by $6.71, to $27.56 after Oshkosh Truck said it would acquire the company for $3.2bn.William McGuire, UnitedHealth Group chairman and chief executive officer, resigned from the company early on Monday after an investigation into stock options. Shares were down 2.48 per cent at $47.54 at the close.Shares in the Intercontinental Exchange fell 6.8 per cent, or $5.67, to $77.30 after reports the exchange was being looked at by authorities in relation to the recent steep trading losses at hedge fund Amaranth.

Titular: Wall Street mixed as oil prices climb
Texto: A morning rally on Wall Street fizzled out on Monday as oil prices climbed and investors became cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve’s meeting on interest rate policy on Wednesday.Energy stocks ticked higher after BP announced production at its Thunder Horse rig in the Gulf of Mexico would be delayed until 2008, and Iran warned against sanctions over its nuclear programme. Schlumberger gained 4.6 per cent to $58.84, and ExxonMobil rose 2.2 per cent to $66.08.Steelmaker Nucor added 4.3 per cent to $48.77, and copper miner Phelps Dodge rose 3 per cent to $86.21.First Data, provider of electronic payment systems, sank 7.6 per cent to $41.25 after Standard & Poors cut its rating on the company’s debt from A+ to A.Freescale Semiconductor jumped 5.7 per cent to $39.26 on news that the chipmaker would be bought for $17.6bn by a private equity consortium led by the Blackstone Group.Symbol Technologies, a maker of barcode scanners and mobile computers, soared 15.4 per cent to $14.67 on reports that it was putting itself up for sale.Applied Materials, a manufacturer of chipmaking equipment, rose 3.4 per cent to a four-month high of $17.78 after it announced plans to buy back up to $5bn of its own stock over the next three years.Not all technology stocks were as strong however. Ebay fell 3.6 per cent to $26.84, and Sun Microsystems shed 3 per cent to $5.12.At the close, the S&P 500 was up 0.1 per cent, or 1.31 points, at 1,321.18, while the Nasdaq Composite was flat, up 0.16 points, at 2,235.75. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.1 per cent, or 5.77 points, at 11,555.00.The Federal Reserve’s Open Market Committee meets on Wednesday and is widely expected to keep rates unchanged.“Confidence seems to be growing that the Fed will pull off a soft landing,” said Alfred Goldman, chief market strategist at AG Edwards.Consumer cyclical stocks came under pressure. Home improvement retailer Home Depot sank 1.7 per cent to $36.58 after Credit Suisse cut its rating on the stock from “outperform” to “neutral”, saying a weakening housing market could lead to earnings shortfalls.Ford Motor continued to slump after it announced steep cost-cutting measures on Friday. The carmaker dropped 2.5 per cent to $7.82.Intercontinental Exchange gained 2.4 per cent to $76.15, after it was upgraded from “neutral” to “buy” by Bank of America, which cited the exchange’s recent announcement that it would buy the New York Board of Trade. Nasdaq also ticked higher, adding 5.2 per cent to $30.85.Rail stocks pushed higher. Norfolk Southern gained 4.1 per cent to $44.80, and Burlington Northern Santa Fe added 1.9 per cent to $71.15.

Titular: ICE and Nybot in $1bn deal
Texto: The managements of Intercontinental Exchange and the New York Board of Trade – the latest exchanges to commit themselves to tying the knot – have been doing their best to sell the merits of their $1bn merger.The merger would combine a listed electronic energy exchange with a member-owned agricultural commodity and financial futures exchange.But the deal is far from concluded, as the exchanges navigate the regulatory and clearing house issues that the deal throws up, as well as warding off a rival bid.“We were two incomplete exchanges, but now we are a complete exchange just like the CME (Chicago Mercantile Exchange),” Charles Falk, president and chief executive officer of Nybot told reporters and analysts on Friday.“We have the clearing house, but not the electronic platform. ICE have the electronic platform, but not the clearing house, so combining the two makes a lot of sense,” said Mr Falk.Traders said the key attraction of ICE’s purchase of Nybot, through $400m in cash and the issue of equity that equates to 15 per cent of its stock, was Nybot’s own clearing house, the New York Clearing Corporation rather than Nybot’s soft commodities such as coffee, cocoa, sugar, cotton and orange juice and its financial futures business.This will give the Atlanta-based electronic commodities exchange the flexibility it wants to compete with its bigger rival the New York Mercantile Exchange, which is planning its initial public offering for the end of the year.But it puts into question ICE’s relationship with LCH.Clearnet, the London-based clearing house, that clears all of ICE’s futures including Brent crude oil, and derivatives that are traded through ICE’s over-the-counter market.Jeffrey Sprecher, ICE chairman, said most of the $50m in synergy savings from the deal will come from the $40m a year it pays in clearing fees to third parties. ICE will also have to give 12 months notice to LCH-Clearnet if it wants to move its business.“LCH-Clearnet has been a good partner. They cleared our products when nobody else would, and we would like to continue the relationship with them, but we have to sit down and talk first,” said Mr Sprecher.With ICE potentially having its own clearing house, it is unclear who will ultimately regulate it. ICE Futures, a unit of the Atlantic-based group, is regulated by the Financial Services Authority, because the group’s futures arm in based in London.However, ICE’s grab of more than a third of futures trading in the key US crude oil futures benchmark West Texas Intermediate, has prompted a review of futures exchange regulation.Mr Sprecher said on Friday that ICE will be accountable to both Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the FSA.The deal includes a $37m break-up fee, which would be paid in the event that Nybot accepts a higher bid from a rival exchange.`Nymex, which is also Nybot’s landlord, is understood to be interested in acquiring its neighbour, and the Chicago Board of Trade has also courted the 136-year exchange.“When you are involved in a $1bn transaction, $37m is petty cash,” said one trader from a rival exchange.The deal also depends on obtaining a two-thirds majority from Nybot’s 967 seat-owners, many of whom earn their livelihood from the trading floor.Mr Falk said there was no plan to close the floor. Instead the combined exchange would follow the route of the CBOT and Chicago Mercantile Exchange, and operate with the floor open at the same time as the electronic system is live.

Titular: ICE to buy Nybot for $1bn
Texto: The IntercontinentalExchange on Thursday sealed a $1bn agreement to acquire the member-owned New York Board of Trade, heralding another industry push into hybrid electronic and floor-based derivative trading.The planned combination of the two US exchanges continues the flurry of consolidation, alliances and flotations which have transformed the landscape of global financial exchanges over the past two years.Nybot, whose members trade soft commodities such as coffee, cocoa, sugar, cotton and orange juice, had been courted by several parties including the Chicago Board of Trade and financial buyers.Its decision to pursue a trade sale rather than a public offering could also increase pressure on the industry leaders to intensify the merry-go-round of merger talks already taking place in the financial exchange sector.The Atlanta-based ICE, which listed last November, was courted by the far larger Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The CME baulked at the potential price and has since elected to focus on organic growth and revenue-generating alliances with Reuters and the New York Mercantile Exchange, itself a prospective candidate for an initial public offering.The ICE was an early pioneer in the shift to all-electronic trading, closing its trading floor in a move that highlights the manner in which screen-based execution has widened the global customer base for exchanges.However, the Nybot’s trading floor would be retained under the proposed deal - a hybrid structure adopted by the three main Chicago exchanges and the New York Stock Exchange aimed at targeting traders’ preference for face-to-face execution of more complex transactions.The ICE said it expected $50m in annualised synergies from the deal to be accretive within 12-18 months, providing crucial liquidity in its fierce battle with Nymex for supremacy in the energy derivatives market.The Nymex has allied with the CME, which is hosting the New York group’s core energy products on its electronic platform, side-by-side with floor-based platform.For the ICE, the acquisition would also diversify a product base of exchange-based energy futures and fees from executing deals in the far larger over-the-counter market. Nybot would also bring its control of the New York Clearing Corporation, lessening the ICE’s reliance on outsourcing services to the London-based LCH.Clearnet.The ICE said it expected “clearing synergies” from the deal, noting that its customers paid $36m in clearing fees to the third-party provider over the past 12 months.The success of the ICE in capturing market share from the Nymex in the energy market has fuelled a doubling in its stock price since the November listing, valuing the group at $3.66bn.However, the share price is a quarter below its peak, reflecting pressure on margins as well as the froth in the market created by the takeover battle for Euronext, the European stock and futures exchange being pursued by the NYSE and Deutsche Borse.The ICE is offering 10.297m of its own common shares and $400m in cash for the Nybot, which would become a wholly-owned subsidiary. About 700 people, either commodity traders or former traders on the exchange, own the Nybot’s 967 seats, which represent the equity of the exchange.

Titular: Nybot poised to take ICE’s $1bn takeover offer
Texto: Directors of the New York Board of Trade were poised on Wednesday to accept a takeover offer of about $1bn from fellow commodity exchange, IntercontinentalExchange (ICE), in the latest phase of consolidation among stock and futures exchanges.The proposed sale of Nybot – where coffee, cocoa, sugar, cotton and orange juice trading takes place – comes as commodity exchanges have seen their values soar in the past 18 months on the back of both record trading volumes and commodity prices. ICE shares have risen 150 per cent from their $26 issue price last November.However, it is thought Nybot favours a trade sale over an IPO because it is far smaller than its peers, which include Atlanta-based ICE – where oil, gas and their derivatives are traded – Chicago Board of Trade, Chicago Mercantile Exchange and neighbour the New York Mercantile Exchange (Nymex), which itself is planning an IPO – worth about $4bn-$5bn – by the end of the year.The offer is understood to include a mixture of cash and ICE shares. This will create a tidy windfall for the 124-year exchange’s equity owners. About 700 people, either commodity traders or former traders on the exchange, own Nybot’s 967 seats, which represent the equity of the exchange.It is understood that the offer will also include some commitment to keeping the Nybot trading floor open for a certain length of time. ICE, which bought the London-based International Petroleum Exchange, now ICE Futures, in 2001, became fully electronic last year. Nybot is one of the few major commodity exchanges not to have an electronic trading strategy.The main attraction for ICE, which is the home of Brent crude trading, is the prospect of having its own clearing house, rather than the diversification into agricultural commodities. At present, ICE has to clear all its futures trading through the London-based LCH.Clearnet.Nybot owns New York Clearing Corporation. One person close to ICE said the exchange wants to participate more in clearing services. An exchange with its own clearing house has greater flexibility in launching new contracts, which are becoming more frequent as competition intensifies between exchanges.If Nybot management does opt to go with ICE, it may have to look for a new home.At present, Nybot operates from the same building, the World Financial Center, as Nymex, a rival to ICE and owner of the building. One person familiar with the issue said that there is a clause in the lease agreement that prohibits Nybot to trade competing products.

Titular: Nymex plans $250m IPO on NYSE
Texto: The New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest US physical commodities exchange, on Monday filed with regulators to sell up to $250m in an initial public offering of common stock on the New York Stock Exchange.It comes as competition in the US securities exchange arena continues to mount, with a host of exchanges, including the NYSE itself, commodities markets such as the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Chicago Board of Trade and the Intercontinental Exchange, Nymex’s leading rival in the energy trading market, opting to go public in recent times.The also coincides with a period during which soaring trading volumes for oil and gas futures, such as those traded on the Nymex, on the back of rising geopolitical tension, have pushed energy prices to record highs.The Nymex, which had previously signalled its intention to float this year, said in a registration statement with the US Securities and Exchange Commission that JPMorgan and Merrill Lynch would act as lead underwriters for the offering.The filing did not state exactly how many shares the company planned to offer, or their price. Those details can be expected in updates over the coming weeks.The $250m valuation for the IPO was estimated solely for calculating the registration fee, the filing said. Often, the eventual price terms of an IPO offer differ substantially from the valuation in the first registration.Nymex Holdings is the parent company of Nymex, on which customers trade primarily energy futures and options contracts. It also owns Comex, which trades metals futures and options contracts.Nymex said in the filing that it is the largest physical commodity-based futures exchange and clearing house in the world, and the third-largest futures exchange in the US, as measured by 2005 contract volume.“Increased market acceptance and awareness of derivatives, increased price volatility in key commodities, technology advances and reduced regulatory barriers offer significant opportunities for expanding derivative markets,” Nymex said in the filing.Nymex will not receive any proceeds from the sale of shares of common stock by the selling holders.General Atlantic, which owns 10 per cent of the company’s common stock, is the largest single owner of the Nymex. General Atlantic is restricted to a so-called lock-up period and will not be allowed to sell all of its shares in the IPO.The company plans to list its common stock on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol NMX.In May, Nymex cut its board by 25 members to 15 and elected a new chairman, clearing an important hurdle to the IPO.Nymex is locked in a battle for market share with its smaller rival the InterContinental exchange, which earlier this year launched an electronic version of Nymex’s flagship West Texas Intermediate crude contract.

Titular: Wall Street lower after rollercoaster week
Texto: Wall Street ended the week mixed after exceptional volatility which saw sell-offs on Monday and Tuesday that pulled the S&P 500 down 2.6 per cent, and an equally spectacular rally on Thursday.Investors were wary of financial stocks and healthcare, but warmed to some consumer stocks and large-cap industrial plays such as Caterpillar and Boeing.Investment banks slumped early in the week as strong earnings vied with downbeat outlooks from the leading brokerages. Lehman Brothers and Goldman Sachs fell despite reporting continued high profits, as they warned of potential headwinds in the coming months.At one stage they had shed 11 per cent and 8.7 per cent respectively.On Thursday, market sentiment grew more sanguine, and investors greeted results from Bear Stearns more favourably, pulling the banks? shares back from their lows. Bear Stearns shed 3.6 per cent at $131.44. and Lehman Brothers fell 3.4 per cent at $63.35, while Goldman Sachs was off 3.9 per cent to $144.00.Exchange stocks stayed in focus as speculation surrounded the question of whether US regulation would apply to European companies listed on an exchange tied to a US exchange. After intense volatility, Nasdaq was off 2.1 per cent for the week at $26.83, while IntercontinentalExchange fell 0.5 per cent to $50.59 and NYSE Group shed 3.6 per cent to $55.08.Thursday?s were the best gains by leading indices in years. The S&P 500 had its best day since October 2003, and the Nasdaq Composite - off 3.3 per cent for the week at one point - enjoyed its best day since March 2004.At the close on Friday, the S&P 500 was down 0.4 per cent or 4.62 points at 1,251.54, down 0.1 per cent for the week.The Nasdaq on Friday shed 0.7 per cent or 14.20 points, leaving it down 0.2 per cent for the week at 2,129.95. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was flat down 0.64 points to 11,014.55, a gain of 1.1 per cent for the week.Jim Paulsen, chief investment strategist at Wells Capital Management, attributed the large dip in the markets to an absence of news about the health of the economy.?The problem was there was no real fundamental data. The markets were trading on momentum,? he said.?Last week we were looking for a bottom; we did the same again this week, and it looks like we found one. I think we?re crawling back to a more normal market where we can go back to trading on fundamentals rather than [on] momentum.?VeraSun Energy, an ethanol producer, had a strong debut. It rose more than 30 per cent on Wednesday, its first day of trading, only to slide back and end the week up 9.8 per cent at $25.25.Capital goods stocks were strong. Caterpillar added 4.5 per cent to $70.55 and Boeing gained 6.3 per cent to $85.54, after a broker upgrade and orders for its Dreamliner aircraft.Consumer cyclicals posted some of the strongest gains. Harley Davidson leapt 8.1 per cent to $53.05 after an analyst report showed strong sales and bullish forecasts from dealers.Circuit City rose 4.2 per cent to $29.48 after announcing it would pay a dividend.Technology stocks had a mixed week. Intel gained 6.6 per cent to $18.30 on an upgrade from Goldman Sachs. Broadcom added 9.6 per cent to $32.15, and Hewlett-Packard rose 10.4 per cent to $33.04. But other techs fared less well. Jabil Circuit was the worst performer of the week, losing 22.9 per cent to $26.26. The electronics manufacturer cut earnings estimates for the third quarter due to production delays and labour costs.Managed health stocks took a turn for the worse as the sector provided three of the 10 worst performers in the S&P 500. Aetna shed 5.8 per cent to $39.23, Coventry dropped 7.2 per cent to $51.07, and Tenet Healthcare fell 5 per cent to $7.41.Stock options investigations helped push down more companies. Comverse Technologies announced it would delay filing its quarterly report due to the ongoing review of its stock options grants. Shares fell 14.7 per cent to $20.11. Monster Worldwide fell 2 per cent to $41.17 after it said independent directors were investigating the company?s stock options programme.Oil services stocks were sluggish. Schlumberger fell 1.6 per cent to $58.25 and BJ Services fell 1 per cent to $35.72.

Titular: Gillian Tett: The battle over cyberspace regulation
Texto: When the annals of the Great American and European Exchange Wars are written one day, the saga of ICE will deserve a chapter of its own.“ICE what?” you might ask. For unless you happen to be an energy trader, or live in the US state of Georgia, the workings of ICE – an Atlanta electronic platform also called the Intercontinental Exchange – are not well known.But in recent weeks, ICE has been quietly engaged in a fight that makes the European ambitions of the New York Stock Exchange or Nasdaq seem almost outdated. Indeed, this battle is so red hot that it has prompted the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, a US regulator, to hold a hearing starting on June 27 that traders around the world would do well to follow.For what the CFTC will be discussing is whether it is time to redefine the concept of a “US” exchange. Behind that abstract definitional issue lies a second, more explosive, question: should the US regulatory authorities start flexing their muscles over markets outside the US, such as an energy trading platform that ICE runs in London? Until recently, the business of trading oil futures in America was dominated by one main exchange: the New York Mercantile Exchange (Nymex), a doughty 134-year old institution, which famously uses open outcry. But six years ago, a group of investment banks and energy companies created ICE as an electronic energy exchange. In 2001, ICE acquired in the UK the International Petroleum Exchange, which is best known for hosting trade in Brent crude oil futures, the European benchmark.In February, ICE took a stunningly cheeky step: it used its electronic platform to launch its own version of the West Texas Intermediate Crude contract, the US benchmark and a core Nymex product. Even cheekier is that ICE’s WTI prices are settled on Nymex WTI settlement prices, an issue that Nymex tried to protect through the courts, when it made a legal claim that its prices were a trademark and therefore could not be copied by a rival exchange. Nymex lost that battle.Technically, this platform was based in London, at the old IPE, which is now called ICE Futures. Consequently, it fell under the orbit of UK regulators, who have a famously lighter touch than their US counterparts. But because ICE is electronic in nature, its WTI contracts could be immediately accessed by any hedge fund sitting in New York – or Nevada. And these funds have flocked to ICE: these days about a quarter of all WTI futures trades take place in cyberspace via this London platform, rather than in the Nymex pits.Unsurprisingly, Nymex is furious. And in time honoured fashion, it has turned to the regulators for help, claiming that ICE is using “regulatory arbitrage” to win business. As ICE is servicing US customers with a US product – and its headquarters sit in an Atlanta business park – Nymex thinks it should be redefined as a “US” exchange. That could then bring it under US regulatory control, irrespective of the London address.So who will win the fight? Right now, it is unclear. The CFTC has a history of being a relatively level-headed organisation. Consequently, some observers in London hope the furore will quickly melt away. But others fear it might not. After all, there is a distinctly protectionist whiff in Washington these days. And Nymex has impressive lobbying power: by a happy coincidence, the chief executive officer of Nymex is the former chairman of none other than the CFTC.Moreover, even if Washington regulators decide against planting a flag in London, the implications of this debate will not disappear. What the ICE tale shows is just how hard it is to define where an exchange is really based in this age of electronic trading. And the current wave of exchange mergers will make this task even harder in the future.No wonder Sir Callum McCarthy, chairman of the UK’s Financial Services Authority, has been issuing dark warnings in recent days about the implications of a US exchange seeking to purchase the London Stock Exchange. And no wonder many investors and banks quietly admit they want to keep new areas of the financial world, such as credit derivatives, in the over-the-counter space, and thus away from regulated exchanges altogether. Given all the heat being generated by ICE, who can blame them?

Titular: Wall Street slides ahead of key inflation data
Texto: US markets ended sharply lower on Monday, extending the sell-off of last week that drove the Dow Jones Industrial Average to its lowest level in four months.Lehman Brothers was unable to inspire investors in spite of better-than-expected results, dragging exchange stocks lower, while stock options investigations depressed Comverse Technologies and Monster Worldwide.Lehman Brothers, the investment bank, fell 5.5 per cent to $62.01 in spite of reporting stronger-than-expected second quarter results. Analysts noted that earnings had dipped from the first quarter, sparking fears that brokerage earnings had run out of steam.The rout in brokerages fed through to the exchange sector. NYSE Group tumbled 7.9 per cent to $52.62 and Nasdaq fell 7.7 per cent to $25.29. Intercontinental Exchange was off 3.6 per cent to $49.00.At the close, the S&P 500 was down 1.3 per cent, or 15.90 points, at 1,236.40, while the Nasdaq Composite was down 2.1 per cent, or 43.74 points, at 2,091.32. The Nasdaq Composite is now down more than 5 per cent this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.9 per cent, or 99.34 points, to 10,792.58.The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies was down 2.5 per cent, dipping below 700. Since its peak in May, it has shed 11.8 per cent, whereas the Russell Top 50 Index of the largest companies in the US has lost only 4.5 per cent as large-caps weather the sell-off better than small caps.Recruitment company and advertiser Monster Worldwide sank 8.1 per cent to $38.60, its worst day since April 2005. The company said a committee of independent directors was investigating its stock options grants.The fallout from an investigation into stock options grants also dragged Comverse Technologies down 13.1 per cent to $20.48 after it said it would miss a deadline for filing quarterly earnings.Markets were pre­occupied by crucial May inflation figures expected over the next two days. These could decide whether the Federal Reserve increases US interest rates later this month.“I think people are today positioning themselves with some nervousness,” said Marc Pado, chief market strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald. “The market is bracing itself for a big week on the economic front. This week is probably going to convince people of what the Fed is going to do. In my opinion, it seems like everyone is bracing for a real negative shock on the inflation front.”Walt Disney was a big drag on the Dow, falling 1.5 per cent to $28.90 after Citigroup downgraded it from “buy” to “hold”.Adobe was the best performer in the S&P 500, gaining 3 per cent to $28.84 on an analyst upgrade.Qualcomm dropped 5.2 per cent to $41.19 after announcing it had filed a complaint for copyright infringement against Nokia.

Titular: Nymex relents and allows electronic trade
Texto: For 23 years the price of oil has largely been determined on the trading floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the world’s largest commodity exchange. But that may be about to change from Monday.Until four months ago, Nymex was refusing to join the trend of other commodity, equity and financial derivative exchanges, where trading floors have closed as exchanges realised that a global network of electronic trading screens was able to generate more volume.When Nymex launched the West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures contract in 1983, it succeeded in replacing the oil price setting mechanism of the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and in turn made consuming countries the oil price setters.Now that oil is a more important financial asset to the investment community, which prefers to trade electronically, Nymex has been forced to change tack.Nymex executives had said that its customers preferred open outcry. However, when its smaller but faster-growing rival IntercontinentalExchange launched an electronic WTI contract in February and grabbed about a third of WTI trade – Nymex’s biggest single market – the New York-based exchange announced plans for electronic trading during the opening hours of its heaving pits.The electronic launch, which started yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange’s Globex system, is likely to cause casualties. About 150 of the 800 brokers and traders on the Nymex floor are execution-only brokers, whose functions can be transferred to screens most easily.The introduction of electronic trading is not the only thing that has upset traders. Nymex’s planned listing by the end of the year is likely to be a cash bonanza for the exchange’s 816 seat owners, who own 90 per cent of its equity, having collectively sold 10 per cent of their interest to General Atlantic, the private equity group, this year.Each seat is worth almost $5m, giving Nymex a pre-listing value of about $4bn. Two-thirds of the seats are owned by former traders who lease their seats to current traders, which means that most of the people working on the Nymex floor do not hold equity in the exchange.The launch is likely to result in electronic trade becoming the preferred way to trade oil, if the CME is any guide.In 2000, electronic trade accounted for 15 per cent of its volumes: last year it was 70 per cent.

Titular: Wall Street falls as downgrades hit confidence
Texto: Wall Street continued to fall on Tuesday, extending losses for a second day. Analyst downgrades also pushed mortgage groups Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac lower while a fall in metals prices put pressure on mining stocks.NYSE Group sank 4.7 per cent to $60.50 after Jacques Chirac, French president, said he favoured a merger between Euronext and Deutsche Börse. NYSE last week agreed to buy the Paris exchange for $10.2bn, but Deutsche Börse said it would continue its own attempts to tie up with Euronext.Intercontinental Exchange fell 2.4 per cent to $50.36 and Nasdaq dropped 3.4 per cent to $28.11.“This market has a general malaise about it,” said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Co, who believes investors are now watching technical trends in the market for danger signals – such as the S&P 500 slipping below 1,260. “Unfortunately, what happens on a day like today is there are folks who don’t look at the fundamentals, but at the technicals,” said Mr Hogan, who believes such trading feeds on itself.At the close, the S&P 500 was down 0.1 per cent, or 1.44 points, at 1,263.85 while the Nasdaq Composite was down 0.3 per cent, or 6.84 points, at 2,162.78.The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.4 per cent, or 46.58 points, at 11,002.14, at one point dipping below 11,000.Mining stocks were hit as gold and copper both fell. Phelps Dodge shed 1.1 per cent to $82.25 and Alcoa dropped 2.2 per cent to $30.69.A downgrade from Credit Suisse sent Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac lower. Fannie Mae lost 1.9 per cent to $49.08, while Freddie Mac lost 3.3 per cent to $58.11. Fannie Mae recently paid a $400m fine to regulators after an investigation into its accounting practices.Homebuilders were also bruised by analyst downgrades. Wachovia cut Pulte, DR Horton and Lennar from “outperform” to “market perform”. Pulte fell 5.5 per cent to $28.11, while DR Horton dropped 5.6 per cent to $23.41, and Lennar fell 3.2 per cent to $45.00.Google rose 4.2 per cent to $389.99 as the internet search company announced that it would introduce online spreadsheet software, potentially offering a free alternative to Microsoft’s Excel.Telecommunications groups were the best performers in the S&P 500.Sprint and Qwest moved higher as the American Civil Liberties Union asked regulators to block the proposed merger of rivals AT&T and BellSouth, pending an investigation into reports the companies inappropriately gave customer calling records to the National Security Agency.Sprint added 3.1 per cent to $21.72, while Qwest jumped 3.1 per cent to $7.63.General Motors dipped 3.1 per cent to $25.25 as Rick Wagoner, chief executive, warned that rising commodity prices would make cost cutting more difficult

Titular: ICE announces plans for first coal futures
Texto: The IntercontinentalExchange on Wednesday announced plans to launch its first coal futures in a move that highlights rising global demand and the growing importance of banks and hedge funds in the energy market.The all-electronic exchange already lists utility-based contracts, including those based on UK natural gas and pan-European emissions, through its ICE Futures unit in London.It aims to tap into the appetite for risk-management and speculative trading tools from producers and end users such as utilities and steel companies, which rely primarily on an expanding array of over the counter products.“Coal is the next step to complete the offering to the utilities’ market,” said Fredrik Voss, head of market development at ICE Futures.The launch, which is subject to regulatory approval, comes weeks after the European Energy Exchange in Leipzig started the region’s first energy futures. The ICE offering is similar to that of its rival, with contracts based on the key coal route of exports from Richards Bay in South Africa to Rotterdam in the Netherlands.The coal market has evolved in recent years from one dominated by long-term bilateral trades, predominantly involving physical delivery, to a more fluid environment underpinned by a market growing at about 1bn tonnes a year.Clean-burning coal has captured a greater share of the power-generation market, spurred by technological advances and the rise of oil and natural-gas prices.“There are more and more short-term spot trades,” said Mr Voss.The global OTC market for coal has climbed from 100m tonnes in 2001 to 700m tones last year in Europe, by far the largest regional segment. Stephen Doyle, head of Doyle Trading Consultants in Denver, estimates this could top 1bn tonnes by 2007.The US OTC market is below the peak hit before the collapse of Enron drove many participants away, but could reach 300m tonnes this year as more financial players spur activity.Mr Voss did not rule out the launch of a US contract. The New York Mercantile Exchange – which is engaged in a fierce battle with the ICE in the oil-futures market – launched its first US coal futures in 2001, but is primarily used as a clearing house for “lookalike” products that have attracted increasing interest from financial traders.“We’ve seen at least five of the major banks enter the market,” said Stephen Nesis, head of the coal desk at Evolution Markets, one of the largest US coal brokers. “Now we are seeing the hedge funds come in.”Mr Nesis said the clearing function had made the market more attractive – about 30 per cent of its business is done through the Nymex – and both the ICE and the EEE hope to expand the existing European market by offering cleared products.“It becomes accessible to those who cannot, or will not, access the OTC space,” said Mr Voss. “We believe we will add new user groups.”Coal prices have historically lacked the volatility seen in other energy sectors, but the combination of tighter global supplies and deregulation of the power markets has seen this increase in recent years.Power generators, industrial users and coal producers still tend to use the expanding OTC market to hedge physical positions, while traders estimate that half of the dealing by financial institutions is for speculation and market-making.

Titular: Wall Street rallies as investors warm to data
Texto: Wall Street finished the week higher as investors chose to read economic data in a largely positive light while crude prices picked up, buoying energy stocks.A steep sell-off in European bourses and in Asia rattled US investors on Monday, but the markets regained their composure later in the week. Investors also paid close attention to the continuing transatlantic flirtation between financial exchanges, and two stock market debuts.Economic data released during the week were mostly interpreted as positive in that they would ease the pressure on the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Sales of durable goods fell more than was expected in April, and gross domestic product growth was more sluggish than had been forecast. However, a rise in core inflation figures on Friday along with greater-than-expected new home sales served as a reminder that inflationary threats had not yet been quelled.“It was a pretty rough week,” said Peter Cardillo, chief equity analyst with SW Bach. “But we’re looking at a market that is beginning to stabilise. I think investor confidence is starting to return.”At the close, the S&P 500 had gained 0.6 per cent, or 7.28 points, up 1 per cent for the week at 1,280.16. The Nasdaq Composite rose 0.6 per cent, or 12.13 points, at 2,210.37, a gain of 0.8 per cent for the week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.6 per cent, or 67.56 points, to 11,278.61, a gain of 1.2 per cent for the week.Commodities gave investors food for thought as oil and copper rose but gold dropped. Nymex crude gained more than 4 per cent during the week, supporting oil stocks. Oil-field services stocks benefited the most. BJ Services jumped 6.4 per cent to $35.33, and Baker Hughes added 7.1 per cent to $84.42. Copper producer Phelps Dodge jumped 6.3 per cent to $88.26.The acquisition battles in the exchange sector continued as NYSE Group made a $10.2bn offer for Euronext. A sell-off that hit exchange stocks across the world during the week brought NYSE down 4.8 per cent to $61.40, below the price at which it floated in March.Nasdaq, which has recently been building a stake in the London Stock Exchange, was especially volatile, falling 13 per cent by midweek, only to add 10 per cent over Thursday and Friday. It is now down 3.4 per cent to $31.91. Nasdaq has a lower market capitalisation than LSE and the 25 per cent stake it owns in the London exchange constitutes 38 per cent of its own market value.InterContinental Exchange, which includes London’s International Petroleum Exchange, fared the worst, plunging 18 per cent to $57.44.Carmakers were the best performers in the S&P, with the S&P Autos and Components index gaining 5.3 per cent during the week.The sector was led higher by General Motors. Both Merrill Lynch and Prudential upgraded the stock during the week, while the company said it was pleased with the uptake by its employees of buy-out offers designed to cut costs. GM was up 13.8 per cent at $28.08.GM is now trading at its highest level since October 2005.A tie-up between Yahoo and Ebay sent both stocks soaring. Under the terms of the multi-year deal, Yahoo will provide advertising for Ebay, while Yahoo will promote Ebay’s Pay-Pal payment system. Ebay jumped 15.2 per cent to $34.20 while Yahoo gained 11.8 per cent to $33.02.Two stocks made their debut during the week. Vonage, the internet telephony provider, started trading on Wednesday and fell 12.7 per cent in one day, the worst debut for any initial public offering this year. It is down 23.4 per cent at $13.02 for the week.MasterCard followed a day later but proved more popular, jumping 18 per cent in its first day, and was up 15.2 per cent for the week at $44.93.Semi-conductors fared the worst, with chipmakers’ shares the four largest fallers for the week.National Semiconductor was downgraded by Piper Jaffray, and American Technology Research, pushing shares down 7.3 per cent to $25.60.Wal-Mart finished the week up 4.9 per cent to $49.65. The retailer was boosted by the sale of its Korean holdings and a brokerage upgrade from Bank of America.

Titular: Wall St higher as investors try another rally
Texto: Wall Street finished higher on Wednesday as investors attempted another rally after being foiled by Tuesday?s late sell-off.Traders were left with conflicting data to puzzle over. An unexpectedly big drop in durable goods orders for April provided some relief for the market?s fears of higher interest rates. Data on new home sales were stronger than expected.?Durables are too volatile for it to be much of an influence,? said Marc Pado, chief market strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald. ?I think the housing number is more important since even though there was a revision, that pace of new home sales is still very healthy, which is reassuring.?At the close, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.2 per cent, or 18.97 points, at 11,117.32. The broader-based S&P 500 was up 0.2 per cent, or 1.99 points, at 1,258.57, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.5 per cent, or 10.41 points, to 2,169.17.Nymex crude fell $1.90 to $69.86, dragging down ConocoPhillips 2.5 per cent to $61.15, and Chevron down 0.9 per cent to $57.60.?There was a lot of volatility, and all of a sudden, crude just tumbled,? said Mr Pado.Gold dropped 4.3 per cent, denting mining stocks with Barrick Gold losing 3.4 per cent to $30.06, and Newmont Mining down 3.2 per cent to $49.53.Trading was, however, dominated by the poor market debut for Vonage, the internet telephony provider, after its initial public offering was priced on Tuesday night. Volume in the stock was close to double that of any other on the New York Stock Exchange. By the close, it was down 12.7 per cent at $14.85.Mastercard was still scheduled to make its stock market debut on Thursday in what would be the biggest US initial public offering in two years.Technology stocks were led higher by Microsoft, which gained 3.1 per cent to $23.50. The company has suffered a sharp sell-off in recent weeks, after announcements that it would delay the launch of its new Vista operating system and would spend more on internal investment.General Motors, the stricken carmaker, also continued its recent recovery, surging 8.3 per cent to $26.51, the biggest gainer on the Dow. Merrill Lynch upgraded the stock from ?neutral? to ?buy?.The weak durable goods order might have eased interest rate fears, but it made investors uncomfortable over Boeing which lost 3.3 per cent to $82.38.Medtronic, the medical devices manufacturer, was up 4.6 per cent at $50.17, thanks to an earnings report.Selling of exchange stocks continued, with the worst fall suffered by the InterContinental Exchange, which dropped 7.9 per cent to $53.87. NYSE Group was down 5.4 per cent at $56.80.

Titular: Nymex energy futures to trade on CME
Texto: The board of the New York Mercantile Exchange has voted to launch trading of its energy futures contracts on the electronic trading platform of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on June 11.The move comes amid mounting competition in the US energy and commodities trading market from its smaller rival the Intercontinental Exchange (ICE).Under the deal, the CME, the largest US futures exchange, will become the sole provider of electronic trading services for Nymex energy derivatives – Nymex is the largest US energy exchange.Electronic trading, on the CME’s Globex 24-hour electronic platform, will run alongside pit trading at the Nymex, a system known as side-by-side trading.Trading of the energy futures will be conducted on the CME’s Globex 24-hour electronic platform.In the initial phase of the launch, Nymex, which is preparing for an initial public offering, said it would offer cash-settled energy futures contracts for all listed months.Nymex miNY futures contracts will also start trading on CME Globex on June 11.For the second phase of the launch, Nymex said it would offer physically delivered energy futures contracts, no later than six months from the launch.The deal will give Nymex the technology to handle expanding electronic trading activity. The CME gains exposure to the increasingly important energy sector.The Nymex is battling for market share with the ICE, which went public last year.ICE this week reported a sharp rise in volumes and open interest on its futures contracts after the launch of a fully electronic benchmark crude oil contract.

Titular: Steep rise in ICE futures contracts
Texto: The Intercontinental Exchange, the Atlanta-based energy and commodities derivatives market, has seen total open interest in its futures contracts rise almost 50 per cent since the start of this year, in a dramatic response to its recent launch of a fully electronic benchmark crude oil contract.The ICE, which went public last year, is engaged in a battle for market share with the New York Mercantile Exchange - Nymex, the largest US energy exchange, which is considering its own initial public offering.February’s launch of an electronic version of Nymex’s flagship West Texas Intermediate WTI crude contract took ICE’s rivalry with its larger competitor to a new level.On May 9, total open interest on ICE stood at 969,008 contracts, up 49.4 per cent compared with 648,585 contracts at December 31, 2005.Total volume in ICE futures markets reached 451,308 contracts, surpassing the May 4 record of 430,939 contracts by 4.7 per cent.The ICE WTI Crude futures contract set a new daily volume record at 157,009, exceeding the April 25 record of 143,455, with open interest standing at 206,300.In terms of overall volume, Nymex remains in front. Exchange - wide futures and options volume on Nymex recently reached a record 1,420,734 contracts.Earlier this month, Nymex said it would list its energy and metal futures contracts on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange’s electronic exchange, in a move aimed at fending off competition from the ICE. Under the terms of the deal, the CME, the largest US futures exchange, will become the sole provider of electronic trading services for Nymex energy derivatives.The deal will give Nymex the technology to handle expanding electronic trading activity. The CME gains exposure to the increasingly vital energy sector.Analysts said the Nymex move guarded it against competition with the CME and could give it an advantage over the ICE.The chief executives of the CME and ICE politely exchanged their differing views at a panel discussion in New York earlier this weekCraig Donohue, CME chief executive, made clear the Chicago exchange would embrace a “winner take all” mentality, saying he expected energy traders eventually to move to a single marketplace.Jeffrey Sprecher, chief executive and chairman of the ICE, said there was room for two large markets.

Titular: Nymex board changes pave way for IPO
Texto: The New York Mercantile Exchange has cut its board by 25 members to 15 and elected a new chairman, clearing an important hurdle before its proposed initial public offering this year.Richard Schaeffer replaces Mitchell Steinhause as chairnan. James Newsome, Nymex chief executive officer, and William Ford, president of General Atlantic, were elected to the board as part of a deal agreed this year with GA, which took a 10 per cent stake for $160m. The reduction in the size of the board was one of the conditions for the GA deal.Nymex received more than 50 board nominations. None of the candidates fielded by former chairman Michel Marks were elected. Another former Nymex chairman, Danny Rappaport was elected under the equity owners category.Meanwhile, Intercontinental Exchange, Nymex’s rival that floated last year, reported record trading volumes and said it might consider a secondary offering in the near future, although it did not elaborate on what the proceeds might be used for.ICE took the rivalry between the two to a new level in February, launching an electronic version of Nymex’s flagship West Texas Intermediate crude contract.ICE said on Tuesday that excluding the WTI contract, futures volume in the first quarter rose 64.1 per cent.Exchange-wide volume at ICE futures exceeded 400,000 contracts for the first time in a single day on April 25, when 407,303 contracts traded. That was also the busiest day ever for the WTI contract, when 143,455 contracts were traded.The burgeoning volumes pushed ICE’s first-quarter profit to $19.7m from $8.9m a year ago. Revenues were up 58 per cent at $50.3m.

Titular: Wall Street rallies on Fed minutes
