Texto: Wall Street rallied strongly on Tuesday as solid company earnings and a clear indication from the Federal Reserve that its rate-raising cycle might be near its end helped overcome worries over rising oil prices.The market jumped after the FOMC issued minutes of its latest meeting in which it said the end to rate rises was “likely to be near”.“The market was caught off guard by the dovish statement,” said Peter Cardillo, chief market analyst at SW Bach. “However, if energy prices continue to go up, the Fed will probably continue with its cycle of monetary tightening.”Scott Wren, senior equity strategist, AG Edwards and Sons, was less concerned about spiralling crude prices.Although oil futures settled at a record high of $71.35, Mr Wren said the fact that the core producer price index only increased by 0.1 per cent in March was evidence that higher energy prices had not led to a more generalised inflation.“It’s wage-pushed inflation the Feds will be looking at,” he said. “Three-dollar gas might slow down consumer spending but that’s going be offset by strong economic growth.”The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 1.8 per cent, or 194.99 points, at 11,268.77, its biggest point gain in more than two years.The broader S&P 500 rose 1.7 per cent to 1,307.65, while the Nasdaq composite index jumped 2 per cent to 2,356.14.The Amex oil index gained 1.9 per cent, with bellwether ExxonMobil up 2.3 per cent at $63.49 and oil service provider Schlumberger up 2.9 per cent at $64.41.Rate-sensitive stocks such as financials and homebuilders advanced, while Texas Instruments led chipmakers higher with its 3.8 per cent advance to $33.93.The Philadelphia semiconductor index jumped 3.1 per cent after shedding 1.5 per cent in the previous session.Financials were boosted by Merrill Lynch, which rose 1.2 per cent to $79.38 after the group delivered a record $8bn in quarterly revenue.Wells Fargo also saw first quarter profits rise steeply. The stock gained 0.9 per cent to $65.06.IntercontinentalExchange surged 14.3 per cent to $66.16 after analysts at Bear Stearns initiated coverage on the stock with a favorable rating, citing potential for growth and the exchange’s appeal as a takeover target.Other movers included the internet travel services company Travelzoo. Its first-quarter profits topped analysts’ estimates. The shares soared 43 per cent to $28.59.Yahoo and IBM rose ahead of its first quarter earnings. Yahoo rose 1.1 per cent to $31.30 while IBM gained 2.1 per cent to $83.31.Johnson & Johnson, which topped analysts’ estimates with its first-quarter results, rose 0.8 per cent to $58.13 while Boston Scientific, which reported a small decline in first-quarter profit, rose 1.2 per cent to $21.74.

Titular: Nymex ‘disadvantaged’ by futures rules
Texto: James Newsome, president of Nymex, believes the current rules governing the US futures industry could be giving his main rival, the IntercontinentalExchange, a competitive advantage.He also says that a clarification of the rules could lead Nymex to move some of its operations out of the US.The issue has arisen because the US regulator – the Commodity Futures Trading Commission – is reviewing ICE’s status as a foreign futures exchange in the US.ICE offers its futures contracts in the US under a so-called “no-action” letter from the US regulator, which allows it to offer both local and foreign energy contracts. The letter was originally given to the International Petroleum Exchange, the London commodities futures exchange, in 1999. ICE, which is based in Atlanta, bought the exchange in 2001 and renamed it ICE Futures.This means that in the US regulatory regime, ICE is based in the US but its futures contracts are regulated in the UK by the Financial Services Authority.Mr Newsome’s comments are not entirely free of irony, as he was the person responsible for drawing up much of today’s regulatory framework. The Nymex president joined the exchange in August 2004 after serving as chairman of the CFTC for three years. However, he said circumstances had changed since he chaired the regulatory body.ICE’s UK-based futures exchange has moved from trading the vast majority of volumes physically on the floor in London, to a fully electronic exchange where all trade is matched and executed on ICE’s computer systems in Atlanta. The trades are still cleared through LCH.Clearnet in London.“We have no issues with the FSA or LCH, the issue is for the CFTC to decide whether ICE is a US exchange or a foreign exchange. If it is classed as a US exchange, but is allowed to be regulated by the FSA that is fine. It then gives us some options on where we can list our products and contracts,” he said.These options could include listing its electronically traded futures products through Nymex Europe, its London-based futures exchange business, said Mr Newsome.The regulatory frameworks in the US and UK are similar in most areas, but one key difference is the limit on the volume of futures contracts one investor can hold, which is greater in the UK.The Nymex president also warned that the CFTC’s decision on ICE could pave the way for other futures exchanges operating in looser regulatory environments to launch derivative products in the US market.“Once we start on that slippery slope we could see all sorts of players emerging in the market,” Mr Newsome told the Financial Times during a visit to London.Nymex raised concerns about its Atlanta-based rival’s status in January, when ICE sought permission to launch an electronic version of the West Texas Intermediate crude oil contract, to put it in direct competition with Nymex’s premium product.Since its launch a little more than two months ago, ICE’s new contract has grabbed a 25 per cent market share of the total WTI volume. On Friday it plans to launch a heating oil and gasoline futures contract.The New York-based exchange has responded to the challenge from ICE with its own electronic strategy. It plans to extend electronic trading hours to match its trading hours on the floor, so contracts can be traded simultaneously, or side-by-side. It has also aligned itself with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange by agreeing to put all its electronic futures trade on the CME’s Globex system for a 10-year period.Mr Newsome said the side-by-side trading in its energy products would begin by June 1.Comex will move its out-of-hours electronic trading from the Nymex Access system to Globex in the third quarter, but Comex’s management has yet to decide on introducing side-by-side trading.Nymex and Comex merged in 1994, but Comex retains its own independent management, and is operated separately to the energy business. Mr Newsome said the company sought to change the way Comex’s business was structured. Comex’s 700 seat owners hold the rights to all electronic trade in Comex metal contracts, which include gold, silver and copper.“Now we have the Globex deal complete, our top priority is to change the term sheets of the Nymex-Comex relationship. Obviously under the current structure it is prohibitive to expanding electronic trade globally in Comex contracts if only 700 people have the right to trade,” he said.“We hope to have a resolution in the next 60 days.”Changes to the Comex rules would also affect Nymex’s international plans. Nymex owns half of the Dubai Mercantile Exchange, which plans to launch a gold futures contract, but is restricted from doing so until Comex rules are amended.

Titular: Wall St succumbs to profit-taking
Texto:
The old market adage “buy the rumour, sell the news” was in evidence yesterday as investors took profits after Wall Street’s run up this week in anticipation that the March employment report would come in stronger than expected.Nervousness about a sharp rise in long-dated bond yields provided traders with a further reason to sell. By the close, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.9 per cent at 11.120.04, the S&P 500 lost 1 per cent to 1,295.50 and the Nasdaq Composite shed 0.9 per cent to 2,339.02.The broad-based sell-off capped a week of volatile trading that left the Dow and the S&P 0.1 per cent higher over the five sessions, and the Nasdaq almost unchanged.Christopher Johnson, director of quantitative analysis at Schaeffer’s investment research, said the
wild intraday swings were due to a tug of war between bulls betting on a strong move higher as the earnings season gets underway on Monday, and bears who believed high interest rates and crude prices and record commodity prices would hurt earnings growth later in the year.“At the moment, I think the bulls have a slight edge over the bears,” he said, citing the absence of negative earnings pre-announcements as a cause for optimism.Energy, material and information technology were the top performing S&P industry groups this week. Shares of mining companies surged as metal prices such as copper and gold hit new highs. Copper producer Phelps Dodge advanced 4.3 per cent to $83.96, gold producer Newmont Miningadded 1.6 per cent to $52.74 and aluminium maker Alcoa jumped 6.3 per cent to $32.50.Energy stocks climbed alongside crude prices. The Amex Oil index rose 2.5 per cent, led by ConocoPhillips, up 4.4 per cent at $65.96.General Motors, which agreed to sell a controlling stake in GMAC, its finance arm, for $7.4bn this week, led the decliners on the Dow.It fell 8.3 per cent to $19.51 as sentiment was undermined by its ongoing dispute with Delphi and news that first-quarter sales fell by 14 per cent. Ford Motor, which reported lower sales, lost 4.5 per cent to $7.60.Merck weighed on the blue-chip index. Shares in the pharmaceutical group lost 2.2 per cent to $34.47 after it was ordered to pay at least $4.5m in compensation to a man who blamed Merck, the maker of Vioxx, for his heart attack.Analysts said the decision could potentially open the door for a new wave of litigation that could result in Merck paying billions of dollars in compensation.Supporting the Dow was 3M, which surged 7.1 per cent to $81.03 after raising its profit outlook for the first quarter. The Post-it Note maker said first-quarter revenue growth was expected to be as much as twice previous estimates while earnings could grow by up to 5.5 per cent.Technology stocks continued to make headway, with Apple Computer leading the way with a 11.3 per cent advance to $69.79.Apple shares soared after it unveiled new software allowing users to run Microsoft’s Windows operating system on its Intel-based Macintosh computers.Analysts said the move was likely to open the door to new Mac converts, although some warned that the gains would not be as swift and dramatic as some expected.“We would not expect any meaningful impact on Mac sales or earnings in the near or intermediate term,” said Rick Sherlund at Goldman Sachs.Google, up 4.1 per cent on the week to $406.16, saw its shares climb back above $400 for the first time since early February as index funds
continued to buy the stock following its inclusion in the S&P 500 index last week.Shares in Intercontinental Exchange, the electronic energy exchange, slumped 23.2 per cent this week to $53 after New York Mercantile Exchange (Nymex) announced plans to list its benchmark energy products on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME).Morgan Stanley cut its rating on the stock, saying the CME-Nymex team-up
“creates a potentially formidable combination that could alter the competitive landscape for the ICE”.“While we continue to believe in the ICE’s solid position in the energy derivatives market, the CME/Nymex partnership may limit further upside in the stock price,” said analyst Camron Ghaffari.

Titular: Nymex to unveil CME energy pact
Texto: The New York Mercantile Exchange is on Tuesday expected to announce plans to list its benchmark energy products on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, highlighting the role that its new private equity shareholder has assumed in shaping strategy.Nymex will outsource all of its electronic trading activities in crude oil and other futures to the CME’s Globex electronic distribution platform, according to shareholders at the New York exchange.Observers view the move as an admission that Nymex – facing intensifying competition from the all-electronic Intercontinental Exchange – cannot move fast enough by itself to introduce electronic trading side-by-side with its existing pits.The deal comes three months after the two exchanges failed to agree on a minority investment by the CME, with Nymex opting to press ahead with the agreed sale of a 10 per cent stake to General Atlantic, the private equity group.Bill Ford, GA’s president, secured a place on the Nymex board as part of the deal, and some market observers view the CME pact as evidence of the firm’s hand in grooming the exchange for an initial public offering this year.However, it is unlikely to entice members of the metals exchange unit at Nymex to move towards electronic trading as they have no equity stake in the business.The CME will secure fees for handling trades in Nymex crude oil and related products on Globex. It would also demonstrate the effectiveness of Globex in attracting and executing energy business ahead of the planned launch of energy products by the CME itself after an existing non-compete agreement with the New York exchange expires in June.“The key will be to show that they have the domain-handling capability,” said Tom Kloet, chief operating officer of Fimat USA, one of the largest futures brokers.The pact will be closely watched for any amendment to the non-compete clause as any CME energy strategy is almost certain to include crude oil. It could damp speculation of a future tie-up between the CME and ICE, which floated last year.ICE intensified the pressure on Nymex in February when it launched an electronic version of the West Texas Intermediate crude contract, the premier product at the New York exchange. However, observers believe ICE will need a more powerful distribution tool – such as Globex – to build on its success since abandoning pit-trading in favour of an all-electronic platform.Nymex declined to comment as did the CME, which on Monday extended the contract of chief executive Craig Donohue by three years until the end of 2009.

Titular: ICE turns up the heat with new futures
Texto: Intercontinental Exchange, the online commodities exchange, said on Tuesday it would launch an electronic version of US heating oil futures and US gasoline futures next month.The new contracts, which will intensify competition with the New York Mercantile Exchange, its bigger rival, will be launched through ICE Futures, formerly the International Petroleum Exchange.Last month ICE launched a West Texas Intermediate contract, the world’s premier energy futures contract.It now has daily volumes of more than 60,000.ICE is launching New York Harbor unleaded gasoline blendstock (RBOB) futures and ICE New York Harbor heating oil futures, along with three spreads, or “cracks”, between new and existing contracts.Nymex is in the middle of phasing out its main gasoline futures contract, unleaded gasoline, which will be replaced by RBOB. Trading volume in the Nymex RBOB contract is about a fifth of that in the main gasoline contract.Nymex’s heating oil contract is threatened by ICE, which has doubled daily volumes in its gas oil contract – the European benchmark for winter fuel prices – in the past year and has surpassed Nymex’s heating oil volumes.“We are pleased to build on the recent success of our new ICE WTI crude futures contract with a variety of new products based on customer demand,” said David Peniket, ICE Futures president and CEO.Since ICE Futures moved fully electronic last April, it has increased its market share against Nymex from below 30 per cent to about 40 per cent by attracting more investors who prefer to trade electronically.

Titular: Nymex prepares to go public
Texto:
The New York Mercantile Exchange looks set to become the next beneficiary of strong investor demand for financial exchanges after shareholders approved the
purchase by General Atlantic, the US private equity group, of 10 per cent of Nymex for up to $170m.Although the transaction values Nymex at $1.7bn, the market value is expected to be far higher by the time Nymex, the world’s largest energy futures exchange and owner of Comex, the metals futures exchange, comes to its initial public offering, scheduled for the end of the year.A better guide for the valuation of the exchange, which is 134 years old, is the sale price of its seats. Each of the 816 seats gives the owner equity in the exchange and exclusive rights to trade on the exchange floor, where the price of West Texas Intermediate, the world’s most closely watched oil benchmark, is set.On Monday – the day that 93 per cent of Nymex shareholders who voted approved the General Atlantic deal – a seat was sold for a record $3.9m, surpassing the previous record of $3.8m set last Friday. This would value Nymex at almost $3.2bn, closer to its probable IPO valuation if current share prices for futures and stock exchanges are a guide.Nymex’s seats represent the entire equity of the exchange. As of Tuesday, seat owners now view the value of their seats split between the equity and the trading component.Bill Ford, GA president, said the size of the vote gave a clear mandate for change. “We see a lot of potential for Nymex, with the introduction of side by side electronic trading and new product innovation,” he said. The Intercontinental Exchange (ICE), Nymex’s smaller but faster growing competitor, is valued at more than $4bn. Shares in ICE have risen more than 170 per cent since it listed in November, and is worth more than its older rival in spite of having about 40 per cent of the US and European energy futures market compared with Nymex’s 60 per cent.Before Nymex lists, it has work to do. It has to shrink the size of its board from 25 to 15 members, one of the conditions for the GA deal.The exchange’s membership subcommittee meets on Wednesday to accept recommendations for the new board ahead of a vote in May on the board changes.Nymex has received more than 50 board nominations, including applications from Michel Marks and Danny Rappaport, former chairmen. At present, the board is dominated by traders and has no independent directors, leading to accusations that it has been managed as a private members’ club.Mr Ford will join the Nymex board, while the private equity group’s say in the boardroom is expected to be aided by Richard Schaeffer, Nymex vice-chairman, who is expected to oust Mitchell Steinhause as the chairman in the May vote. Mr Schaeffer brought the GA deal to the Nymex board last year.Potential investors in Nymex will be looking for the exchange to provide more clarity on its plans to implement electronic trading side by side with pit trading. The average daily turnover of ICE energy futures has doubled since it switched to a fully electronic exchange last April.Mr Ford said Nymex was likely to copy the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, where the floor and electronic trading co-exist.One Nymex shareholder said Nymex had the technology to handle more electronically generated trades but lacked the distribution of its terminals to customers. He said that left the prospect open for Nymex to partner another exchange such as Eurex or Euronext.Liffe where Nymex futures contracts could be traded on the systems of other exchanges.

Titular: Electronic trade lifts ICE volumes
Texto: ICE Futures, formerly the International Petroleum Exchange, has increased its share of the global energy futures market to about 40 per cent since it moved to full electronic trading last April.That compares with less than 30 per cent in March 2005, the last full month before it went electronic, according to PVM, a London energy futures broker.PVM’s estimates show that ICE Futures, which is owned by the Atlanta online commodities exchange Intercontinental Exchange, is gaining market share on its bigger rival, the New York Mercantile Exchange.It has been helped by the launch last month of an electronic version of the West Texas Intermediate futures, the flagship contract of its bigger rival Nymex.Following its launch ICE’s WTI contract attracted average daily volumes of about 44,000 contracts.Figures for March show ICE’s new contract has achieved average daily volumes of more than 50,000 contracts, or about 15 per cent of Nymex’s WTI daily volumes.Nymex still controls about 60 per cent of the energy futures market and is experiencing higher volumes now than it did 12 months ago.Trading volumes on both ICE and Nymex are more closely watched: competition between the two exchanges has intensified over the past 18 months with Nymex relaunching its Brent contract in Europe against ICE’s contract of the same name.Volume growth is also important to the valuation of both exchanges.ICE listed its shares of the New York Stock Exchange in November, and Nymex plans an initial public share offering by the end of the year. Next Monday, Nymex shareholders will vote on a move by General Atlantic, the private equity group, to buy a 10 per cent stake of the exchange.PVM said in a note to clients that daily volumes on ICE’s crude futures contracts averaged more than 200,000 in February, more than double the average in March 2005.During the same period, Nymex’s crude futures volume has risen to more than 300,000 contracts a day from about 250,000.ICE’s gasoil contract, which is an indicator for European winter fuel, has seen its daily volumes almost double in the past year to more than 65,000 contracts, overtaking Nymex’s competing contract, heating oil, for the first time.Nymex heating oil futures was the first energy contract the exchange launched when it listed in 1978.

Titular: Profile: Richard Ward
Texto: Despite his lack of experience in the insurance industry, Richard Ward has been named as the new chief executive of Lloyd’s, as the world’s oldest insurance market looks to overhaul its business practices in the face of competition from rival markets such as Bermuda.Previously, he worked as chief executive of the International Petroleum Exchange until it was taken over by the Intercontinental Exchange last year.It is understood that ICE did not want a second chief executive to Jeffrey Sprecher, so Mr Ward’s role was downgraded to the role of vice-chairman.During his six years as head of the IPE, Mr Ward oversaw a significant period of change during which the exchange was taken over and its open outcry trading system overhauled to become a fully electronic operation ahead of the move by the New York Mercantile Exchange to open a rival exchange in London six months ago.Despite some teething difficulties when human error halted trading for a few hours and fierce opposition from floor traders, volumes at the IPE have risen by more than a third since it went fully electronic in April. This modernisation in the face of international competition is what is likely to have impressed Lloyd’s.Mr Ward became IPE chief executive after setting up an innovative gas futures market while working in business development.Prior to moving into financial services, Mr Ward worked for BP, initially as manager of a large analytical research and development department within BP Group Research before being appointed head of business development at its oil trading business.His early career was spent as a scientist at the Science and Engineering Research Council.

Titular: Nymex abandons plan for London floor trading in oil
Texto: An ambitious attempt to re-introduce floor trading in oil contracts in London by the New York Mercantile Exchange is to be abandoned.Nymex intends soon to close its pit-trading floor for energy futures in London and shift to electronic trade. The move comes six months after launching the floor in London.Nymex has failed to attract significant trading volumes in its European benchmark Brent crude contracts since opening the London floor. The operation had been seen as one of a string of open out-cry trading floors Nymex intended to open round the world to take advantage of the increased trading in energy. These plans have now been curtailed.Nymex spent millions of dollars opening the London floor with a capacity for about 100 traders using sophisticated telephone and computer systems. Most of the trade now handled by the handful of traders who remain in the Nymex London pit is via screens.However, Nymex, the world’s biggest energy futures exchange, has no plans to quit the European market and is looking to establish a market in Russian Urals crude and other energy products to take on its London rival ICE Futures, formerly the International Petroleum Ex-change, which is owned by IntercontinentalExchange.ICE Futures became fully electronic last April and its daily volumes in its premium contract, Brent, have risen by more than 60 per cent. “Brent will go electronic,” said Andy Gooch, chief executive of Nymex Europe. He added that the exchange had many options, including the possibility to be the home for all of the electronically traded energy futures contracts operated by its parent.

Titular: Nymex to abandon London open-outcry trading
Texto: An ambitious attempt by the New York Mercantile Exchange to re-introduce floor trading in oil contracts in London is to be abandoned.Nymex intends to close its pit-trading floor for energy futures in London soon and shift over to electronic trade. The move comes six months after the launch of the floor in London.Nymex has failed to attract significant trading volumes in its European benchmark Brent crude contracts since opening the London floor. The operation had been seen as one of a string of open out-cry trading floors that Nymex had intended to open around the world in order to take advantage of the increased trading in energy. These plans have now been curtailed.Nymex spent millions of dollars opening the London floor with a capacity for about 100 traders using sophisticated telephone and computer systems. Most of the trade now handled by the handful of traders who remain in the Nymex London pit is via screens.However, Nymex, the world’s biggest energy futures exchange, has no plans to quit the European market and is looking to establish a market in Russian Urals crude and other energy products to take on its London rival ICE Futures, formerly the International Petroleum Ex-change, which is owned by Intercontinental Exchange.ICE Futures became fully electronic last April and its daily volumes in its premium contract, Brent, have risen by more than 60 per cent. “Brent will go electronic,” said Andy Gooch, chief executive of Nymex Europe.He added that the exchange had many options, including the possibility to be the home for all of the electronically-traded energy futures contracts operated by its parent.

Titular: Futures in WTI go electronic at Nymex
Texto:
The New York Mercantile Exchange has confirmed it plans to offer electronic trading in its flagship futures contract in West Texas Intermediate crude oil alongside its traditional floor trading from the second quarter of this year.The Nymex board also approved a revised offer from General Atlantic, the private equity group, which will pay $160m for a 10 per cent stake in the 134-year-old exchange.This compares with an original offer of $135m for the stake.The exchange said General Atlantic would pay an extra $10m under three conditions: Nymex’s 816 shareholders must vote to back the offer by March 15; hold an annual meeting to reduce the size of its board from 25 to 15 by May 1; and complete an initial public offering at a $2bn valuation or more by the year-end.The proceeds will be distributed to Nymex shareholders through a cash distribution of about $196,000 per share and the additional $10m investment will be
distributed in a special dividend of about $12,255 per share.Nymex said the revised definitive agreement contained provisions to support and protect open outcry trading, including a requirement for financial support for technology, marketing and research for open outcry.The provisions also state that core futures and options contracts may not be eliminated without a vote by trading rights holders, as long as specified liquidity requirements are met.“If the exchange ever terminates open outcry trading of a particular product, trading rights owners will receive a 10 per cent royalty payment based upon the electronic trading of that product,” Nymex said.The move to expand Nymex’s electronic trading in WTI follows the launch last Friday by rival commodities exchange IntercontinentalExchange (ICE) of
an electronic WTI contract.The new contract has attracted daily volumes that equates to almost 10 per
cent of Nymex’s daily WTI turnover.Separately, Dubai Mercantile Exchange, a joint venture between Nymex and Dubai Holding, a company owned by Crown Prince Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum, said it plans to open the Middle East’s first energy futures exchange in the fourth quarter. Originally the partners had planned to open the DME early this year.Trading on the new exchange will be mostly electronic, along with its “trading hubs”, featuring four to six seats where traders can manage trades.The DME plans to launch with a sour-based crude oil contract to reflect the
type of oil produced in the region.

Titular: Nymex joins electronic revolution
Texto: The New York Mercantile Exchange has always done business its own way. Over the past two years it has pursued a global strategy of opening up satellite energy futures trading floors as the world’s other futures markets were going increasingly electronic.Now, Nymex appears ready to accept that electronic trading is the future. Any day, it is expected to announce formally that it will introduce electronic trading alongside its pit trading this spring.Nymex shareholders say that the move mirrors that of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, which have both introduced electronic trading side by side with their pit trading. The CME introduced electronic trading in 1990 and the CBOT in 2000, and it now accounts for about 70 per cent of business on both exchanges.Although Nymex insiders claim that the issue has been debated for some time at boardroom meetings, the admission last week by Nymex shareholders that the exchange intended to introduce parallel trading follows a week in which competitors increasingly encroached on its turf. Its closest rival, the IntercontinentalExchange (ICE), the Atlanta online commodities exchange, last Friday launched an electronic version of West Texas Intermediate, the world’s most prominent oil futures contract and the flagship contract for Nymex.“This was not prompted by ICE, but it has been under discussion for months,” said one Nymex shareholder. “In fact the pressure came from the floor, where many of the floor community thought that it was a good idea to have the two together as it may create more liquidity.”The launch has also stirred up a debate about regulation of the WTI contract, which is the world’s most popular reference price for oil. ICE launched its new contract through its UK arm, ICE Futures, formerly the International Petroleum Exchange, which is regulated by the UK’s Financial Services Authority.Nymex shareholders say that this gives ICE an unfair advantage because the FSA does not place an upper limits on investors’ holdings of energy contracts, whereas the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission has imposed limits. Nymex has threatened to move its electronic trading business to London in order to compete with ICE under the same regulations.“Moving the [electronic trading] business offshore is a real issue and something the board is looking at very closely,” said the shareholder. “However, we don’t want to get into a row with the CFTC because that will not be good for business.” James Newsome, Nymex president, was formerly the CFTC chairman. Nymex has a trading floor in London, which was opened last year after ICE closed its London oil futures trading pits where its premier contract Brent crude was traded.However, Nymex’s Brent volumes have been poor because many former London-based floor traders have migrated their oil trading activities to the screen.On its first day, ICE’s new product traded more than 38,000 contracts, or about 10 per cent of Nymex’s daily volume for its WTI contract. The launch came three days after Craig Donohue, CME chief executive officer, said the exchange was finalising its energy markets strategy.“We believe there is a lot of growth opportunity in the energy market, particularly related to electronic trading,” said Mr Donohue.CME and Nymex fell out last month when talks about the CME buying a 10 per cent stake in its rival broke down.A non-compete clause between the two ends on June 6, leaving the CME free to pursue its energy strategy. “They [CME] are very serious. They see energy as the missing piece in their suite of products,” said one industry consultant.The increased competition for Nymex comes when shareholders of the exchange, which is 134 years old, are considering the sale of 10 per cent of the exchange to private equity group General Atlantic for $170m.Shareholders have yet to vote on the proposed partial sale to General Atlantic, which increased its original offer by $35m.“Nymex has a lot of issues up in the air – the threat of CME coming in, ICE launching WTI and the General Atlantic deal. It is sending them into panic mode,” the industry consultant said.Additional Reporting by Doug Cameron

Titular: Nymex poised for electronic trading push
Texto: The New York Mercantile Exchange, one of the last bastions of face-to-face trading, could within a month offer electronic trading alongside its famous open outcry pits, seatholders said on Friday.The world’s largest energy exchange is also looking for international partners to broaden its electronic offering, seatholders said.The development is another sign of the speed at which electronic trading is sweeping aside decades of trading pit transactions. The news came as the InterContinental Exchange (ICE), Nymex’s all-electronic rival, on Friday launched its biggest attack on the New York exchange by offering its own electronic version of the Nymex’s flagship West Texas Intermediate crude futures.Nymex, with roots in a butter, cheese and egg exchange founded in 1872 by a group of Manhattan dairy merchants, is expected to go public this year.Seatholders said the board decided on Wednesday to go ahead with the side-by-side electronic trading following pressure from members. Its smaller, “mini” contracts are currently traded electronically, but its benchmark energy products trade in the famously crowded pits. Seatholders said Nymex was looking for international partners with strong electronic trading capabilities.A Nymex spokesperson on Friday declined to comment, saying only that the exchange “continued to evaluate ways to expand on the success that we have”.Nymex is believed to be close to selling a 10 per cent stake to General Atlantic, a private equity group. GA was instrumental in the merger of the floor-based New York Stock Exchange with the all-electronic Archipelago in a deal that should close soon and will lead to a hybrid trading model.Any move by Nymex’s flagship crude and natural gas contracts electronically would be considered a blow to the remaining advocates of floor-based trading. Nymex’s neighbour and fellow floor-based trading hold-out, the New York Board of Trade, last month announced it would partner with the Chicago Board of Trade to offer its financial futures electronically. Both the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the CBOT are overwhelmingly electronic.A switch to electronic by Nymex would increase pressure on the NYSE to follow suit.Nymex is also discussing the possibility of moving its electronic platform to London. to put it under the regulatory scrutiny of the UK’s Financial Services Authority which would put it on an equal footing with its rival ICE. The FSA and the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission have slightly different regulatory requirements.

Titular: ICE shares soar in Wall St debut
Texto: Shares in the IntercontinentalExchange surged more than 60 per cent in their first morning of trading after the energy derivatives specialist was valued at $1.44bn in the pricing of the offering.By mid-morning on Wednesday, ICE shares had risen 63 per cent to $42.50. The rally follows a successful initial public offering from CBOT Holdings, owner of the Chicago Board of Trade and a leading futures exchange.The successful IPOs underscore investor appetite for a slice of the derivatives market, whose dramatic growth has outstripped the equities market. They also reflect the resilience of the futures industry after the debacle last month at Refco, the bankrupt financial services group.The world’s second-largest energy exchange this week raised the indicative range for the offering by a third and boosted the issue size by 60 per cent, reflecting investor demand for both fast-growing derivatives and the buoyant commodities sector.The net proceeds will also provide ammunition for the exchange’s battle with the New York Mercantile Exchange, its larger rival.Nymex, which has courted ICE for many years, on Tuesday finalised its sale of a 10 per cent stake to General Atlantic for $135m, pricing in line with the value of its smaller rival. It said it would pursue an IPO next year.ICE also owns ICE Futures, formerly known as the International Petroleum Exchange. It took the custodian of the Brent crude futures market all-electronic earlier this year, while Nymex opened an open-outcry pit in London last month. Investor interest in the derivatives sector has been buoyed by the performance of the Chicago Board of Trade, the third-largest futures exchange, whose shares have more than doubled since an IPO last month.The share price of the second-ranked Chicago Mercantile Exchange has tracked record highs in recent weeks and climbed more than 10-fold since its flotation in December 2003.The ICE raised its indicative pricing from $18-$20 a share to $24-$26 a share on Monday and lifted the offer size from 10m to 16m shares, of which 13.5m are being sold to existing shareholders. The underwriters have the option to purchase an additional 2.4m shares to cover overallotments.Nymex commands more than 60 per cent of global energy futures contracts but the ICE’s Brent business is a fast-growing operation.

Titular: ICE to make waves with flotation
Texto: The Intercontinental Exchange, the world’s second largest energy futures exchange, has unveiled a planned initial public share offer that could raise up to $230m. If successful, the offer would value the exchange at more than $1.1bn, a price that would put it beyond the clutches of its bigger rival, the New York Mercantile Exchange, which has long sought to buy ICE.The proposed ICE flotation, announced late Friday, is expected in the next four weeks. ICE shares were given an indicated value of $18-$20 apiece. The float comes with futures and derivative exchanges in high demand among equity investors encouraged by the meteoric rise in the share price of Chicago Mercantile Exchange since it listed four years ago.ICE, less than a decade old, may not be as well known as its peers, some of which have been around for more than a century. Despite recent setbacks to some futures exchanges caused by the Refco scandal, ICE hopes to take advantage of the high multiples investors are willing to pay for a stake in futures exchanges.The valuation of ICE puts it not too far below the value placed on Nymex, the world’s largest commodity exchange, by a proposed offer for 10 per cent of the exchange from General Atlantic. The offer, valuing the stake at $135m, has been approved by the Nymex board but has yet to be voted on by shareholders.Nymex commands more than 60 per cent of global energy futures contracts, as well as boasting a subsidiary, Comex, that is the world’s largest precious metals futures exchange. But ICE is hoping its strategy of electronic-only trading provides it with greater growth opportunities than its rival, which has stubbornly stuck with the open outcry that has been abandoned by most exchanges.“ICE has had a phenomenal year. They are a lower cost operator than Nymex, and they have positioned themselves well in the OTC market, which has been growing faster than the futures market,” said one former futures exchange executive.Nymex has been trying to buy ICE and its International Petroleum Exchange subsidiary, the custodian of Brent trading, for five years. In a letter to shareholders last week, Michel Marks, a former Nymex chairman who continues to hold a significant Nymex stake, said Nymex should buy ICE before Nymex floats.ICE was behind the decision to close the IPE’s London trading floor in April after 25 years of pit trading, leaving the IPE as an electronic-only exchange. After an initial dip in trading volume following the floor closure, volumes for its key Brent futures contract have increased by a third to an average of 183,000 contracts a day during September.The increase in IPE’s Brent futures trading volume has made it difficult for Nymex, which opened a trading floor in London last month to great fanfare and with the mission to revive open outcry energy trading in London. Nymex Brent trading volumes have slowed dramatically from the 16,591 contracts on the first day.The IPE business now vies with ICE’s rapidly growing over-the-counter energy derivative trading business as the biggest single contributor to the Atlanta-based exchange’s operations. ICE claims it now clears – a function where an exchange settles trades as well as taking on the financial risk should one trading party default – about 78 per cent of all OTC natural gas trade in the US and 64 per cent of the power market for central and eastern US states.ICE had a small presence in the US power market three years ago, while OTC trades in the US natural gas have tripled in the first six months this year.The decision to go ahead with a flotation followed a US court decision on September 30, which rejected Nymex’s claims of copyright and trademark infringement by ICE for ICE’s use of Nymex’s settlement prices in electronic energy trading and clearing operations.ICE gave no indication of timing for its float, but its announcement comes just ahead of the Chicago Board of Trade listing tomorrow. The CBOT has raised $126.5m from selling a 6 per cent stake, valuing the CBOT at more than $2.1bn.The planned IPO would mark an attractive return for its shareholders, which include Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, BP Royal Dutch Shell, Deutsche Bank and Société Générale, which backed ICE five years ago.Goldman, Morgan Stanley and the investment banking arm of Société Générale are on the ICE float underwriting team.ICE plans to sell 2.5m new shares in the float to raise a maximum of $50m, which would be used to pay debts. ICE shareholders plan to sell 7.5m shares, raising $150m. Morgan Stanley and Goldman will have the option to buy another 1.5m shares to cover over-allotments.

Titular: Record volumes revealed by IPE
Texto: The International Petroleum Exchange, the custodian of the Brent crude oil futures contract, said its benchmark contract struck record volumes this week, rising almost 90 per cent from the daily average before the London exchange moved to fully electronic trading in April.IPE, owned by the Intercontinental Exchange in Atlanta, said Brent volumes reached 185,144 contracts on Tuesday, exceeding the previous record of 181,182 contracts last September.IPE thinks electronic trading in commodities will attract more customers such as hedge funds, which are used to trading other assets, such as equities, bonds and currencies, via electronic systems.IPE’s increase in trading volume adds to the challenge rival New York Mercantile Exchange faces in its attempt to market grab share from the IPE in the Brent contract.Nymex has built a new trading floor for open-outcry trading in London in an effort to take the IPE head-on, but is yet to win regulatory approval from the UK’s Financial Services Authority. Nymex has a functioning open-outcry trading floor in Dublin where year-to-date volumes were 5,260 contracts a day, compared with Reuters estimates that IPE Brent volumes averaged more than 111,000 contracts a day.James Newsome, Nymex president, last week admitted the exchange’s task was becoming harder as more traders got used to trading Brent electronically.The rise in IPE Brent volumes has also narrowed the gap with Nymex’s benchmark crude futures contract, West Texas Intermediate, the world’s most actively traded crude contract. It recorded volumes of 302,999 contracts on Tuesday.

Titular: Nymex admits its London struggle
Texto: The New York Mercantile Exchange conceded on Thursday that establishing a strong presence in the Brent crude futures market in London was becoming more difficult as it awaited regulatory approval, while volumes continued to rise at its electronic rival, the International Petroleum Exchange.Nymex plans to open an open-outcry exchange in London to try and wrest control of trade in Brent futures away from the IPE, which closed its trading floor in early April. In the interim, Nymex has established a Brent futures trading hub in Dublin with mixed success.James Newsome, president of Nymex, said the task was becoming harder as more traders got used to trading Brent electronically.“It gets more and more difficult (to take business) as time goes by,” Mr Newsome said at a derivatives conference in London on Thursday.The IPE, wholly-owned by Atlanta-based commodities exchange Intercontinental Exchange, has seen a rise in Brent futures daily trading volumes to about 130,000 contracts a day, compared with 100,000 a day before the IPE moved electronic.Brent volumes in May were almost 2.5m, compared with 2.2m in March, the last month of open-outcry trade. Mr Newsome said Nymex’s Brent volumes in Dublin have averaged between 5,000 and 20,000 contracts a day since opening in November. Nymex is the world’s largest energy futures exchange and is the custodian of the US benchmark, the West Texas Intermediate contract.Mr Newsome said Nymex was also considering offers from private equity companies for a minority interest in the exchange. “Any deal would be with a view to doing an IPO (initial public offering),” he said. Blackstone and Battery Ventures are said to be seeking to buy a 20 per cent stake in Nymex for about $185m.Nymex said in May it had spoken with other exchanges about a possible tie-up, but the only futures exchange to say it was interested in buying into Nymex was the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The CME has become the most likely partner for the Chicago Board of Trade, which said earlier this week that it had received a financial offer from a third party.“All futures exchanges are talking to everybody at the moment,” Mr Newsome said. Nymex has said it will decide over the summer its future financial options.Roy Leighton was made chairman of Nymex Europe, the subsidiary spearheading Nymex’s move into London. Mr Leighton is also chairman of the UK’s Futures and Options Association.

Titular: Nymex to discuss possible IPO
Texto: Members of the New York Mercantile Exchange have been called to a special meeting to discuss the exchange's possible plans for an initial public offering and increasing threats from competing exchanges, its largest participant said on Wednesday.Mark Fisher, an independent trader who runs MBF Clearing Corp, said he had issued a call for the exchange's members to meet on March 30."The exchange is at a critical juncture," said Mr Fisher, whose firm is also the largest clearing member of the exchange.The development comes as Nymex, the largest energy futures exchange in the world, faces competition on multiple fronts and is considering joining other US exchanges in pursuing an IPO.On Tuesday, Atlanta-based rival the Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) filed with regulators to raise up to $115m in an IPO.That could strengthen its hand against Nymex, which plans to launch an "open outcry" Brent crude trading pit in London soon, in competition with the International Petroleum Exchange. The London exchange, which has been owned by ICE since 2001, is moving rapidly to switch from "open outcry" to electronic trading.The issue of "ICE vs. Nymex" was one item the agenda issued by Mr Fisher.Mr Fisher told the FT: "Hopefully as many members and lessees and equity owners will show up as possible. We are the largest volume participant [on Nymex] so I thought we'd do something about it. It's the right time."He declined to say what he expected from the meeting.A Nymex spokeswoman said: "It's not an exchange meeting, it's just a private business owner holding a meeting."Other issues on the agenda were Nymex and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, which has said it is interested in expanding into energy futures.Next week, it will launch an electronically-traded ethanol futures contract that will compete with a rival ethanol futures contract that started trading in open outcry on Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade.Nymex has 816 seats, although members may own multiple seats. A seat on Nymex last sold for $1.9m, compared to $675,000 in 2000.

Titular: IPE to shut open outcry and go fully electronic
Texto: The International Petroleum Exchange said on Monday it plans to shut its open outcry trading floor in London on April 7 in a move to full electronic trading of its energy futures contracts, including Brent crude futures.The closure comes ahead of a planned opening of an open-outcry trading floor in London by IPE’s larger rival, the New York Mercantile Exchange later this year. The all electronic exchange will open on April 8.“The board’s decision has been taken to maintain and enhance the competitive position of the IPE as well a to take advantage of the greater acceptance and adoption of electronic trading,” the IPE said.The IPE closed its morning open-outcry trading session last autumn in an effort to increase electronic trading volumes, which at the time had only amounted to 4 per cent of total daily volumes. IPE management have been encouraged by the transition with volumes in the morning session now at the level traded when the floor was open.The exchange hopes to repeat the same trend for the whole day.Another contributing factor to the closure was the decision last week by the IPE’s parent the Intercontinental Exchange, the Atlanta-based online commodities exchange, to make a initial public share offering.Traders said the IPE wanted to avoid a costly battle with Nymex by keeping its trading pits open.IPE’s main contract Brent futures is a key benchmark for oil exporters in the Middle East, but is less traded than Nymex’s West Texas Intermediate crude futures contract.

Titular: Oil exchange plans IPO as crude reaches record
Texto: The battle for control of the global energy trading market intensified on Thursday as Intercontinental Exchange, owner of the International Petroleum Exchange in London, outlined plans to hold an initial public offering.The plan comes as the IPE, Europe?s largest oil futures market, faces the prospect of a new exchange launch in London from US rival Nymex.Interest in the commodity exchanges has intensified in recent years as oil and metal prices have risen to record levels, driven by demand from China and supply shortages.Oil reached its highest level since October 27 in trading on Thursday.Brent crude futures on IPE rose to a record $52.25 a barrel, surpassing its previous high of $51.94 a barrel.US light crude was trading at $53.65 a barrel having gained almost 17 per cent in three weeks as colder weather gripped Europe and the north-eastern US.Atlanta-based Interncontinental Exchange (ICE), the owner of the exchange that offers over-the-counter trading in oil, gas and power derivatives, as opposed to the traditional open-outcry system of trading, said it plans to file a registration document with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the US market regulator, in the ?next several weeks.?Plans by rival Nymex for global domination of commodities trading was dealt a blow in 2001 when ICE acquired the US exchange?s London rival, IPE, which trades the benchmark Crude futures contract, for an undisclosed sum.But ICE?s plans to replace open-outcry trading with a more efficient electronic alternative within a year of the deal, stalled in the face of growing opposition from users of the London exchange.In November, ICE introduced a system which restricted open-outcry trading to the afternoon session in an attempt to boost volumes and win over clients to over-the-counter trading.The Nymex exchange, which offers the benchmark West Texas Intermediate futures contract as well as the Brent crude contract, processes an average of 250,000 contracts a day compared to 100,000 contracts on the IPE.The London exchange was thought to have planned a board meeting for later on Thursday to discuss the IPO plans of its parent and further moves towards the complete removal of open-outcry trading.Separately, ICE released results for 2004 which showed electronic trading grew as a share of the total number of contracts traded on the IPE to 27.2 per cent in January compared to 2.8 per cent the previous year.The parent group reported full-year revenues of $108.4m, up from $93.7m in 2003. Consolidated net income almost doubled to $22m from $13m the previous year.

Titular: Energy traders enter next battle phase
Texto: The focus of New York Mercantile Exchange's move to London is the battle to win control of the Brent crude oil futures market, the domain of the UK-based International Petroleum Exchange.But the rivals also face a skirmish over the business of clearing both over-the-counter and exchange-traded energy derivatives contracts.Both Nymex and Intercontinental Exchange (ICE), IPE's parent, have benefited from a growing trend to the outsource the financial risk attached to trading in the unregulated OTC markets for power, gas and oil.This has facilitated strong growth in the clearing of energy trades in the OTC market, which is twice the size of the futures market.Jeffrey Sprecher, chief executive of ICE, said banks, utilities, energy trading houses, shippers and gas and oil producers - and increasingly hedge funds - no longer want to tie their balance sheet up to provide collateral for underwriting OTC trades. Instead, they pay a fee for a third party, such as an exchange, to take the risk in the event that the other side to the trade is unable to fulfil its financial obligation.By freeing up their balance sheets, market participants can conduct more trades, Mr Sprecher said. "It's a good business for the exchanges right now, and it looks like it will continue to grow as more traders see it as a economical way to trade OTC," he said.Many OTC traders avoid bilateral clearing agreements as it takes time to separately negotiate the terms with all the counterparties they trade with, which number in the hundreds for some active traders.New technology has also made third-party clearing easier. ICE provides customers with a choice of electronic or bilateral clearing, whereas Nymex uses a network of voice brokers, including ICAP, which are active in OTC trading and increasingly use the Clearport electronic platform to clear the trades.The latest published figures from Nymex show OTC clearing volumes more than quadrupled over the 11 months to November 2004, while ICE's volumes tripled over the same period. Meanwhile, executives say the market is still in its early stages of development.Joseph Raia, vice-president marketing at Nymex, said the success of Clearport had prompted the exchange to extend its clearing business into shipping freight swaps, and European petroleum product swaps. The OTC market has largely recovered from the exit of energy merchants such as Enron, Mirant and Dynergy from business in 2001, when Enron, the market leader, collapsed.US traders are used to outsourcing their clearing business, a concept initially developed by Enron. However, European traders have so far been reluctant to embrace exchange clearing, instead continuing to trade OTC through bilateral risk agreements."The need to remove any threat of balance sheet damage is another reason why US traders are happy to let someone else worry about the clearing," one exchange executive said.The growth in OTC clearing has also changed the way futures exchanges view the market. Instead of considering OTC trading as a threat, they now see it as a growth area.Unlike Nymex, ICE is not a clearing house. Instead, ICE funnels all its clearing traffic to LCH.Clearnet in which it, along with EuronextLiffe and the London Metal Exchange, has a minority stake.Executives from both exchanges say there is plenty of scope for growth for clearing OTC trades.However, LCH.Clearnet and Nymex are also poised to become rivals in the more competitive market of clearing energy futures when Nymex, which plans to open its London futures exchange later this year, starts clearing all its futures trades through its clearing house in New York. If Nymex succeeds in capturing a large slice of the London Brent futures market, it will threaten LCH.Clearnet's clearing volumes.

Titular: Total might sue ICE over B-share payments
Texto: Total, the French oil group, has threatened to launch legal action against InterContinentalExchange, the online commodities exchange, over its plan to pay out $67.5m to its B shareholders.The move by Total, one of the original backers of ICE when the exchange was set up in May 2000, adds uncertainty to the payment to the B shareholders.ICE first mooted the payment in June in an effort to appease discontented shareholders. They have yet to receive any money for selling their interests three years ago in the London-based International Petroleum Exchange, the world's second-largest energy futures exchange.The original payment was conditional on the IPE moving to electronic trading.IPE members, many of whom are B shareholders, received a letter this week highlighting the latest twist to this long-running saga.The letter said that the payment had been held up because of the threat of legal action by one of the A shareholders on ICE and its directors, and that any decision had to wait until the issue was resolved.Although Total was not mentioned by name in the letter, sources close to the IPE said that the French company was behind the threat after voting against the proposal this month.Total, which owns about 4 per cent of ICE, would make no comment. A spokeswoman for ICE said that the exchange would not comment on any potential litigation issues, and was working hard to settle the dispute.Total's stance is in contrast to the overwhelming majority of shareholders - more than 90 per cent of both A and B classes - of the Atlanta-based commodities exchange who approved the payment. ICE's other shareholders include Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, Deutsche Bank and BP.Total has taken the view that ICE was under no obligation to make the payment to B shareholders because the original criterion for making the pay-out was not met. As part of the takeover, ICE promised to pay the B shareholders 12 months after the IPE had gone fully electronic.The lack of any cash payment since the takeover from ICE had created friction between IPE members and its owners, which led to ICE's decision to waive one of its original takeover conditions in order to allow early payment to B shareholders.Following this decision, IPE's management decided to shorten the opening hours of pit trading from November 1 in an effort to stimulate more screen trading, which only accounts for 4 per cent of total IPE turnover in Brent crude oil contracts.

Titular: Nymex turns down $1.6bn offer
Texto: The New York Mercantile Exchange has turned down a takeover bid from a private equity firm valuing the world's largest energy futures exchange at about $1.6bn.The decision announced on Friday comes just days after James Newsome, the former head of the Commodities and Futures Trading Commission and Nymex's regulator, took his post as the new president of the exchange.Mr Newsome was appointed Nymex president after the departure of Robert “Bo” Collins, who favoured the transaction with Parthenon Capital, a Boston private equity firm. People close to Nymex have said the Parthenon proposal caused a rift between Mr Collins and Mitchell Steinhause, the Nymex chairman.At a meeting with reporters last week, Mr Steinhause said he thought the members would not want to support the Parthenon deal, in which the private equity firm would have acquired 60 per cent of Nymex.The offer valued each of the Nymex's 816 seats at $2m. The eventual conclusion of the Parthenon deal was seen as the demise of the open-outcry, floor-based trading model at the Nymex and people close to the exchange said Mr Steinhause opposed it.Nymex has so far made little attempt to move towards full electronic trading, unlike its smaller rival the International Petroleum Exchange in London, which plans to reduce the opening hours of its trading floor in an effort to migrate more trading volume to its electronic system.Nymex has made a takeover bid for IPE's parent, the IntercontinentalExchange, valuing the Atlanta-based company at between $300m and $350m, according to industry sources. Jeffrey Sprecher, ICE chief executive, has acknowledged the bid and described it as an insult. The bid comes as the two companies have been engaged in a legal battle over the ICE's use of Nymex settlement prices to value some of its own products. Nymex is seeking damages for copyright infringement while the ICE retorted by alleging the Nymex broke anti-trust laws.Many analysts have said a merger between the Nymex and ICE would make sense strategically and would not necessarily trigger objections from regulators. Nymex has not acknowledged the ICE bid but has said it was open to merger talks.

Titular: Emerging market debt burdens may be sorely understated
Subtitular: Recent paper suggests overseas liabilities of EMs are greater than previously thought
Texto: For emerging economies, coronavirus struck first through the financial markets. Long before the numbers of cases and deaths in these countries began to spread alarm, many emerging markets experienced a sudden halt in foreign investment inflows.Overseas investors have taken $95bn out of EM stocks and bonds since late January, according to the Institute of International Finance, dwarfing the withdrawals that followed the onset of the global financial crisis in September 2008.As Covid-19 infections rise and fragile health systems struggle to cope, foreign investors may be low on the list of concerns for EM governments. But these outflows will have a big impact on the fiscal measures policymakers can bring to bear on the crisis.Emerging markets’ overseas liabilities, moreover, may be bigger than previously imagined. A paper published by Matteo Maggiori at Stanford and colleagues at Harvard, Chicago Booth and Columbia Business School suggests the true ownership of EM bonds by overseas investors is much greater than shown in standard data — in some countries, by many multiples.The paper also suggests that foreign holdings of shares issued by Chinese companies may be many times greater than the $160bn that shows up in US national accounts. Should US-China relations sour in the aftermath of the coronavirus crisis, these giant holdings could become a source of significant risk.Mr Maggiori and his colleagues question the normal practice of allocating securities in national accounts on the basis of the residency rather than the nationality of their issuer. It may make sense, for example, for a bond issued by a Brazilian subsidiary of Banco Santander to be added to the debt statistics of Brazil (the residency of its issuer) rather than Spain (the nationality of the issuer’s ultimate owner), because the bond’s proceeds are likely to be put to use in Brazil.But it makes much less sense for a bond issued by Petrobras International Finance Company, a Cayman Island subsidiary of the Brazilian oil group, to be added to the debt statistics of the Cayman Islands. Yet that is what happens in standard, residency-based financial statistics such as the US’s Treasury International Capital data (TIC) and the IMF’s Coordinated Portfolio Investment Survey (CPIS).Mr Maggiori says this results in a vast understatement of the investments by US, European and other international investors in emerging economies. So the academics developed an algorithm to reallocate the securities logged in the TIC and CPIS data according to nationality rather than residency.The results are startling. TIC data show that US ownership of Brazilian bonds at the end of 2017 amounted to $8bn, based on the residency of issuers. But restated by nationality, the total rises to $68bn. For Chinese bonds, the total rises from $3bn to $55bn. Mr Maggiori says the results sound a warning as the coronavirus crisis threatens to tip emerging markets into a debt crisis.“If we are going to see a wave of corporate defaults, it’s a risk worth thinking about that a lot of issuance has taken place offshore,” he said. “[Our work] shows that exposures are quite large.”What is also striking is the role played by tax havens such as the Cayman Islands. In the TIC data, of Brazil’s $59bn in reallocated bonds, $42bn were issued in tax havens. Of China’s $52bn, $44bn were issued in tax havens. The results also shine a light on the role of so-called variable interest equity structures in US investments in Chinese companies. VIEs allow US investors to hold shares in these companies, circumventing Chinese restrictions on foreign ownership of some operating businesses. But in these transactions what investors actually buy are shares in listed companies, generally resident in the Cayman Islands, that give them a claim on the profits of Chinese operating businesses.By reallocating such investments on the basis of nationality rather than residence, the paper shows that US “ownership” of Chinese companies at the end of 2017 was not $160bn, as shown in US national statistics, but $700bn. This puts it closer to the amount of Chinese ownership of US Treasuries, of about $1.1tn. This is significant because Chinese regulators are certainly aware of the smoke-and-mirrors act being carried out by VIEs. They could, should they wish, bring the practice to an end.Mr Maggiori is not suggesting they will. But he thinks the risk is worth noting. “You read a lot about the possibility of China dumping its US Treasuries but very little about the possibility of China imposing its own regulations. If we’re talking about one, we should certainly be talking about the other,” he said.jonathan.wheatley@ft.com
